superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter k *
[The twenty-second letter of the Alphabet, called kaAfN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap, or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; and it also belongs to the class called $ajariy~ap. It is a radical letter. ― -b2- As a numeral it denotes twenty. ＝ -A2- k, as a pronominal suffix, as a preposition, and as a particle of allocution, see Supplement.]

R. Q. 1 kaA^okaA^a *
, (K,) inf. n. kaA^okaA^apN; (TA;) and takaA^okaA^a↓, (S, K,) as also tkEkE; (S;) He drew back, or retired, and was cowardly. (S, K.) ― -b2- kaA^okaA^a, inf. n. kaA^okaA='N, [respecting the form of which see ZaA^oZaA^a,] He was very impatiently cowardly. (AA, K.) [In the CK., in the explanation of the inf. n., Aljabiynu is put for Aljubonu.] ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, He (a thief) ran away. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See R. Q. 2.

R. Q. 2 takaA^okaA^a *
He was prevented, or hindered. (Lth.) ― -b2- takaA^okaA^a fiY kalaAmihi He hesitated in his speech, and was unable to speak. (K.) ＝ -A2- takaA^okaA^a Ealayohi Aln~aAsu, (S, K, *) and kaA^okaA^a↓, (K,) The people collected around him; (S, K;) crowded, or pressed, upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And see R. Q. 1.

mutakaA^okiy^N *
Short. (S, K.)

1 kay^iba *
, aor.
kaAa^a
, inf. n. kaA^obapN and kaA=bapN (S, K) and kaA^obN (K) and kaA^obaA='u; (TA;) and AktA^b↓; (S, K;) He was in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; (S, K;) he was in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad. (K.) See also 4.

4 AkA^bhu *
He caused him to grieve, or mourn, or to be unhappy, sorrowful, or sad; (K;) threw him into grief, or mourning, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- AkA^b He was in grief, or mourning; was unhappy, sorrowful, or sad: (K:) or he entered upon a state of grief, mourning, unhappiness, sorrow, or sadness; or a state of being changed and broken in spirit by reason of intense anxiety. (TA.) See also 1. ＝ -A2- He fell into destruction, or ruin. (K.)

8 AktA^b wajohu AlA^aroDi *
(tropical:) [The face of the earth, or land, became of sad aspect]. (TA.) See 1.

kay^ibN *
: see kay^iybN.

kaA^obaA='u *
Grief, mourning, unhappiness, sorrow, or sadness: (K:) [in which sense the inf. n. kaA=bapN is more commonly used:] or intense grief, &c.: used both as an inf. n. and as an epithet. (TA.) See kay^iybN.

kuw^abapN *
i. q. tuw^abapN, in the following phrase maA bihi kw^bpN There is nothing in him for which he should be ashamed. (K.)

kay^iybN *
(S, K) and kay^ibN↓ and makotay^ibN↓ (K) A man in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; (S, K;) in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad. (K.) kay^iybapN and kaA^obaA='u↓ the same, as applied to a woman. (S.) ― -b2- AlArD kay^iybapu Alwajohi (tropical:) [The earth, or land, is of sad aspect.] (TA.)

mukotay^ibN *
see kay^iybN. ― -b2- ramaAdN mukotay^ibu All~awoni Ashes of a colour inclining to black; (S, K;) as is the colour of him who is in an evil state, or broken [in spirit] by grief. (S.)

1 kaA^ada *
, aor.
kaAa^a
, He was in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; or was in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad, syn. kay^iba. (K.)

5 takaA^~adaniY *
and takaA='adaniY↓ It (a thing, or an affair,) was difficult to me; it distressed, troubled, fatigued, or wearied, me. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- tkA^~d Al$~aYo'a He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the thing, in spite of difficulty, trouble or inconvenience; he constrained himself to do the thing, notwithstanding it was difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient, to him. (L, K.) You say takaA^~adotu Al*~ahaAba A_ilaY fulaAnK, meaning, I [constrained myself to go, and] went to such a one, in spite of difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience. (AZ, L.) ― -b3- He endured the thing; struggled with, or against, it; contended with its difficulty, or severity; underwent difficulties, troubles, or inconveniences, in doing it; endured, or bore, its heat and severity; syn. kaAbadahu, and SaliYa bihi. (IAar, L, K.)

6 takaA~a^a
see 5.

kaA^odaA='u *
Difficulty. (IAar, L, K.) ― -b2- Grief; sorrow; mourning; syn. HuzonN: so accord. to the K; but accord. to IAar [and the L] fear; syn. xawofN: (TA:) and caution: (IAar, L.) ― -b3- Injustice. (K.) ― -b4- A dark night. (IAar, L, K.) ― -b5- See also kaw^uwdN.

EaqabapN kaw^uwdN *
, (S, L, K,) and kaA^odaA='u↓, (L, K,) A mountain-road difficult of ascent. (S, L, K. *) Such a road is also termed [simply] kaA^odaA='u, and SuEadaA='u: [in the K it is said, that kuw^adaA='u is syn. with SuEadaA='u:] and kaw^uwdN [in like manner, as a subst.,] signifies. a difficult place of ascent: like SaEuwdN. (L, TA.)

kaA^osN *
, (ISk, S, A, Msb, K,) and kaAsN, with the ' suppressed, is allowable, (Msb,) and sometimes occurs, (TA,) A drinking-cup: (A, K:) or [a cup of wine; i. e.] a cup containing wine; (S, A, K;) or a cup full of wine: (Msb:) when not containing wine, it is not thus called; (IAar, S, Msb;) being in this case called qadaHN: (TA:) or it has the first and the second of these significations: (TA:) or it signifies wine itself: (As, AHát, Ibn-'Abbád:) or has this signification also: (K:) and is of the fem. gender: (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akow^usN and [of mult.] kuw^uwsN and kiy^aAsN, (S, Msb, K,) the last with ', (TA, [but written without ' in the CK,]) and, accord. to AHn, kiyaAsN, without ', which, if correct, is originally kiwaAsN, from kaAsN, with the ' changed into A as representing w, (TA,) and
kaAsaAtN, (K,) without '. (TA.) It is used metaphorically in relation to every kind of disagreeable, hateful, or evil, things. Thus you say, saqaAhu kaA^osFA mina Al*~ul~i (tropical:) [He gave him to drink a cup of abasement]: and mina Alfuroqapi (tropical:) [of separation]: and mina Almawoti (tropical:) [of death]: and mina AlHub~i (tropical:) [of love]. (TA.) You say also, saqaAhu AlkaA^osa AlA^amar~a (tropical:) [He gave him to drink the most bitter cup]; meaning death: (A, TA:) and kuw^uwsa AlmanaAyaA (tropical:) [The cups of death; lit., deaths]. (A.) Az. thinks that it may be derived from kaASa fulaAnN mina AlT~aEaAmi waAl$~araAbi, meaning, “ Such a one ate and drank much ”; because S and s are interchangeable in many words on account of the nearness of their places of utterance. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 kaA^ana fiY xaloqihi *
He, (a man) was strong in his make (IAar, in TA, voce kanata.)

kaA^oniY~N *
A man strong in his make. (IAar, in TA, voce kanata.)

kaA^K *
and kA'K: see kaA^aY~K or kaA^ay~ino in art. A^aY~N (p. 134 a.)
See art. kyA^.

1 kab~ahu *
, aor.
kabu3a
, (inf. n. kab~N, TA;) and kabokabahu; (K, TA;) He inverted it, or turned it upside-down. (K.) ― -b2- kab~a AlA_inaA='a, aor
kabu3a
, inf. n. kab~N, [He inverted, or turned down, the vessel, so as to pour out its contents]: (TA:) he turned the vessel over upon its head. (Msb.) ― -b3- kab~a AlqaSoEapa He turned over the wooden bowl upon its face. (TA.) ― -b4- kab~ahu, (K,) or kb~h liwajohihi, (S,) [or EalaY wajohihi (see 4),] and Akb~h↓ (K) and kabokabahu↓, (S, K,) He prostrated him; threw him down upon his face. (S, K.) [One says,] kab~a All~`hu Eaduw~a Almusolimiyna [May God overthrow, or prostrate, the enemy of the Muslims!]: but one should not say Akb~↓. (S.) See also 4. ― -b5- He cut, or wounded, a camel in the legs. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kab~a, (aor.
kabu3a
, inf. n. kab~u, TA,) (tropical:) He [convolved, or glomerated, thread, and likewise hair (see faliylN), or he] made thread [&c.] into kubab [or balls]: (S, K:) or into a kub~ap [or ball]. (ISd.) [The verb is used in the present day to signify He wound thread into a ball, or balls.] See 5. ＝ -A3- kab~a, [aor., app.,
kabi3a
,] He, or it, was weighty, or heavy. (K.) See kub~apN ＝ -A4- He kindled, or set on fire, kub~, which is [a plant, or tree, of the kind called] HamoD. (AA, K.)

2 kb~b *
, inf. n. takobiybN, (tropical:) He made kabaAb, or meat cut up, &c. (K.)

4 A^akoba3a
See 1. ＝ -A2- Akb~ He bent his head down towards the ground; [as also A_ilaY AlA^aroDi Ankb~↓, occurring in the TA, art brz;] bent himself down; stooped. (TA.) [See Kur, lxvii, 22.] ― -b2- Akb~, (K,) or Akb~ EalaY wajohihi, (S) and Ankb~↓, (TA,) quasi-pass. of kab~a; He fell prostrate or prone; fell upon his face: (S, K:) the former verb extr. with respect to analogy, (S,) [as quasipass. of kab~a: see A^aHojama, and A^aHonaja]: [and kab~a↓, aor., app.,
kabi3a
, inf. n. kab~N, he fell, having stumbled: for] kab~N is the contr. of AinotiEaA$N. (S, art. tE$.) ― -b3- Akb~ lahu (i. e., lil$~aYo'i, TA) i. q. taHaAnaY (as in some copies of the K) or tajaAnaA^a (as in others): the latter [meaning He bent down towards it] is probably the correct reading. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Akb~ Ealayohi, (i. e., ElY Al$~aYo'i, TA,) and Ankb~↓, (assumed tropical:) He fell to, or set about, doing it. (K.) Akb~ ElY AlA^amori yafoEaluhu, and Ankb~↓, [He fell to, or set about, the thing, to do it]. (S.) ＝ -A4- Akb~ Ealayohi, (i. e., ElY EamalK, TA,) and Ankb~↓, (tropical:) He kept, or adhered, to it; (K;) i. e., to a work. (TA.)

5 tkb~bt AlA_ibilu *
The camels were prostrated by disease (S, K) or emaciation. (S.) ＝ -A2- tkb~b (tropical:) It (sand) became contracted (by reason of its moisture, TA,) into a compact mass: (S:) or became moist, and, in consequence, compact: whence kub~apu gazolK [a ball of spun thread], as indicated by Z in the A. (TA.) ― -b2- tkb~b (tropical:) He wrapped himself up in his garment: (A:) [as also tkbkb↓: ex.] jaA'a mutakabokibFA fiY viyaAbihi He came wrapped up in his garment. (S.)

6 tkAb~wA Ealayohi *
(tropical:) They pressed together, or crowded together, upon it. (TA.) [See t~akaAt~uwA, in art. kt.]

7 Ankb~ *
It (a jug, or the like) was, or became, inverted, or turned down, so as to pour out its contents. (IB, in TA, voce garabN.) ― -b2- See 4, in five places.

R. Q. 1 kabokabahu *
He turned him over, one part upon another: or threw him from the top of a mountain or wall. (TA.) See 1, in two places. ― -b2- kabokabahu, inf. n. kabokabapN, He threw him into a deep place, or hollow. (K.) fakubokibuwA fiyhaA [Kur, xxvi, 9 4,] And they shall be thrown prostrate therein: [i. e., into the fire of hell:] (S:) or they shall be collected together and thrown down into it, namely, the abyss of hell-fire: (Lth:) lit., they shall be thrown so as to turn over and over until at length they come to a stop therein: (TA:) or they shall be thrown into it, one upon another: (Zj:) or they shall be collected together therein. (TA.) ― -b3- kbkb AlmaAla He collected together, and brought or put back, the extremities of what was scattered of the wealth or property: [meaning, he collected the camels &c. by driving together those that were dispersed:] like kamohalahu and dabokalahu &c. (L.)

R. Q. 2 takabokabuwA *
(tropical:) They collected themselves together. (TA.) ― -b2- See 5.

kub~N *
, [coll. gen. n., A plant or tree, of the kind called] HamoD; (K;) a kind of tree excellent for kindling, the leaves of which make the tails of horses beautiful and long; it has joints and thorns, and grows in fine, or soft, and plain soil: n. un. with p: or, accord. to some, it is [a plant, or tree,] of the kind called najiylu AlfalaApi: but IAar says, among the [plants, or trees, called] HamoD, are the njyl and the kb~. (TA.)

kab~apN *
and kub~apN↓ A charge, an assault, or an onslaught, in war. (K) [And] kab~apN (S, K) and kub~apN↓ (K) A single impetus [in some copies of the S, dafoEap; in others, and in my copies of the K, dufoEap: I prefer the former reading:] in fighting and in running [in the CK, wAljaroYu, which is doubtless a mistake]: (S, K:) and vehemence thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- kab~apN and kub~apN↓ A collision between two troops of horses: in the K, biyona Aljabalayoni; but correctly, bayona Alxayolayoni, as in other lexicons. (TA.) ― -b3- kab~apN (S, K) and kub~apN↓ (K) A letting loose, or setting free, horses, (S, K,) upon the race-course, or field, to run, or to charge. (S.) [This is evidently meant in the S as an explanation of the words rendered here “ a single impetus ” &c.] ― -b4- kab~apN (S, K) and kub~apN↓ (K) The vehemence and assault [in some copies of the S, dafoEap: in others, and in my copies of the K, dufoEap: I prefer the former reading:] of winter. (S, K) ― -b5- kab~apu Aln~aAri A dash, or dashing of the fire [of hell]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kab~apN and kub~apN↓ and kabokabapN↓ and kibokibapN↓ and kibokibN↓ or (accord. to the TA) kabokabN↓, A throwing into a deep place, or hollow. (K.) See kabokaba. ＝ -A3- See also kub~apN.

kub~apN *
: see kab~apN passim. ＝ -A2- Alkb~ [a mistranscription for Alkub~apu, as is shown by the next sentence,] What is collected together, of dust, or earth, and of other things. (TA [See also safaApN, voce safFA.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) kub~apN (tropical:) A jarawohaq (which is not an Arabic word, TA, [but arabicized, from the Persian kuruwhaho guróhah, signifying a ball] of spun thread: (S, K:) or such as is collected together, [or convolved, so as to
form a ball,] of spun thread: (TA: [see 5:]) pl. kubabN. (S, K.) [And it is likewise of hair: see faliylN.] ― -b3- [Hence,] kub~apN (S, K) and kubokubapN↓ (S) or kabokabapN↓ (K) (tropical:) A company, congregated body, or troop, (K,) of horses, (S,) or of men. (TA.) kbkbpN mino baniY A_isoraAy^iyla A company of the Children of Israel. (TA, from a trad.) kub~apu Als~uwqi The company of the market: said in a trad. to be the company of Satan. (TA.) ramaAhumo bikub~atihi [He threw upon them] his troop, or company. (TA.) See also below. ― -b4- A herd of great camels. (K.) A_in~aka lakaA@lbaAy^iEK Alkub~apa biAlhub~api Verily thou art like the seller of a herd of great camels for wind. A proverb, thus related by AZ: but, as related by some, Alkbp bAlhbp, without teshdeed: see arts. kbw and hbw. (TA.) ― -b5- kub~apu Alxayoli The greater number, or main part, of the troop of horses. (Th.) ― -b6- I. q. EiyaAlN: so in the phrase Ealayohi kb~pN [He has a family, or household, dependant upon him]. (TA.) ― -b7- kub~apN (K) and kab~apN↓ (S, K) (tropical:) A pressing, or crowding, together. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- kub~apN Weight. (K.) So in the saying ramaAhumo bikub~atihi [He threw upon them his weight]. (TA.) (But see above.) And A^aloqaY Ealayohi kub~atahu He threw his weight upon him. (TA.)

kabaAbN *
i. q. TabaAhajN; (S;) i. e., (TA,) (tropical:) Flesh-meat cut up [into small pieces] (K) and roasted, or broiled; or thrown upon burning coals: (TA:) [small morsels of meat, generally mutton or lamb, roasted on skewers]. Asserted by El-Khafájee to be Persian; and thought to be so by Yaakoob. (TA.)

kubaAbN *
A large number of camels or of sheep or goats. (K.) Also used as an epithet: ex. naEamN kubaAbN Camels, or camels and sheep or goats, so numerous that one mounts upon another. (TA.) naEamN kubaAkibN Many camels, or camels and sheep or goats. (TA.) See also kuvaAbN ＝ -A2- Dust; earth. (K.) ― -b2- Adhesive mud; or clay. (K.) ― -b3- Moist earth. (K.) ― -b4- An abundance of moist, or soft, earth, that cleaves together. (TA.) ― -b5- Sand that is contracted (by reason of its moisture, TA,) into a compact mass: (S:) sand that has become moist, and, in consequence, compact. (TA.)

kabaAbapN *
A certain medicine (S, K) of China: (K:) [cubeb, or piper cubebae.]

kibokibN *
and kabokabN, see kab~apN ＝ -A2- A certain game (K) of the Arabs. (TA.)

kubokubN *
and kubaAkibu A man (TA) of compact (and strong, TA,) make: pl. kabaAkibu. (K.)

kabokabapN *
and kibokibapN, see kub~apN.

kubokubapN *
see kubokuwbN.

kabokaAbN *
An excellent kind of thick dates. (K.)

kubokuwbN *
and kubokuwbapN and kubokubapN↓ A closely congregated body of men. (K.)

kabokaAbapN *
A fat woman. (K.)

rajulN A^akab~u *
A man who is constantly stumbling. (TA.)

mikab~N *
and mikobaAbN↓ One who looks much towards the ground. (K.)

mukab~abapN *
A dust-coloured wheat, with thick ears, (K,) like small birds, and a thick straw, the eaters of which [namely the straw, a common fodder in Arabia,] do not become brisk, or sprightly. (TA.)

mikobaAbN *
see mikab~N.

1 kabatahu *
, aor.
kabita
, (inf. n. kabotN, TA,) He threw him down prostrate; (K;) as also kabatahu liwajohihi: (S:) he threw him, or it, down upon his, or its face; like kab~ahu: this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- kabatahu All~`hu liwajohihi May God prostrate him, so that he may not succeed in his enterprise, or may not gain the victory! (TA.) ― -b3- kabata AlkaAfira He (God) prostrated the unbeliever, and denied him what he desired, or disappointed him, or caused him to fail of attaining his desire. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- kabatahu He repelled him (i. e. an enemy) in his rage, or wrath. (K.) ― -b5- I. q. kasarahu [here app. signifying He routed him; or put him to flight.] (K.) ― -b6- kabatahu, (inf. n. kabotN, S,) He turned away, or averted, him: (S, K:) and abased him; debased him; rendered him vile, despicable, or ignominious. (S, K.) Syn. A^a*al~ahu and A^axozaAhu (K) Ex. kabata All~`hu AlEaduw~a God averted and abased the enemy. (S.) ― -b7- kubituwA kamaA kubita Al~a*iyna mino qabolihimo, in the Kur, [lviii, 6,] signifies, They [who oppose God and his Apostle] have been abased, and punished, by their being overcome, like as those who were before them, of such as opposed God, were abased, &c.: (Zj:) or they have been enraged, and grieved, on the occasion of the war of the Moat, like as those who were before them, who fought with the prophets, were enraged and grieved: (Fr:) in favour of which latter interpretation it has been argued, that Alkbt is formed from Alkbd, the liver, by the substitution of t for d, and that the liver is the source of rage and malevolence. (Az.) ＝ -A2- kabatahu i. q. kabadahu, He smote, or hurt, his liver. (TA.) ― -b2- kabata gayoZahu fiY jawofihi (tropical:) He restrained his rage in his inside [or bosom]. You say, mano kabata gayoZahu fiY jawofihi kabata All~`hu Eaduw~ahu mino xawofihi [Whoso restraineth his rage in his bosom, God will avert and abase his enemy, through fear of him]. (A.)

7 Ankbt *
He was thrown down, or fell down, prostrate; or, upon his face. (TA.)

kbt *
[app. kabotN or kibotN or kabitN] i. q. kabidN The liver. Ex. baruda kbtuhu [His liver became cool: i. e., his rage became assuaged]. ('Ináyeh.)

kabotN *
Rage or wrath; and grief, or sorrow. ('Ináyeh.)

makobuwtN *
pass. part. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Also, Affected with violent grief, or sorrow: originally makobuwdN: i. e., having his liver affected by grief, or sorrow. (TA, from a trad.)

mukotabitN *
Filled with grief, or sorrow; (K;) or with rage, or wrath. (TA.)

1 kabiva *
, aor.
kabava
, It (flesh meat) became altered and stinking. (S, K,) ― -b2- kabava, (aor.
kabuva
, inf. n. kabovN, TK,) He covered over (gam~) flesh-meat, (K,) so that it became altered and stinking. (TK.)

2 kb~v Als~afiynapa *
, inf. n. takobiyvN, He inclined the ship towards the shore, and transferred what was in it to another ship. (K.)

kabaAvN *
[coll. gen. n.] What is ripe of the fruit of the A^araAk; (IAar, S, K;) what is unripe thereof being called bariyr: (S:) or what has become black thereof: (TA in art. brm: [see also marodN:]) or what is unripe thereof: (M:) or, as some say, the fruit of that tree when scattered: n. un. with p: (TA:) the kbAv are, in quantity (miqodaAr), a little above the grains of the coriander, and fill both the hands of a man; being more than a camel takes at once into his mouth. (AHn.)

laHomN kabiyvN *
, and makobuwvN↓, Flesh-meat that has been covered, (K,) [and] become [in consequence] altered and stinking. (TK.) AA explains kabiyvN by the words laHomN qado gum~a. (TA.)

kunobuvN *
and kunobuwvN and kunaAbivN Hard and strong. (K.) ― -b2- Also, all the three words, Contracted [in disposition], and niggardly, or stingy. (K.) Accord. to some, the n is a radical letter. (TA.) [See also art. knbv.]

makobuwvN *
: see kabiyvN.

1 kabaHa Ald~aAb~apa *
, (aor.
kabaHa
, inf. n. kaboHN, L,) He pulled in the horse, or the like, by the bridle and bit, (and struck its mouth with the bit, L,) in order that it might stop, (S, L, K,) and not run; (S, L;) as also A^akobaHahaA↓; (Yaakoob, K;) or you say AkmHhA and AkfHhA and kbHhA [only]; the last alone without A: (As, S:) or he (the rider) pulled its head towards him, and prevented its being refractory, and its overcoming him, and going quickly: so in the Nh, the explanation in which is incorrectly given by
Mullà 'Alee Káree: (TA:) or AkbHh↓ signifies he pulled up his head by the bridle, so as to make it upright, or erect; (Msb;) and so kabaHahu. (A.) ― -b2- kabaHa fulaAnFA Eano HaAjatihi (tropical:) He turned such a one back from, or made him to revert from, or relinquish, the thing that he wanted. (L, K.) ― -b3- kabaHa AlHaAy^iTu Als~ahoma (tropical:) The wall made the arrow, striking it, to turn from its course, without its sticking in it. (L.) ― -b4- kabaHahu He struck him with a sword, (K,) upon his flesh, not upon a bone. (Msb.)

3 kAbHhu *
: see qAbHh.

4 A^akobaHa
see 1, in two places.

kaAbiHN *
That which presents itself before thee, (K,) or he who presents himself before thee, (T, L,) of such objects as are of evil omen, (T, L, K,) as a he-goat &c.; (L;) because it turns him back from his course: (TA:) pl. kawaAbiHu. (L, K.)

1 kabadahu *
, (aor.
kabida
, AZ, L, K, and
kabuda
, L, K, inf. n. kabodN, L,) He, or it, hit, or smote, or hurt, his kabid [or liver]: (AZ, S, IKtt, L:) or struck it. (L, K.) ― -b2- kabadahumu Albarodu, (aor.
kabida
and
kabuda
, K,) (assumed tropical:) The cold affected them severely; distressed them; straitened them: (L, K:) or, smote their livers; which only the most intense cold does. (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- kabida, aor.
kabada
, (L, K,) inf. n. kabadN, (L,) He had a pain in his liver: (L, K) and (A, L:) or kubida, (K,) inf. n. kubaAdN, (TA,) he had a complaint of his liver. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- kabida, aor.
kabada
, (L,) inf. n. kabadN, (S, L, K,) He was big in the belly, (L, K,) in its upper part: (L:) he (a man) was bulky in the middle, and therefore slow in his pace. (S, L.) ― -b2- It (anything) was big, or large, and thick, in the middle. (L.) ＝ -A3- See 5.

2 kab~ada
See 5.

3 kAbd AlA^amora *
, (inf. n. mukaAbadapN and kibaAdN, L, K,) (tropical:) He endured the thing; struggled, or contended, with, or against, it; struggled or contended with, or against, its difficulty, or severity; syn. qaAsaAhu, (L, K,) or qaAsaY $id~athu; (S;) he endured, or struggled, or contended, with or against, its difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience; syn. EaAnaY ma$aq~atahu: (L:) he underwent difficulties, troubles, or inconveniences, in doing it. (Msb.) ― -b2- kAbd All~ayola (tropical:) He (a man) braved (rakiba) the terribleness and difficulty of the night. And kaAbadotu Zulomapa h`*ihi All~ayolapi mukaAbadapF $adiydapF I braved the darkness of this night with a mighty braving. (Lth, L.) ― -b3- baEoDuhumo yukaAbidu baEoDFA (tropical:) [One party of them struggles, contends, or strives, against the opposition of the other]: said of adversaries in a contest, litigation, or the like. (A.)

5 tkb~dhu *
(tropical:) He tended, or betook himself, or directed himself or his course, to, or towards, it, namely, an affair, (L, K,) and a town or country; syn. qaSadahu; (L, K;) as also kabadahu↓, aor.
kabida
and
kabuda
. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- tkb~d (tropical:) It (milk) became thick; (S, A, L, K;) as also any other beverage; (L;) and (the former) became thick like liver, so as to quiver. (L.) ＝ -A3- tkb~dt Al$~amosu, (S, A,) or tkb~dt Al$msu Als~amaA='a, (L, K,) (tropical:) The sun became in the kabid, (S, L,) or kubayodaA=', (K,) of the sky; (S, L, K;) became in the middle of the sky; culminated; (A;) as also kb~dt↓, inf. n. takobiydN: (K:) and Aln~ajomu Als~amaA='a kb~d↓ the star, or asterism, [or the Pleiades,] culminated. (S, L.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce xa$afa.] ― -b2- tk~bd AlfalaApa (tropical:) He directed his course to, or towards, the middle and main part of the desert. (L.)

kabodN *
and kibodN: see kabidN.

kabadN *
(tropical:) Difficulty; distress; affliction; trouble. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) Ex. waqaEa fiY kabadK He fell into difficulty, &c. (A.) So in the words of the Kur, [xc, 4,] laqado xalaqonaA A@loA_inosaAna fiY kabadK Verily we have created man in difficulty, &c., (S, L, Jel,) in a state in which he has to contend with the afflictions of the present life and the difficulties pertaining to the life to come: (Zj, * Jel:) or fY kbd here signifies, in a right and just state: (Aboo-Tálib, L:) or in an erect state, and in just proportion: (Fr; L:) or in an erect state, and walking upon his two legs; whereas other animals are not erect: or in the belly of his mother, with his head towards her head; in which state the child remains until near the birth, when it becomes inverted. (L.) ― -b2- And see kaAbidN and kabidN.

kabidN *
, (S, L, Msb, K, &c.,) the most chaste and best known form of the word, (TA,) and kibodN↓, (S, L, Msb, K,) a contraction of the former, (Msb,) and kabodN↓, (S, L, K,) also a contraction of the first, (S,) [The liver;] a certain black piece of flesh on the right of the lungs: (L:) fem., and sometimes masc.; (Fr, L, Msb, K;) or fem. only: (Lh, ISd, L, Msb:) pl. A^akobaAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and kubuwdN; (L, Msb, K;) the latter seldom used. (Msb) ― -b2- Also, [the first,] (tropical:) The place of the liver, outside: (L;) the side. (K) It is said in a trad., fawaDaEa yadahu EalaY kabidiY, meaning, And he put his hand upon my side externally; or, upon the external part of my side, next the liver. (L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The inside of an animal, altogether. (Kr, ISd, K.) Sometimes used in this sense. (Kr, ISd.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The inside, meaning a cave, or ravine, of a mountain. (L.) ― -b5- kabidu AlA^aroDi (tropical:) The interior of the earth: (Msb:) or the minerals (maEaAdin) of the earth: (A:) or the gold and silver and the like that are in the mines of the earth: (L:) pl. A^akobaAdN (A, L) and kubuwdN. (L.) It is said in a trad. wataloqiY AlA^aroDu A^afolaA*a kabidihaA (tropical:) And the earth shall cast forth what is hidden in her belly, of treasures and minerals. (L.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The middle of anything, (A, L, Msb, K, *) and its main part. (L, K.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The middle of the sea. (L.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The middle of a butt for archers. (A, L.) ― -b9- daAruhu kabida najodK (tropical:) His house is in the middle of Nejd. (A.) ― -b10- kabidN; (L;) in the K, kabadN↓; but none [except F] says so; (MF;) The middle of a tract of sand, (L, K,) and its main part. (L.) ― -b11- kabidN; (S, A, L, Msb;) in the K, kabadN↓; but none [except F] says so; (MF;) and kabodN↓, and kabodaA='u↓, (K,) and kubayodaAtN↓, (S, A, L,) as though they had formed the dim. kubayodapN from kabidN, and then formed the pl.; (S, L;) in the K, kubayodaApN; but this is wrong; (TA;) and kubayodaA='u↓, (L, Msb, K,) dim. of kabidN, contr. to rule, like suwayodaA='u; (Msb;) [or dim. of kabodaA='u;] (tropical:) The middle of the sky, (S, A, L, K,) and its main part: (L;) or [the meridian of the sky;] the middle of the sky, wherein is the sun at the time of its declining from the meridian: (L:) or the part of the middle of the sky which faces the spectator. (Lth, L, Msb.) ― -b12- kabidN (Lh, L; in the K, kabadN;) (assumed tropical:) The air; (Lh, L, K;) as also kabodaA='u↓. (L.) ― -b13- kabidN (tropical:) of a bow, The handle: (S, A, Msb:) or the part a little above the handle, (Az, L, Msb,) against which the arrow goes: (Az, L:) or the part between the two extremities of the handle, and that along which the arrow runs: (S, L:) or the part [midway] between the two extremities of its suspensory string or cord or the like: (As, L, K:) [see rijolN:] or the space of a cubit from its handle: (L, K:) or each part where the thong of its suspensory string or the like is tied: (L:) in the bow is its kabid, which is the part [midway] between the two extremities of its suspensory string or the like; then, next to this, the kuloyap; then, next to this, the A^abohar; then, next to this, the TaAy^if; then, the siy^ap, which is the curved part of each extremity. (As, L.) ― -b14- fulaAnN tuDorabN A_ilayoh A^akobaAdu AlA_ibili Such a one is a person to whom men journey seeking knowledge &c. (S, L, K.) [See an ex. in the first paragraph of art. Drb.] ― -b15- suwdN AlA^akobaAdi [Black-livered men;] a designation of enemies, (As, S, L, K,) similar to Suhobu Als~ibaAli [q. v.]: (As, S, L:) they are so called because the effects of rancour, or malevolence, have [as it were] burnt their livers so that they have become black; the liver being the source of enmity. (L.)

kbodaA'u *
: see kabidN, and A^akobadu.

kubaAdN *
Pain of the liver: (S, L, K:) or a disease, or complaint, of the liver. (L.) The only known word, signifying a disease, derived from the name of the member affected, except nukaAfN and qulaAbN. (Kr.) It
is said in a trad. AlkubaAdu mina AlEab~i, (S, L,) i. e., The pain, or disease, of the liver is from drinking water without sipping. (L.)

kubayodaA'u *
and kubayodaAtN: see kabidN.

kab~aAdN *
A certain species of the layomuwn; [citrus limon sponginus Ferrari: (Delile, Flor. Aeg. Illustr., no. 748:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p]. (TA.)

kaAbidN *
(tropical:) a subst. from kaAbada, (ISd, L, K,) [in the sense of mukaAbadapN: see 3:] as also kabadN↓. (MF.) Ex. of the former,
walayolapK mina All~ayaAliY mar~ato
bikaAbidK kaAbadotuhaA wajar~ato
[Many a night of nights has passed with a struggling against its severity: I have struggled against its severity; and it was long]. Said by El-'Ajjáj. jr~t signifies TAlt. (L.) ― -b2- You also say, of adversaries in a contest, litigation, or the like, mino A^amorihimo A_in~ahumo fiY kabadK↓ (tropical:) [Verily they are in a state of struggling, contention, or strife, against mutual opposition with respect to their affair]. (A.)

A^akobadu *
Anything big, or large, and thick, in the middle. (L.) ― -b2- kabodaA='u A she-camel large in the middle: (L:) and in like manner, a tract of sand, ramolapN. (L, K.) ― -b3- A^akobadu Big in the upper part of the belly: (L:) a man bulky in the middle, and therefore slow in his pace: fem. kabodaA='u. (S, L, K. *) ― -b4- Having the place of his liver rising, or prominent. (K.) ― -b5- qawosN kabodaA='u (tropical:) A bow of which the handle fills the hand: (S, A, L, K:) or, of which the part called the kabid is thick and strong. (L.) ― -b6- kabodaA='u (assumed tropical:) A mill that is turned with the hand: (L, K:) so called because of the difficulty, or trouble, with which it is turned. (L.) ＝ -A2- See makobuwdN. ＝ -A3- A^akobadu A certain bird. (K.)

makobuwdN *
Hit, or hurt, in his liver. (S.) See makobuwtN ― -b2- Having a complaint of his liver: (TA:) and A^akobadu↓ signifies the same: (A, L:) or this latter, having a pain in his liver. (L.)

1 kabura *
, aor.
kabura
, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. kuborN (A, Msb, K) and kibarN and kabaArapN, (A, K,) He, (TA,) or it, (Msb,) was, or became, great, [big, or large in body, or corporeal substance: and in years, or age; (when said of a human being, often particularly signifying he attained to puberty;) and in estimation or rank or dignity;] contr. of Dagura; (A, K;) syn. EaZuma, (S, Msb, K,) and jasuma. (K.) [In the K the pret. is twice mentioned: where it is explained as signifying the contr. of Sagura, the above inf. ns. are mentioned, as in the A: where it is explained by EaZuma and jasuma in the K, no inf. n. is mentioned; but in the TA it is there said that in the sense of EaZuma it relates to an affair or case, and that the inf. n. is kibarN and kabaArapN; and that in the sense of jasuma it relates to anything.] ― -b2- kabura AlA^amoru [The affair, or case, was, or became, of great moment; it was, or became, momentous: or it signifies as in the phrase next following]. (A.) ― -b3- kabura Ealayohi AlA^amoru The affair, or case, was, or became, difficult, hard, severe, grievous, distressing, afflictive, troublesome, or burdensome, to him or in its effect upon him; syn. $aq~a. (A, * TA.) In this sense the verb is used in the Kur, x, 72, (TA,) and xlii, 11. (Bd, ii. 42.) And so in the Kur again, xvii, 53, A^awo xaloqFA mim~aA yakoburu fiY Sduwrikumo, (TA,) meaning, A^awoxaloqFA mim~aA yakoburu Einodakumo Eano qubuwli AlHayaApi [Or a created thing of those which are too difficult in your minds to receive life], as being the thing most remote from capability to receive life. (Bd.) [This signification is from the primary application of the verb.] ＝ -A2- kabira, aor.
kabara
, inf. n. kibarN and makobirN, He (a man, S, a human being, and a beast, TA, and a child, Msb,) became full-grown, or old, or advanced in age. (S, K.) Hence the prov., kabira Eamoruw Eani AlT~awoqi: see art. Twq.] ― -b2- [In modern Arabic, and, I believe, sometimes, in classic authors, it also signifies He became big; (said of a boy, or child, in the TA in art. rE, &c.;) i. e. attained to full growth: and to adolescence: and to puberty: see kabiyrN.] This form of the verb and that first mentioned are sometimes erroneously used, each for the other, by persons of distinction as well as by the vulgar. (TA.) ― -b3- See kaborapN, below. ＝ -A3- kaAbarotuhu fakabarotuhu, aor. of the latter,
kabura
: see 3. ― -b2- kabarahu bisanapK, aor.
kabura
, He exceeded me in age by a year. (K.) And maA kabaraniY A_il~aA bisanapK He did not exceed me in age save by a year. (IAar.)

2 kb~r *
, inf. n. tkabiyrN, He made a thing great. (K.) ― -b2- He magnified, or honoured; syn. EaZ~ama. (S) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, and kib~aArN, (Sgh, K,) which latter is of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab and many of the people of El-Yemen, (Sgh,) He said Aall~`hu A^akobar. (K.) See A^akobaru, below.

3 kaAbarotuhu fakabarotuhu *
, aor. of the latter
kabura
, [I contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in greatness, and I overcame him therein.] (A.) You say kaAbara fulaAnN fulaAnFA Such a one disputed with such a one for superiority in greatness, and said I am greater than thou. (A.) ― -b2- kAbrhu, inf. n. mukaAbarapN, He vied with him; or contended with him for superiority; syn. gaAlabahu: and he contended against him; or he contended against him, or disputed with him, not knowing the truth or falsity of what he or his adversary said; syn. EaAnadahu: (Msb:) or he contended or disputed with him, knowing that what he himself said was false, and that what his adversary said was true. (Kull, p. 342.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., laAtukaAbiruwA AlS~alaApa, meaning, laA tugaAlibuwhaA [app., Contend not ye against prayer.] (TA.) ― -b4- kuwbira faA^abaY [It was contended with, and refused, or would not]: said of what he would utter by a man who had an impediment in his speech. (A.) ― -b5- kaAbarahu EalaY Haq~ihi He denied, or disacknowledged, to him his right, or due, and contended with him for it; expl. by jaAHadahu wagaAlabahu. (A, TA. [See 1 in art. jHd.]) ― -b6- kuwbira EalaY maAlihi He had his property taken from him by force. (A, TA.)

4 Akbrhu *
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ikobaArN; (Msb;) and Astkbrhu↓; (K;) He deemed it great [or formidable; see an ex., voce faZiEa;] it was great in his estimation; (IJ, K;) syn. A_isotaEoZamahu. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Akbrt She brought forth a great child, or young one. (IKtt.) ― -b3- A^aSogarati Aln~aAqapu waA^akobarato: see art. Sgr.

5 tkb~r *
and Astkbr↓ (S, K) and tkAbr↓ (K) He magnified himself; behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; (K;) syn. taEaZ~ama: (S:) or tkb~r signifies, as used in the Kur, vii. 143, he considered himself as of the most excellent of the creation, and as having rights which others have not: (Zj:) or this verb has two significations: one of them, he did really good and great actions, exceeding the good actions of others; and hence Almutakab~iru [applied to God] in the Kur, lix. 23: the other, he affected to do such actions, and boasted of great qualities which he did not possess; as do the generality of men; and hence, mutakab~ir in the Kur, xl. 37; and the verb itself in the Kur, vii. 143: and Astkbr↓ is nearly syn. with tkb~r, and likewise has two significations: one of them, he endeavoured, and sought, to become great; and to do so, when the manner and place and time are such as are requisite, is praiseworthy: the other, he boasted of qualities which he did possess, and feigned such qualities; and to do so is blameable; and in this sense the verb is used in the Kur, ii. 32: (El-Basáïr:) and tkAbr↓ signifies he feigned himself great in estimation or rank or dignity, or in age. (A, TA.) ― -b2- tkb~r EalaY A@ll~`hi He magnified himself against God, by refusing to accept the truth. (El-Basáïr.) ― -b3- [tkb~r Eano ka*aA He was disdainful of such a thing; he disdained it; turned from it with disdain; he held himself above it; like taEaZ~ama and taEaAZama and tajaAl~a and taraf~aEa.]

6 takaAobara
see 5, in two places.

10 A_isotakobara
see 4: ＝ -A2- see also 5, in two places.

kuborN *
: see kiborN, in two senses: ＝ -A2- and see kiborapN in three places.

kiborN *
Greatness [in corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity]. (IKoot, Msb.) ― -b2- Nobility; eminence; highness; (K, * TA;) as also kuborN↓: (K:) eminence, or highness, in, or with respect to, nobility; (K;) as also kuburN↓, with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b3- I. q. EaZamapN [which, as an attribute of God, signifies greatness, or majesty, or the like: (see munakab~irN:) and as an attribute of a man, pride]: (S, Msb, K:) a subst. from Alt~akab~uru: (Msb:) as also kiboriyaA='u↓; (S, Msb, K;) a word, says Kr, of which there is not the like [in measure], except siymiyaA='u and jirobiyaA='u; for, he adds, as to kiymiyaA='u, I think it a foreign word: (TA:) the latter [kiboriyaA'u↓] occurs as an attribute of God, in the sense of EaZamapN, (A, Mgh, Jel,) in the Kur, xlv. 36: (Jel:) and as an attribute of men, in the Kur, x. 79, where it is said to signify proud behaviour towards others, (Bd,) or dominion: (IAmb, Bd, Jel:) and both signify pride, haughtiness, or insolence: (K:) or the former, self-admiration, or self-conceit; and the holding one's self greater than others: and the ↓latter, disdain of submission; an attribute to which none but God has a right. (El-Basáïr.) ― -b4- Unbelief: the association of any other being with God. So in a trad., in which it is said, that he who has in his heart the weight of a grain of mustard-seed of kibor shall not enter paradise. (TA.) ― -b5- See also kabiyrapN. ＝ -A2- The main, or greater, or greatest, part of a thing; (Fr. ISk, Az, S, Mgh, K;) as also kuborN↓, (Fr, Mgh, Sgh, K,) like EuZomN; (Fr;) thought by Ibn-ElYezeedee to be a dial. form; but Az says, that the Arabs used the other form [kiborN]. (TA.) So in the Kur, xxiv. 11, waA@l~a*iY tawal~aY kiborahu (Fr, S) And he who took upon himself, or undertook, the main part thereof; namely, of the very wicked lie against 'Áïsheh: (Jel:) thus accord. to the “ Seven Readers ”: and kuborahu↓, which is an extr. reading, (Msb,) the reading of Homeyd Ibn-El-Aaraj, (Fr, Sgh,) and of Yaakoob. (Sgh, Bd.) kuboru siyaAsapi Aln~aAsi fiY AlmaAli, [app. signifies The main part of men's management is with respect to property, or camels, &c.]. (S.)

kabarN *
[The caper, or capparis of Linnæus;] a certain plant having thorns; (TA;) an arabicized word, from the Persian [kabaro]; (S;) called in Arabic laSafN, (Mgh,) or A^aSafN: (S, K:) the vulgar say kub~aArN↓. (K.) A beverage is described as made of kabar and barley: kvr is a mistranscription. (Mgh.)

kuburN *
: see kiborN.

kibarN *
inf. n. of 1: ― -b2- see also kaborapN.

kubur~N *
: see kiborapN.

kaborapN *
, a subst. from kabira, (S,) Oldness; age; old age; (S, Msb, K; *) as also kaburapN↓ and makobarapN↓ and makburapN↓ (K) and makobirN↓ (S, K) and kibarN↓. (TA.) The last two, the latter of which is the most common of all, are inf. ns. of kabira.] You say Ealatohu kaburapN, (S, Msb, K,) and kaburapN, and mukobarapN, and makoburapN, (K,) and EalaAhu Almakobiru, (S,) or makobirN, (K,) and kibarN, (TA,) [Age overcame him;] he became old, or advanced in age. (Msb.) Ealatohu kaborapN is also said, tropically, of a sword, and of the iron head or blade of a weapon, when it has become old: (TA:) or of an old iron head or blade of a weapon when spoilt by rust. (M, TA.) And kaborapN is used by AHn with respect to dates and the like. (L.) [See also an ex. voce HaloqapN.]

kiborapN *
: see kabiyrapN. ＝ -A2- huwa kiboratuhumo, (K,) and kubur~atuhumo↓, (Az, K,) so in the handwriting of AHeyth., (TA,) and A_ikobir~atuhumo↓, and A^akobir~atuhumo↓, and kuboruhumo↓, and kubur~uhumo↓, (K,) He is the greatest of them (K, TA) in age, or in headship: (TA:) or he is the nearest of them in kin to his chief, or oldest, ancestor; (K, TA;) his intermediate ancestors being fewer in number: (TA:) but some of these epithets are differently explained, as follows:] h`*aA kiborapu A^abiyhi this is the greatest, or oldest, (A^akobaru,) of the children of his father; contr. of Sigorapu A^abiyhi: (A:) and huwa kiborapu waladi A^abawayohi he is the greatest, or oldest, (Akbr,) of the children of his parents: (Ks, Az:) or he is the last of the children of his parents; (Sh, S;) and the like is said of a female, (Sh, ISk, S,) and of a pl. number: (ISk, S:) it is like Eijozapu waladi A^abawayohi: (Sh, A'Obeyd, S:) or, accord. to Ks and Az, this last phrase has this meaning; but Az says, that kiborap means otherwise, namely, A^akobaru: (TA:) and fulaAnN A_ikobir~apu qawomihi such a one is the greatest, or oldest, (A^akobaru,) of his people; and the like is said of a female, and of a pl. number: (S:) and qawomihi huwa kuboru↓, (S,) or qawomihi A^akobaru↓, and qawomihi A^ukobur~u↓, of the measure of A^ufoEul~, and applied to a woman as to a man, (TA,) he is the nearest of his people in kin to his chief, or oldest, ancestor; (S, TA;) in which sense, qawomihi kaAna kubora↓ is said of El-'Abbás, in a trad., because there remained not, in his lifetime, any one of the descendants of Háshim more nearly related to him than he: (L:) and in another trad. it is said, AlawlA='u llkubori (S, Mgh, Msb) the right to the inheritance of the property left by an emancipated slave belongs to the nearest in kin [to the emancipater] (Mgh, Msb) of the sons of the emancipater; (Mgh;) i. e., when a man [who has emancipated a slave] dies, leaving a son and a grandson, the right to the inheritance of the property left by the emancipated slave belongs to the son, not the grandson. (S.)

kaburapN *
: see kaborapN.

kubur~apN *
: see kiborapN.

kiboriyaA='u *
: see kiborN.

kiboriytN *
: see art. kbrt.

kubaArN *
: see kabiyrN.

kabiyrN *
Great [in body, or corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity; contr. of SagiyrN, but see EaZiymN]; (S, K;) as also kibiyrN, as asserted by En-Nawawee and others, (TA,) and kubaArN↓ (S, K) [in an intensive sense, like EuTaAmN,] and kaAbirN↓ and kub~aArN↓: (K:) or the last signifies excessively great: (S, TA:) and kaAbirN is an epithat applied to a man, and signifying great in dignity and nobility; (S, TA;) or great and noble; (Msb;) or one overcoming in greatness; (A;) or a lord, or chief; and the greatest, or oldest, ancestor: (AA:) the fem. [of kabiyrN] is with p: (K:) and the pl. is kibaArN (S, K) and kubaraA='u, applied to men, (TA,) and makobuwraA='u, (S, * K,) [or rather the last is a quasi-pl. n.,] like ma$oyuwxaA='u; [see $ayoxN;] (TA;) and [of kub~aArN] kub~aAruwna. (K.) [See also A^akobaru, and mutakab~irN.] You say tawaAravuwA A@lomajoda kaAbirFA Eano kaAbirK↓ They inherited by degrees dignity, or nobility, one great in dignity and nobility from another great in dignity and nobility: (S:) or one great and noble from another great and noble: (Msb:) or Eano is here used in the sense of baEoda [after]: (TA voce TabaqN:) or one overcoming in greatness from another overcoming in greatness. (A.) [In the A and Msb, instead of twArvwA, I find warivuwA.] ― -b2- Great, or advanced, in age; old: (A, Msb, TA:) and also big; meaning full-grown; and adolescent: (see kabira:) occurring in apposition to baAligN in art. brk in the S; and often, like baAligN, when applied to a human being, signifying one who has attained to puberty; opposed to SagiyrN:] fem. with p: and pl. kibaArN. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A teacher, and master: so in the Kur, xx. 74, and xxvi. 48: (Ks:) and the most knowing, or learned, of a people: so in the Kur, xii. 80. (Mujáhid.) ― -b4- Difficult, severe, grievous, distressing, afflictive, troublesome, or burdensome: (TA:) fem. with p; occurring in this sense in the Kur, ii. 42. (Bd, TA.) [The fem. is often used in the present day as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, meaning, An affair, or a matter, that is difficult, severe, grievous, &c.] ― -b5- Alkabiyru as an epithet applied to God is syn. with AlEaZiymu [signifying The Incomparably-great]. (TA in art. EZm.)

kabiyrap *
A foul, or an abominable, sin, or crime, or offence, forbidden by the law, of great magnitude; such as murder and adultery or forni-
cation, and fleeing from an army proceeding against an enemy [of the Muslims], &c.; [contr. of SagiyrapN;] an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (TA:) and kiborN↓ and kiborapN↓ [in like manner] signify a great sin, or crime, or offence, for which one deserves punishment: (M, K:) the p is to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) or kiborN↓ signifies [simply] a sin, a crime, or an offence, for which one deserves punishment, [as kabiyrapN is said, not well, to signify, in the Msb,] and is from kabiyrapN, like xiTo from xaTiyoy^apN: (TA:) pl. of the first, kabaAy^iru, (Msb, TA,) and kabiyraAtN also occurs. (Msb.) ― -b2- And see kabiyrN.

kub~aArN *
: see kabiyrN: ＝ -A2- and see kabarN.

kib~aArN *
: see 2.

kaAbirN *
: see kabiyrN.

A^akobaru *
[Greater, and greatest, in body, or corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity: and] more, or most, advanced in age; older, and oldest: (Msb:) fem. kuboraY: (S, Msb:) pl. masc. A^akaAbiru (S, Msb) and A^akobaruwna; but not kuborN, because this is of a form specially appropriated to an epithet such as A^asowadu and A^aHomaru, and you do not use Akbr in the manner of such an epithet, for you do not say h`*aA rajulN A^akobaru, unless you conjoin it with a following word by mino, or prefix to it the article Al: (S:) [but see the phrase daEaA bikuborihi, below:] the pl. fem. is kubarN (S, Msb, K) and kuborayaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- A^akobaru is also used in the sense of kabiyrN: (Msb:) accord. to some, Aall~`hu A^akobar means God is great; (Az, Mgh, Msb;) like as huwa A^ahowanu Ealayohi [in the Kur, xxx. 26,] means huwa hay~inN Ealayohi; (Az, TA;) but this explanation is of weak authority: (Mgh:) accord. to others, the phrase is elliptical, and means God is the greatest great [being]: (Az, TA:) or God is greater than every [other] great [being]: (Msb:) or greater than every [other] thing: (Mgh, TA:) or greater than such as that one knows the measure of His majesty: (TA:) [or it may be rendered God is most great, meaning, greater than any other being:] it is considered as elliptical because it is necessary that Akbr should have the article Al, or be followed by a noun in the gen. case [or by the prep. mino]. (TA.) In the phrase Aall~`hu A^akobaru kabiyrAF, the word kbyrA is put in the accus. case [as a corroborative] in the place of the inf. n. takobiyrAF, as though one said A^ukab~iru takobiyrFA [I magnify Him greatly, after saying All~`h Akbr]. (TA.) ― -b3- yawomu AlHaj~i AlA^akobari [The day of the greater pilgrimage,] means the day of the sacrifice: or, as some say, the day of 'Arafeh: and others say otherwise. (TA.) ― -b4- In the following words, in a trad. of Mázin, buEiva nabiY~N mino muDara bidiyni A@ll~`hi Alkubari, there is an ellipsis, and the meaning is, bi$aray^iEi diyni A@ll~`hi Alkubari [A prophet of Mudar hath been sent with the greatest, or greater, or great, ordinances of God]. (TA.) ― -b5- In a trad. respecting burial, wayujoEalu A@loA^akobaru mim~aA yaliY A@loqibolapa means, And the most excellent shall be placed towards the Kibleh: or, if they be equal [in dignity], the oldest. (TA.) [Agreeably with the former rendering,] A^akobaru, in the Kur, xxix. 44, is explained as signifying Better. (TA, art. *kr.) [And agreeably with the second rendering of the above trad.,] you say h`*aA A^akobaru mino zayodK, meaning, This is older than Zeyd. (Msb.) ― -b6- In a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, the phrase daEaA bikuborihi means He summoned his sheykhs, and elders, or great men: kubor being here [notwithstanding what has been said above,] pl. of A^akobaru, like as HumorN is pl. of A^aHomaru. (TA.) ― -b7- h`*ihi AljaAriyapu mino kuboraY banaAti fulaAnK means, [This girl is of those advanced in age of the daughters of such a one,] mino kibaAri banaAtihi. (Ibn-Buzurj.) ― -b8- huwa A^akobaru qawomihi: see kiborapN.

A^ukobur~N *
: see kiborapN.

A_ikobir~apN *
and A^akobir~apN: see kiborapN; the former, in two places.

makobirN *
: see kaborapN.

makobarapN *
and makoburapN: see kabobarpN.

huwa mukaAbarN Ealayohi *
He has had it (his property) taken from him by force. (A, TA.)

Almutakab~iru *
, as an epithet applied to God, signifies The Great in majesty: (A:) or the Most Excellent of beings, who has rights which no other has; the Possessor of power and excellence the like of which no other possesses: (TA:) or He whose acts are really good, exceeding the good acts of any other: (El-Basáïr:) or, as also Alkabiyru↓, the Majestic: or He who disdains having the attributes of created beings: or He who magnifies Himself against the proud and exorbitant among his creatures: the t in the former word is to denote individuation, not endeavour. (TA.)

Q. 1 kaborata baEiyrahu *
He smeared his camel over with kiboriyt [or sulphur], (K,) mixed with grease, and with xaDaxaAD, which is a kind of nifoT [or naphtha], black, and of a thin consistence; not qaTiraAn; for this is the black, thick, expressed juice of a certain tree. (TS.) This is done to cure the scab, for the removal of which it is very efficacious. (TA.)

kiboriytN *
[Brimstone, or sulphur;] a thing well known; (S, art. kbr;) one of the kinds of stone with which fire is kindled, or it (red kbryt TA) is a mineral whereof the mine is beyond EtTubbat, [or the country of Et-Tibbet, in Tartary,] in the Valley of the Ants, (K,) by which Solomon passed, (TA,) [as related in the Kur, xxvii. 18]: or [the product of] a spring, or source, whereof the water, when it congeals, becomes white, and yellow, and dusky-coloured, kbryt: (Lth, in the T:) MF says, I have seen it in several places; among these, in one which is near El-Maláleeh, between Fás and Miknáseh; by swimming in which, persons are cured of the venereal disease, and other disorders: also in Africa Proper, in the midst of Barkah, in a place called Albrj; and in other places: (TA:) Aristotle says, that, among the different kinds of kbryt are the red, of an excellent colour; and the white, which resembles dust; and the yellow: the source of the red is in the West: it does not appear in its place: the yellow is found near the ocean, a league (or leagues, as in the TA,) from it: it is useful in cases of epilepsy, and apoplexy, and megrim, and palpitation: and it enters into the preparations of gold: the white blackens white substances; and it is sometimes mixed and concealed in the sources of running water, which sources have a fetid odour: the person who plunges into these waters in times when the air is temperate is cured by them of wounds, and swellings, and scab, and wind in the womb, and [the leprosy called] salaE, that arises from black bile: Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna] also says, that kbryt, untouched by fire, is one of the remedies for the leprosy (baraS): that, mixed with the gum of the turpentine-tree, it removes marks on the nails: that, mixed with vinegar, it removes the [leprous-like discolouration of the skin called] bahaq, and the ringworm, or tetter, (quwabaA',) especially with the gum of the turpentine-tree: that, with natron and water, it is an embrocation for the baraS [or, as in the TA, for the niqoris, or gout): and that fumigation therewith stops a rheum: and others say, that, if yellow kbryt be powdered, and sprinkled upon a place affected with slEp, it has a good effect: that fumigation therewith whitens the hair: that serpents and fleas flee from the scent of it, especially if [mixed] with an unguent, or with the hoof of an ass; and that the fumigation therewith beneath a citrontree of the kind called A^utoruj~ causes all the fruits of it to fall. (El-Kazweenee.) Several authors say, that the t in kbryt is an augmentative letter, and that the proper place of the word is in art. kbr. IDrd thinks it to be not genuine Arabic. (TA.) [Golius thinks it to be from the Persian kuwkurodo (or kuwkurodo): or rather, he adds, from the Hebrew נּפְּרִיח Gen. xix. 24.] ― -b2-
A^aEaz~umina Alkiboriyti AlA^aHomari [More rare than red brimstone, or sulphur]. A proverb. Some say, that kbryt AHmr [meaning as above] is a thing that does not exist: others, that by it is meant gold. (Meyd.) This phrase is similar to A^aEaz~u mino bayoDi AlA^anuwqi. (S, art. kbr.) ― -b3- kiboriytN also signifies gold: (K:) [see above:] or red gold: or red [as an epithet applied to gold]: (TA:) or pure, as an epithet applied to gold. (S, art. kbr.) Ru-beh says,
halo yanofaEan~iY ka*ibN sixotiytu
A^awo fiD~apN A^awo *ahabN kiboriytu
[Will vehement lying profit me, or silver, or pure gold?] (S, art. kbr.) IAar says, Ru-beh imagined that kbryt meant gold: upon which MF observes, that the ancient Arabs erred with respect to meanings, though not with respect to words. The latter author, however, supposes kbryt to be fig. used as signifying gold; for they use the expression Alkbryt AlAHmr [as applied to gold] because gold is [said to be] prepared therefrom, and it is used in alchymical processes. (TA.) ― -b4- kiboriytN also signifies The red jacinth, or ruby; syn. yaAquwtN A^aHomaru. (K.)

1 kabasa *
, (S, A, K,) aor.
kabisa
, (K,) inf. n. kabosN, (S,) He filled up with earth a well, (S, A, K,) and a river, (A, Mgh, K,) and a hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He covered over, or spread, with earth, and made even, a piece of ground: and in like manner, the roof of a house, before plastering it with mud or clay. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [And He spread earth upon a roof &c. (See dak~a.)] ＝ -A2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He pressed, or squeezed, [or kneaded,] a limb with the hand: (TA, art. gmz:) and kb~s↓, inf. n. takobiysN, [signifies the same, accord. to present usage: and] (tropical:) he suppled the body [by kneading, or pressing, or squeezing it, as is done in the bath,] with the hands. (TA, in the present art.) ― -b2- And, aor. as above, (tropical:) Inivit unâ vice feminam. (K.) ＝ -A3- kabasuwA daAra fulaAnK (tropical:) They made a sudden attack upon the house of such a one, (S, IKtt, * K,) and surrounded it. (K.) And kabasuwA Ealayohimo, and kb~swA↓, (tropical:) They threw themselves upon them suddenly and without consideration. (A.) And in like manner, EalaY Al$~aYo'i kb~swA↓, and tk~bswA↓ Ealayohi, (tropical:) They threw themselves upon the thing suddenly and without consideration. (TA.) ＝ -A4- kabasa raA^osahu, [aor. as above,] He put his head within his garments: (S:) and kabasa raA^osahu fiY vawobihi he hid his head in his garment, and put it within it: (K:) or he put it on in the manner of a qinaAE, (taqan~aEa,) and then covered himself with part of it. (TA.) You say also, kabasa raA^osahu fiY jayobi qamiySihi, (A,) or biraA^osihi, (TA,) He put his head within the opening at the neck and bosom of his shirt; (A;) and so tkb~s↓ alone. (TA.) And yakobisu Alr~ajulu vawobahu fiY raA^osihi [app. meaning, The man puts his garment as a covering over his head.] (Sh, TA.)

2 kab~asa
see 1, in three places.

3 kaAobasa
[kAbshu, inf. n. mukaAbasapN, app. syn. with maArasahu, or daAfaEahu: see taAyasa.]

5 tkb~s *
[quasi-pass. of 2, It was, or became, pressed, or squeezed]. ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

7 Ankbs *
It (a river, [and a well,] and any hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground,) became filled up with earth. (Mgh.)

kibosN *
Earth with which a well, (S, K,) or river, (K,) or any hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground, (TA,) is filled up: (S, K, TA:) earth that occupies the place of air. (TA.)

kabiysN *
A kind of dates, (S, Msb, K,) said to be of the best kind; (Msb;) thus called when dry; but when fresh, called A^um~u jiro*aAnK, which is also the name of the tree that bears them. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A kind of women's ornament, made hollow, (A, L, K,) and coated with perfume, (A,) or stuffed with perfume, (L, K,) and then worn; (L;) a necklace being made of ornaments of this kind. (A.) ＝ -A3- Als~anapu Alkabiysapu, (S, K,) and EaAmu Alkabiysi, (L, Az, in TA, voce subaATN, q. v.,) [The intercalary year; or leap-year; both in the Syrian, or Julian, reckoning, and in the Coptic;] the year from which, (minohaA,) accord. to the S and K, but properly, for which, (lahaA,) as in the work entitled Alqawolu AlmaA^onuwsu, a day is stolen (yusotaraqu) [and intercalated]; which is [once] in every four years; as in the S and K; for the said day is an addition thereto; (MF, TA;) the year in which the Syrians following the Greeks, add a day to the month subaAT, [which corresponds to February, O. S.,] making it twentynine days instead of twenty-eight, which they do once in four years; (L;) [and that in which the Copts intercalate, at the end, six epagomenæ instead of five, which, in like manner, they do once in every four years.]

kibaAsapN *
A raceme, (S, A, Msb, K,) or large raceme, (TA,) of a palm-tree, (A, * Msb, K, *) or of dates, like the Eunoquwd of grapes, (S,) complete, with its $amaAriyx, [or fruit-stalks, pl. of $imoraAxN,] (A, TA,) and its dates: (TA:) pl. kabaAy^isu. (A, Msb.) [A kbAsp of moderate size has about one hundred $mAryx; the longest $mrAx having about fifty dates, and being about two feet and a half in length; and the shortest having about thirty dates, and being about one foot in length.] ― -b2- Also applied by AHn, to (tropical:) A raceme of [the fruit called] fuwfal. (TA.)

kaAbisN *
Charging, attacking, or assaulting. (K, * TA.) You say, jaA='a kaAbisFA He came charging, attacking, or assaulting: (K, * TA:) as also mukab~isFA↓, and mukaAbisFA↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Throwing himself suddenly and without consideration [upon a person or thing]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A man putting himself within his garment, covering his body with it. (TA.)

kaAbuwsN *
[Incubus, or nightmare;] what comes upon a man (or rather upon a sleeper, TA,) in the night, (S, K,) preventing his moving while it lasts; (K;) accord. to some, (S,) the forerunner of epilepsy. (S, K.) Some think that this is not Arabic, and that the proper word is nayodulaAnN, and baAruwkN, and jaAvuwmN. (TA.) Hence, app., (TA.) (tropical:) Modus certus coëundi: (K:) or rather, (tropical:) coïtus itself. (TA.)

mukab~asu Alr~aA^osi *
Compact in the head. (AHeyth, T in art. Zrb.)

mukab~isN *
Hanging down his head in his garment: (K, * TA:) or one who throws himself suddenly and without consideration upon others, and assaults them. (K.) See also kaAbisN.

mukaAbisN *
: see kaAbisN.

1 kaba$ahu *
, [aor.
kabi$a
, accord. to present usage,] inf. n. kabo$N, He took it with his hand having the fingers contracted; (TA;) [he took by the handful, so used in the present day.]

kabo$N *
A ram, or male sheep, whatever be his age: (M, TA:) or a male sheep [that has entered his third year,] when he has cast his central incisors: or when his tooth that is next to the central pair of incisors has come forth: (Lth, K:) [also applied in the present day to the wild sheep of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; ovis tragelaphus:] pl. [of pauc.] A^akobu$N and A^akobaA$N (K) and [of mult.] kibaA$N (S, A, K) [and app. kubuw$N] and kubuw$apN, like SuquwrapN from SaqorN. (TA.) The female is not called kabo$apN, but naEojapN. (IJ. [See raAjilapN.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) The chief, or lord, of a people, or company of men; (S, K;) their leader: (K:) or their strenuous defender, or protector, and the one of them to whom others look. (TA.) You say, huwa kabo$u Alkatiybapi (A, TA) (tropical:) He is the leader of the army, or troop: (TA:) and humo kibaA$u AlkataAy^ibi (tropical:) [They are the leaders of the armies, or troops]. (A, TA.) And kibaA$N also signifies
(tropical:) Heroes, or brave men. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Aged and learned persons. (TA in art. xrf.) ― -b3- [Hence also, (tropical:) A buttress: and a corbel which juts out from a wall to support a superstructure: so in the present day: pl. kubuw$N.] You say, banawoA suwrFA HaSiynFA wawav~aquwhu biAlkubuw$i (tropical:) [They built a strong town-wall, and made it firm with the buttresses]. (A, TA.) [See also another ex. voce faSiylN.]

kabo$apN *
[A handful: a heap: so applied in the the present day. ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) A gang, or crew: thus, also, applied in the present day. Whence the sayings,] banuw fulaAnK kabo$apu ru*alaA='a (assumed tropical:) [The sons of such a one are a gang of vile persons]: and kabo$apu dunasaA='a (assumed tropical:) [a gang of dirty, or filthy, persons]: thus they use this word to intimate dispraise: but [SM adds,] I know not how this is. (TA.) [Perhaps SM means that he doubts whether the word thus used be classical or not: for as to its signification, it is well known.]

kab~aA$N *
An owner, [or a tender] of kibaA$ [or rams]. (TA.)
See Supplement

kabaEovaApN *
The [thing termed] EafalN of a woman: (K:) a dial. form of qabaEovaApN. (TA.)

div1.superEntry: kbkb See art. kb. [kbl kbn kbw See Supplement

superEntry.entry:
1 kat~ati Alqidoru *
, (S, K,) aor.
kati3a
, (TA,) inf. n. katiytN, (K,) The cooking-pot boiled: (S, K:) or, made a sound in boiling: (K:) or, made a sound in boiling when the water in it was little; a lower sound than it makes when there is much water boiling in it; as though it said kato kato. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, kat~ati Aljar~apu Aljadiydu, (S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, The new jar made a sound (like kato kato, TA) when water was poured into it. (S.) ― -b3- kat~a, aor.
kati3a
, inf. n. kat~N (TA) and katiytN, (K,) It (nabiy*, K, or another thing, TA,) made a sound in boiling: (K:) or began to boil, before it boiled vehemently. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kat~a, aor.
kati3a
, (S,) inf. n. katiytN, (S, K,) He (a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a cry, or a kind of braying, louder than that which is termed ka$iy$N: (S:) or began to utter the kind of braying termed hadiyrN: (K:) As says, that when a male camel has attained the age when he makes the braying cry termed hdyr, his first kind of braying is termed k$y$; and when it is a little louder, it is termed ktyt: Lth says, that he first makes the kind of braying termed ktyt; then, that termed k$y$; and then, that termed hadiyrN: but Az observes, that the correct saying is that of As. (TA.) ― -b2- kat~, aor.
kati3a
, (inf. n. katiytN, S,) He (a camel, S, K, or, as in the L, a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a gentle cry, (S, L, K,) between that termed k$y$ and that termed hdyr. (TA.) ― -b3- He (a calf) lowed. (Nh.) ― -b4- kat~a, aor.
kati3a
, (inf. n. katiytN, K,) [He (a man) made a sound like the gentle braying of a camel,] by reason of rage, or wrath: (S:) or he (a man) made a a sound in his chest like that made by a bakor, or young camel, by reason of vehement rage, or wrath. (K, TA.) ― -b5- kat~a AlkalaAma fiY A^u*unihi, aor.
katu3a
; and A^akat~ahu↓, and A_ikotat~ahu↓; He whispered the words in his ear. (K.) ― -b6- kut~aniY AlHadiyva, and A^akit~aniyhi↓, Tell me the story as thou heardest it. (TA.) ＝ -A3- kat~a, [aor.
kati3a
,] inf. n. katiytN, (tropical:) He walked gently; at a gentle pace: or he walked with short steps, but quickly; as also katokata↓, inf. n. katokatapN; and takatokata↓. (K.) ＝ -A4- kat~ahu, [aor.
katu3a
,] He angered him; provoked him to anger; syn. A^arogamahu. (TS, K.) ― -b2- kat~ahu, [aor.
katu3a
,] He displeased him; grieved him; did to him what he disliked, or hated; did evil to him. (TS, K.) ― -b3- faEala bihi maA kat~ahu He did to him what displeased him, or grieved him. (TA.) ＝ -A5- kat~a, aor.
katu3a
, inf. n. kat~N, He numbered, counted, or computed, a people. Mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say A^ataAnaA bijayo$K maA yukat~u He came to us with an army not to be numbered, or counted, (IAar, S,) or computed, or of which the number could not be conjectured, and of which the end could not be reached. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- laA takut~uhu A^awo takut~a Aln~ujuwma, [in the CK, erroneously, laA takut~uhu A^awo laA takut~u Aln~ujuwma,] Thou canst not number it, [unless thou canst number the stars]. A proverb. (K.)

4 A^akota3a
see 1.

6 tkAt~w Ealayohi *
They pressed together, or crowded together, upon it, with crying, or noise: from Alkatiytu. Occurring in a trad., as related and explained by Z; but the word commonly known is tkAb~wA, with b. (TA.)

8 Aktt~ *
, inf. n. A_ikotitaAtN, He listened; syn. A_isotamaEa. (K.) ― -b2- Aktt~ AlHadiyva min~iY He heard the story from me like as I heard it. (TA.) See 1.

R. Q. 1 katokata *
, inf. n. katokatapN, (in the K, katokatN, which is a mistake, TA,) It (a HubaAraY, or bustard,) uttered its cry. (L, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- katokata, inf. n. katokatapN, (S, &c.,) He laughed gently, or lowly: (K:) ktktp, in laughing, is less than qahoqahapN: (S:) or like what is termed HaniynN. (Th, El-Ahmar.) ― -b2- katokata fiY DaHikihi He laughed vehemently, immoderately, or excessively; i. q. A^agoraba, q. v. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also 1.

R. Q. 2 takatokata *
: see 1.

kat~N *
A man or woman having little flesh: you say rajulN kat~N and A_imoraA^apN kat~N. (TA.)

kat~apN *
Green produce of land. (TS, K.)

kut~apN *
The worst, or vilest, of camels, or similar property; syn. ru*aAlu AlmaAli. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- kat~apF a [gen?] proper name of A bad she-goat. (Fr, K.)

katiytN *
: see 1. ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A niggardly, stingy, man: (K:) as also katiytu Alyadayoni: (TA:) from katiytu Alqidori: [see 1:] (IJ:) or a niggardly, stingy, man, of bad disposition, and rageful, or wrathful. (T.)

katiytapN *
i. q. EaSiydapN [q. v.] (TS, K.)

kutokutu *
and kutokutaY, both imperfectly declinable, A certain game. (TS, K.)

katokaAtN *
(tropical:) One who walks gently; at a gentle pace: or who walks with short steps, but quickly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A man who talks much (K) and quickly. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 kanotaA^ati All~iHoyapu *
: see kavaA^at.

katoA^apN *
A plant resembling the jirojiyrN, [or rocket], (K,) which is cooked and eaten. (TA.) But AM says it is kavoA^apN, with v; and it is also called nahoqN, accord. to Aboo-Málik and others. (TA.)

kinotaA^owu *
(but accord. to some, this is from knt) A strong rope. (K.) [But see art. kdA^.] ― -b2- Also, A man having a large and thick, or a handsome, beard. (K.) Said to be a dial. form of kinovaA^owN. (TA.)

1 katabahu *
, aor.
katuba
, inf. n. katobN and kitaAbN and kitaAbapN (S, K) and kitobapN; (Msb;) the first of these inf. ns. agreeable with analogy; the second, anomalous; (TA;) or the latter of these two is a subst., like libaAsN; (Lh;) or originally an inf. n., and afterwards used in the senses given
below; (MF;) as also kitaAbapN, and kitobapN: (TA:) and kt~bhu↓ (K) and Akttbhu↓; (S, K;) He wrote it: (S, K:) or katabahu has this signification; and Akttbhu↓, as also Astktbhu↓, signifies he asked [one] to dictate it (A_isotamolaAhu): (K:) A_ikotatabahaA↓ in the Kur, xxv. 6, signifies he hath written them (S) for himself: (Bd:) or he hath asked [one] to write them for him, or to dictate them to him. (TA, Bd.) ― -b2- kataba Eanohu [He wrote what he had heard, or learned from him.] A phrase of common occurrence in biographies. ― -b3- kataba [He was a writer, or scribe, and a learned man. (Implied in the S, where we are referred to the Kur, lii. 41, and lxviii., 47, in illustration of kaAtibN as signifying “ a learned man. ”)] ＝ -A2- kataba, aor.
katuba
, inf. n. kitaAbN, q. v., (assumed tropical:) He (God) prescribed, appointed, or ordained, (TA,) and made obligatory. (Msb.) kutiba Ealayokumu AlqiSaASu The law of retaliation is prescribed, appointed, or ordained, as a law of which the observance is incumbent on you. (Kur, ii. 173.] kutiba Ealayokumu AlS~iyaAmu Fasting is prescribed as incumbent on you. [Kur. ii. 179.] (TA.) ― -b2- kataba Ealayohi ka*aA (tropical:) He judged, passed sentence, or decreed, against him that he should do such a thing. (A.) ktb AlqaADiY biAln~afaqapi The judge gave sentence that the expenses should be paid. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- kataba, aor.
katuba
, inf. n. katobN, He drew together; brought together; conjoined. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, kataba Albagolapa, aor.
katuba
and
katiba
, inf. n. katobN, He conjoined the oræ of the mule's vulva by means of a ring or a thong; (S;) as also kataba EalayohaA. (A.) kataba, aor.
katuba
and
katiba
, (K,) inf. n. katobN; and kataba EalayohaA; (TA;) He closed the camel's vulva, (K,) and put a ring upon it: (TA:) or he put a ring of iron or the like upon it, (K,) conjoining the oræ, in order that she might not be covered. (TA.) ― -b3- kataba, aor.
katuba
, inf. n. katobN; (S;) and Akttb↓; (K;) He sewed a qirobap, (S,) or a siqaA=', (K,) or a mazaAdap, (TA,) with two thongs: (K:) or, accord. to some, he closed it at the mouth, by binding it round with a wikaA', so that nothing [of its contents] should drop from it; (TA;) [as also Aktb↓:] or ktb signifies he sewed a qrbp; and Aktb↓, he bound it with a wkA=', i. e. bound it round the upper part. (Lh.) ― -b4- kataba, aor.
katuba
, inf. n. katobN; (S;) and Aktb↓ (S, K) and Akttb↓ (TA) (tropical:) He bound a qirobap with a wikaA'; (S;) he bound it round the head, or upper part: (K:) or the first of these verbs signifies he sewed a qrbp. (Lh.) See above. IAar says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, A^akotabotu fama Als~iqaA' falamo yasotakotibo↓ I bound the mouth of the sqA', but it did not become fast bound, or closed, because of its hardness and thickness. (TA.) ＝ -A4- kataba Aln~aAqapa He used art to make the she-camel take a liking to that which was not her own young one, and put something as a ring through her nostrils, lest she should smell the baw~, (in some copies of the K, bawol; but this is a mistake; TA,) and not have a fondness for it. (TA.) ＝ -A5- kataba (tropical:) He collected a katiybap. (TA.) See also 2.

2 kat~aba
See 1 and 4 ＝ -A2- kt~b Aln~aAqapa, inf. n. takotiybN, He tied the udder of the camel. (AZ, S.) ＝ -A3- kt~b AlkataAy^iba, inf. n. takotiybN; (S, K;) and katabahaA↓; (TA;) (tropical:) He prepared the troops; (K;) he disposed the troops in order, troop by troop. (S.)

3 mukaAtabapN *
and takaAtubN↓ are syn.: (S, K:) you say, kAtb Sadiyqahu He wrote to his friend: and tkAtbA↓ They wrote, one to the other. (TA.) ― -b2- kAtbhu, inf. n. mukaAtabapN (Az, K, Msb) and kitaAbN, (Az, Msb,) (tropical:) He (a slave) made a written [or other] contract with him (his master), that he (the former) should pay a certain sum as the price of himself, and on the payment thereof be free: (K, &c.:) also he (a master) made such a contract with him (his slave): (Az, Msb, &c.:) and tkAtbA↓ They two made such a contract, one with the other. (Msb.) The slave in this case is called mukaAtabN (S, Msb) and also mukaAtibN; and so is the master; the act being mutual. (Msb.) [But the lawyers in the present day call the slave mukaAtabN only; and the master, mukaAtibN.] AlkitaAbapu, signifying “ what is written, ” is tropically used by the professors of practical law as syn. with AlmukaAtabapu, because the contract above mentioned was generally written; and is so used by them when nothing is written. It was thus called in the age of el-Islám, accord. to Az. These two words are said by Z to be syn.; but it is thought that he may have written the former by mistake for AlkitaAbu, adding the p by a slip of the pen. (Msb.)

4 Aktb *
He dictated. (S, K.) Ex. A^akotiboniY h`*ihi AlqaSiydapa Dictate to me this ode. (S.) ― -b2- Aktb and kt~b↓ He taught the art of writing. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in three places.

5 tkt~b *
(tropical:) He girded himself, and drew together his garments upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tkt~b (tropical:) It (an army, S) collected itself together. (S, K.)

6 takaAotaba
see 3.

8 A_ikotataba
See 1. ― -b2- kitobapN [is a quasi-inf. n. of 8; syn. with A_ikotitaAbN; and is explained as signifying] The writing a book, transcribing it [from another book]: (A_ikotitaAbuka kitaAbFA tanosaxuhu). (K.) ― -b3- It also signifies, [as a quasi-inf. n. of 8,] The writing one's name in [the list of those who receive] stipend and maintenance (AlkttAb fY AlfrD wAlrzq [ASHAb]). (TA.) ― -b4- Akttb He registered himself in the book of the Sultán's army-list, or stipendiaries. (S, K.) A_ikotatabotu fiY gazowapi ka*aA I wrote down my name in the list of the soldiers of such an expedition. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- Akttb kitaAbFA He asked for a book (or the like) to be written for him. (TA.) See also 10. ＝ -A2- Akttb (tropical:) His urine was suppressed. (TA.) ― -b2- Akttb baTonuhu (tropical:) He was constipated, or costive; (TA;) his belly was constipated. (K.)

10 Astktbhu $ayoy^FA *
He asked him to write a thing for him. (S.) See also 1 and 8. ＝ -A2- With reference to a siqaA' (or skin), see 1.

kutobapN *
(tropical:) A thong with which one sews (K) a mazaAdap or a qirobap: pl. kutabN. (TA.) ― -b2- That with which the vulva of a camel (or of a mule, TA,) is closed in order that she may not be covered: (K:) pl. kutabN. (TA.) ― -b3- A seam or suture, (KL, PS,) in a skin or hide; (KL;) [app. made by sewing together two edges so that one laps over the other;] a xurozapN (S, Mgh, K) whereof the thong conjoins the two faces [or sides]: (K:) or a xrzp that is joined together with a thong: (Lth:) or that whereof the thong conjoins each of the two faces [or sides]: (ISd, TA:) pl. kutabN. (S, Mgh.)

kitobapN *
: see 1 and 8. ― -b2- [Also, agreeably with analogy, A mode, or manner, of writing.]

[
kutubiY~N *
, meaning A bookseller, is a vulgar term, like SuHufiY~N: by rule it should be kitaAbiY~N.]

kitaAbN *
[inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- as a subst.,] A thing in which, or on which, one writes: [a book:] a written piece of paper or [a record, or register; and a written mandate;] of skin: (K:) a writing, or writ, or thing written; as also katiybapN↓: and both are applied also to the revelation from above: and to a letter, or epistle, which a person writes and sends: sometimes made fem., as meaning SaHiyfapN: AA says, I heard an Arab of the desert, of El-Yemen, say, fulaAnN laguwbN jaA='atohu kitaAbiY faA@HotaqarahaA Such a one is stupid: my letter came to him, and he despised it: so I said, Dost thou say, jA'th ktAbY? and he replied, Is it not a SHyfp? (Msb.) Pl. kutubN and kutobN. (S.) ― -b3- A revealed scripture. (Msb.) [Whence A^aholu kitaAbK People having a revealed scripture: and A^aholu AlkitaAbi The people of the Bible. See also A^aholN.] AlktAb signifies The taworAp, or Pentateuch, or Mosaic Law: (K:) and the Gospel, or Book of the Gospels: the Scriptures of the Jews and Christians: (Expositions of the Kur, passim:) and the Kur-án. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 3. ＝ -A2- kitaAbN [inf. n., or subst.: see 1] Divine prescript, appointment, or ordinance: judgment, or sentence: fatal decree, or predestination. (S, K.) laA^aqoDiyan~a bayonakumaA bikitaAbi All~`hi I will assuredly determine, or judge, between you two according to the judgment, or sentence, of God, which hath
been revealed in his book. A trad., not relating to the Kur-án. (TA.) El-Jaadee says,
yaA A@bonapa Eam~iY kitaAbu All~`hi A^axorajaniY
Eanokumo wahalo A^amonafan~a All~`ha maA faEalaA
[O daughter of my paternal uncle! the decree of God hath expelled me from you: and could I indeed forbid God to do what He hath done?] (S.) [Hence,] AlkitaAbu AlA^aw~alu [The first writing; meaning the register of God's decrees]. (M and K voce maHobalN, q. v.) ― -b2- A receptacle for ink. (K).

qirobapN katiybN *
A skin that is sewed (S) with two thongs: (TA:) and the same, and mukotabN↓, (S,) and mukotatabN↓, (TA,) (tropical:) A skin bound with a wikaA'; (S;) closed at the mouth, by its being bound with a wikaA', so that nothing [of its contents] may drop from it. (TA.)

kitaAbapN *
subst. from 1; signifying The art of writing. (IAar, Msb.) ― -b2- See also 3.

katiybapN *
see kitaAbN. ＝ -A2- An army; a military force: (S, K:) or a collected portion thereof; (Msb;) [a body of troops; a corps:] or a troop: or a troop of horse making a hostile attack or incursion, in number from a hundred to a thousand: (K:) pl. kataAy^ibu. (S.)

kut~aAbN *
, see makotabN ＝ -A2- The same, (S, K,) as also kuv~aAbN, q. v., but the former is the more approved: (S: the reverse, however, is said in the TA; and MF says that some authors altogether reject kt~Ab, with t, in the sense here following:) A kind of small, round-headed, arrow, with which boys learn to shoot. (S, K.)

kaAtibN *
[A writer; a scribe; a secretary]: pl. kaAtibuwna and kut~aAbN and katabapN. (S, K.) ― -b2- A learned man (S, K) was so called by the Arabs, (IAar,) because, in general, he who knew the art of writing was possessed of science and knowledge; and writers among them were few. (TA.)

makotabN *
(S, K) and kut~aAbN↓ (Lth, S, &c.) A school; a place where the art of writing is taught: (S, K, &c.:) accord. to Mbr and F, the assigning this signification to the latter word is an error; it being a pl. of kaAtibN, and signifying, accord. to Mbr, the boys of a school: in the A it is said, this word is said to signify the boys; not the place: but Esh-Shiháb says, in the Sharh esh-Shifa, that it occurs in this sense in the classical language, and is not to be regarded as a postclassical word: it is said to be originally a pl. of kaAtibN, and to be fig. employed to signify a school. (TA.) Pl. of the former makaAtibu; (TA;) and of the latter kataAtiybu. (S.)

mukotabN *
: see katiybN.

mukotibN *
A teacher of the art of writing. (S.)

bglp makotuwbapN *
, and makotuwbN EalayohaA, A mule that has the oræ of her vulva conjoined by means of a ring or a thong. (A.) See also 1.

mukat~abN *
A bunch of grapes and the like of which a part has been eaten. (K, TA.)

mukotatabN *
: see katiybN.

mukotawotibN *
Swollen, and full. (K.)

katadN *
and katidN [The upper part of the back, above, or between, the shoulders:] the part where the two shoulder-blades come [or approach] together; in a man and a horse (L, K) and a lion: (L:) or the part between the base of the neck and the shoulder-blades: (A:) or the part between the kaAhil [app. here signifying the bas of the neck] and the back; (S, L, K;) as also vabajN: (L:) or the part between the muvab~aj [or place where the pastor puts his stick, or staff, upon his back, putting his arms and hands behind it,] and the middle of the kAhl [which app. here signifies the portion of the back comprising its six upper vertebræ]: or the part from the base of the neck to the bottom of the shoulder-blades, comprising the kaAvibap and vbj and kAhl: (L:) or the kAhl itself: (L, K:) or the upper part of the shoulder-blade: (L:) pl. A^akotaAdN and kutuwdN. (L, K.) ― -b2- naHomiluhu EalaY AlA^akobaAdi faDolFA Eani AlA^akotaAdi [We will carry it upon the livers; much more upon the upper parts of the backs]. (A.) ― -b3- wal~awohumo A^akotaAdahumo They turned their backs upon them, retreating and routed. (A.) ― -b4- Alkatadu (tropical:) A certain star, (S, L, K) [g] in the part called the ktd of the constellation Leo. (L.) ― -b5- humo A^akotaAdN They are companies, or congregated bodies: (L, K:) or, distinct bodies, or parties, or troops: as also A^akodaAdN: (L:) or, like each other; (L, K:) not differing, one from another: (TA:) or, quick, or swift, one party of them following immediately after another: (L, K:) AktAd has no sing.: (K:) it is said to be either A^akodaAdN mispronounced, or a dial. form of this latter word. (MF.)

A^akotadu *
Having the place called the katad prominent. (L, K.)
