[Check thine ass: let him not pasture at large in our meadow: in that case he will be sent back with the ass's shackles straitened]: (S:) meaning Do not venture to revile us; for we are able to shackle this ass, and to prevent his acting as he pleaseth. (L.) See Ham, p. 290. ― -b3- karaba, aor.
karuba
, He loaded a she-camel. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- karabahu, (aor.
karuba
, inf. n. karobN, TA,) It (sorrow, grief, &c., S, K, or an affair, Msb, TA) afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him, (S, Msb, K,) so that it filled his heart with rage. (Msb.) See also 8. ＝ -A4- karaba Ald~alowa, aor.
karuba
, (inf. n. karobN, TA,) and kr~bhA↓, (K,) and AkrbhA↓, (S, K,) He put or attached, a karab to the bucket. (S, K.) ― -b2- kariba, aor.
karaba
, The rope called karab of his bucket broke. (K.) karaba, aor.
karuba
; and kr~b↓; explained by the words TaqoTaqa Alkariyba lixa$abapi Alxab~aAzi [app. meaning, He caused the kryb (a baker's wooden implement) to make a sound, or a reiterated sound, such as is termed TaqoTaqap]. (K.) ＝ -A5- karaba; (accord. to the K;) or kr~b↓, inf. n. takoriybN; (accord. to IM;) He sowed land such as is called kariybN. (K.) ― -b2- karaba AlA^aroDa, aor.
karuba
, inf. n. karobN and kiraAbN, He turned over the ground for sowing, (K,) or for cultivating. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A6- karaba, aor.
karuba
, He took the karab (or lower parts, or ends, of the branches) from the palm-trees. (IAar, K.) He lopped a palmtree. (Msb.) ＝ -A7- karaba, aor.
karuba
; and kr~b↓; He ate the dates called kuraAbap. (K.) ＝ -A8- karaba, aor.
karuba
, inf. n. karobN, He twisted [a rope &c.] (qutala: accord. to some copies of the K) or he slew (qatala: accord to other copies of the same).

2 kar~aba
kr~b: see 1 in four places.

3 kArbh *
i. q. qArbh, He, or it, approached, or was or became near to, him, or it. (K.) The k is substituted for q. (TA.)

4 A^akrbhu *
[He, or it, affected him with karob, i. e. sorrow, grief, distress, or affliction: occurring in the TA in several places.] ＝ -A2- Akrb, inf. n. A_ikoraAbN, He filled (K) a skin. (TA.) ― -b2- Akrb AlA_inaA'a He nearly filled the vessel: [as also Aqrbh]. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1. ＝ -A3- Akrb, inf. n. A_ikoraAbN, (tropical:) He hastened, or sped: (S, K:) he ran, in the manner termed A_iHoDaAr and Eadow. (AZ.) You say, xu*o rijolayoka biA_ikoraAbK [Take up thy feet with speed,] when you order one to hasten in his pace. (S.) In this sense, A^akoraba is said of a man, but seldom; and of a horse, or other animal that runs. (Lth, Lh.)

5 tkr~b *
He picked the dates called kuraAbap (K) from among the roots of the branches (TA) [after the racemes of fruit had been cut off]; and tkr~b Aln~axolapa he picked the dates that were among the roots of the branches of the palm-tree, as also taxal~alahaA. (AHn, TA in art. xl.)

8 Aktrb *
He became afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief, &c., (K,) or by an affair (TA) so also kariba↓, aor.
karaba
. (TA.)

karobN *
[an inf. n. of 1, q. v.] ― -b2- [You say] h`*ahi A_ibilN miAy^apN A^awo karobuhaA (this is the right reading; and some say that kurobuhaA↓ is correct: TA: [the latter is the reading in the CK:]) There are a hundred camels, or about that number; or nearly so. (K.) krb is syn. with qurobN. (L.) ＝ -A2- karobN (S, O, K) and kurobapN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) Grief [or distress, that affects the breath or respiration, [lit.] that takes away the breath: (S, O, and so accord. to some copies of the K, [agreeably with present usage, see bahorN, last sentence:]) or the soul: (so [erroneously] accord. to some copies of the K) or anxiety, solicitude, or disquietude of the mind: (Msb:) [or grief, or anxiety, that presses heavily upon the heart:] or both signify anxiety, grief, or intense grief: (MA:) pl. of the former kuruwbN, (K,) and of the latter kurabN. (Msb.)

kurobN *
: see karobN.

karabN *
The rope that is tied to the bucket after the maniyn, which is the first [or main] rope, so that it (the krb) remains if the mnyn break: or the rope that is tied to the middle of the cross-bars of the bucket, (and is then doubled, and then trebled, S,) so as to be that which is next the water, in order that the great rope may not rot: (S, K:) but in a marginal note in a copy of the S, it is said that this latter explanation properly applies to the darak; not to the krb: (IM:) pl. A^akoraAbN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- karabN [coll. gen. n.] The lower parts, or ends, of palm-branches, (S, K,) which are thick and broad, (K,) like shoulderblades: (S:) or the stumps of the branches, or what remain upon the palm-tree, of the lower parts, or ends, of the branches, after the lopping, like steps: n. un. with p. (TA.) Hence the proverb,
mataY kaAna Hukomu All~`hi fiY karabi Aln~axoli
[When was the wisdom of God in the stumps, or lower ends, of palm-branches?] (S.) Said by Jereer, in reply to Es-Salatán El-'Abdee, who had pronounced El-Ferezdak superior to Jereer in point of lineage, and Jereer superior to ElFerezdak as a poet. IB denies it to be a proverb; but IM contends against him that it is, [The meaning is, When was God's wisdom in husbandmen, and possessors of palm-trees? for the region of Es-Salatán's tribe abounded in palm-trees. The words are applied to a man who provokes another to a contest for excellence, being unworthy of the contest. See Freytag, Arab. Prov., ii. 628.]

kurobapN *
: see karobN.

karabapN *
sing. of kiraAbN, which latter signifies The channels in which water flows (S) in a valley: (K:) or the upper parts (Suduwr) of valleys.
(AA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing bees,
jawaArisuhaA taA^owiY Al$~uEuwfa dawaAy^ibFA
watanoSab~u A^alohaAbFA maSiyfFA kiraAbuhaA
[The eaters, or feeders, among them, resort to the upper parts of the mountains, busily engaged, and pour down (into) ravines with crooked water-channels]. (S.) [jwArs, $Ewf, and mSyf, are explained as above in the TA: and AlhAb is said in the S and TA, art. lhb, to be here pl. of lihobN. In a copy of the S, this last is erroneously written A_ilohaAbFA.] ＝ -A2- karabapN (in the TA, written karabN,) The piece of wood (zir~) in which is inserted the head of a tent-pole. (K.)

karobaAnu *
A vessel nearly full: (S:) fem. karobaA'u; pl. karobaY and kiraAbN. (TA.) Yaakoob asserts, that the k in this word is a substitute for the q in qarobaAnu; but ISd denies this. (TA.)

krAbu A_inaA'K *
[app. kiraAb or kuraAb] What is less than jumaAmu A_inaAwi; [i. e., what is nearly equal to the full, or piled-up, contents, or measure, of a vessel]. (TA.) See qiraAbN.

AlkiraAbu EalaY Albaqari *
[The turning over of the soil is the work of the oxen]: a proverb. (S, K.) See art. kilb: [where other readings, namely AlkiraAba and AlkilaAba and AlkilaAbu, are mentioned]. (K.)

kariybN *
i. q. qaraAHN [Land which has neither water nor trees: or land that is cleared for sowing and planting: pl., app., kiraAbN: see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph of art. xtm:] (K:) and jaAdisN [land that is not cultivated nor ploughed], that has never been sowed. (TA.) See also jariybN. ＝ -A2- A wooden implement of a baker, or maker of bread, with which he forms the cakes of bread (yurag~ifu). (K.) [In the TA is added “ in the oven ”: but I doubt the propriety of this addition.] ＝ -A3- A knot, or joint, (kaEobN), of a reed or cane. (K.) ＝ -A4- Accord. to IAar, i. q. $uwbaqN, which is the same as fayolakuwnN. [$wbq is an arabicised word, from the Persian $uwbajo, or Juwbaho, both of which signify a rolling-pin, and this meaning is given to $wbq and $wbk in the present day. It should be remarked, however, that karoniyb (with n), which is probably a corruption of kariybN, is a name often given in Egypt, in the present day, to a baker's peel.] In the L, kryb is explained, as on the authority of Kr, by sawiyqN; but this is probably a mistake for $wbq. (TA.) See makoruwbN.

karaAbapN *
: see kuraAbapN

kuraAbapN *
(S, K) and karaAbapN↓ (K), but the former is the more approved word, (TA,) Dates that are picked from among the roots of the branches (S, K) after the racemes of fruit have been cut off: (S:) the scattered dates that remain at the roots of the branches: (AHn, TA voce xulaAlapN, which signifies the same:) pl. A^akoribapN, in the formation of which, the augmentative letter (meaning the fem. p, TA,) seems to have been rejected [or disregarded]; for fuEaAlapN (this is the right reading; TA; but in some copies of the K we read fuEaAlaY, and in others fuEaAl;) does not form a pl. on the measure A^afoEilapN. (K.) ― -b2- AHn says, that in this verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
kaA^an~amaA maDomaDato min m~aA'i A^akoribapK
EalaY sayaAbapi naxlK duwnahu malaqu
Akrbp signifies Mountain-tops, from which the water of the mountains flows down; and that its pl. is karobapN: but ISd remarks, that this assertion is not valid; because a sing. of such a measure does not form a pl. on the measure A^afoEilapN. He also says, in one place, that Akrbp is [said to be] pl. of krAbp, which signifies “ dates that fall among the roots of the palm-branches; ” but [that] this is a mistake: upon which ISd remarks, In like manner, [this] his saying is in my opinion a mistake. (TA.)

kariybapN *
A misfortune; a calamity: (S:) or a severe misfortune, or calamity: (K:) pl. karaAy^ibu. (S.)

Alkaruwbiy~uwna *
(K) and Alkar~uwbiy~uwna, or this latter is a mistake, and Alkaruwbiy~apu, (TA,) [Hebr. כְּרֻבִים Cherubim,] the chiefs, or princes, of the angels; the archangels; (K;) of whom are Jebraeel and Meekáeel and Isráfeel; who are also called Almuqar~abuwna, accord. to Abu-l-'Áliyeh: (TA:) the nearest of the angels to the bearers of the throne: so called from krb as signifying “ nearness ” or the “ being near: ” (L:) or from their firmness, or compactness, of make; [see mukorabN] because of their strength, and their patience in worship: or from karabN, “ sorrow &c., ” because of their fear and awe of God. (MF.) Sh quotes the following of Umeiyeh:
karuwbiy~apN minohumo rukuwEN wasuj~adN
[Archangels, among whom are (some) that bend down the body, and (some) that prostrate themselves]. (TA.)

maA biAld~aAri kar~aAbN *
There is not any one in the house. (S, K.)

kaAribN *
[Becoming near; drawing near; approaching]: near; nigh. (TA.) ― -b2- 'Abd-Keys Ibn-Khufáf El-Burjumee says,
A^abunaY~a A_in~a A^abaAka kaAribu yawomihi
faA_i*aA duEiyta A_ilaY AlmakaArimi faA@Eojali
[O my child, verily thy father is near to his day (of death): therefore when thou shalt be called to (the performance of) generous actions, make haste]. (S.) ＝ -A2- A^amorN kaAribu An afflicting, distressing, or oppressive, affair. (TA.)

mukorabN *
(assumed tropical:) A joint full of sinews (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A hard hoof. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A firm, or compact, beast of carriage: (S:) a horse of strong and firm make: (AA:) a firm, or compact, (or strongly compacted, TA,) rope, building, joint, or horse: (K:) a strong horse. (ISd.) ― -b4- mukorabu AlmafaASili, (A,) and AlmfASl makoruwbu↓, (Lth,) (tropical:) An animal of firm joints. (Lth, A.) ― -b5- mukorabu Alxaloqi (assumed tropical:) Of firm make. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mukorabaAtN Camels that are brought to the doors of the tents, or dwellings, in the season of severe cold, in order that they may be warmed by the smoke: (K:) [or] i. q. muqorabaAtN: see muqorabN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- dalowN mukorabapN A bucket having a karab attached to it. (S.)

makoruwbN *
and kariybN↓ Afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief, or anxiety. (K, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also mukorabN.

Q. 1 karobaHa *
He prostrated another: or, [evidently a mistake for and,] inf. n. karobaHapN, he ran heavily; (K;) as also karomaHa: (TA:) and he ran at a slower pace than that termed karodaHapN, (K,) or karodamapN, which is a pace of the ass and mule only. (L.)

kirobaAsN *
A coarse garment or pieces of cloth: (Msb:) or coarse garments or pieces of cloth: (S: [but this explanation is omitted in some copies:]) or a garment or piece of cloth of white cotton: (K:) and so kirobaAsapN: (TA:) or the latter is a more particular term: (S:) [i. e., the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is the n. un.:] a Persian word arabicized; (S, Msb, K;) originally with fet-h, [karobaAs,] altered because of the rareness of the measure faEolaAlN, (K,) in the cases of words not reduplicative: (TA:) [or from כְּרֻבִים, (see Est. i. 6,) whence also kurofusN, and κάρπασος, and carbasus:] pl. karaAbiysu. (S, Msb.)

karaAbiysiY~N *
A seller of karaAbiys: (Msb:) a rel. n., app. likened to A^noSaAriY~N; for otherwise, by rule, it should be kirobaAsiY~N. (Lth, K.)
See Supplement

kurobaqN *
The shop of a vintner: syn. HaAnuwt. As, in TA, voce xS.)
See Supplement

sanapN kariytN *
A complete year. (S, K.) And so a day, and a month. (TA.)

Q. 2 tkrtb EalayonaA *
i. q. tql~b (He turned over upon us or turned against us:) accord. to the K: but accord. to the L and other lexicons, i. q. tgl~b (He got possession of us, or obtained the mastery over us, by force). (TA.)

Q. 1 karotaHa *
, inf. n. karotaHapN, He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly; as also karodaHa. (S, art. krdH.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) and takarotaHa↓, (K,) He went quickly in his walk. (K, TA.)

Q. 2 takarotaHa
see 1.

1 karavahu *
, aor.
karuva
(and
kariva
, TA, as from the K, inf. n. karovN; TA) and Akrvhu↓; It (grief, S, and an affair, TA) pressed severely upon him; oppressed him; afflicted him; distressed him; vexed him: (S, K, TA:) [as also qaravahu]. As rejects the first form, although Ru-beh uses the expression. [You say,] karavaniY AlA^amoru The thing grieved and oppressed me: (As, in TA [but see above:] or pained me. (AA, Skr. p. 20.) ― -b2- karavahu AlA^amoru The affair moved him. (A)

4 A^akorava
see 1.

7 Ankrv *
It (a rope) broke. (K.)

8 Aktrv *
He was oppressed, afflicted, distressed, or vexed. (Lth.) ― -b2- maA A^akotarivu lahu (in some copies of the S, bihi, which is more common, MF) I care not for him, or it: (S, K:) or I am not moved by, and do not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it: (A:) or, as some say, I turn not my face towards him, or it: like A^alotafitu. (TA.) The affirmative phrase A^akotarivu lahu is a deviation from ordinary usage. (Nh.)

karaAvN *
[coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of large trees, (K,) growing on the mountains. (AHn.) [F mentions his having seen them on the mountains of Et-Táïf.] ＝ -A2- And see kur~aAvN.

kariyvN *
: see kaArivN. ― -b2- A_in~ahu lakariyvu AlA^amori [Verily he is in oppressive, afflicting, or distressing, circumstances; or timid, and retiring]: said when one is timid, or cowardly, and draws back, or desists [from an affair]. (K.) And fulaAnN kariyvN Eani AlA^amori Such a one is a recoiler, or shrinker, from the affair. (A in art. rbv.) ＝ -A2- kariyvN is also syn. with makoruwvN↓ [Oppressed, afflicted, distressed, or vexed: and app. attended with difficulty: see rabiyvN] (T in art. rbv:) or kariyvN and makoruwvN↓ both signify pained. (AA, Skr, p. 20.)

busorN karyvaA='u *
, and karaAvaA='u, [in the copies of the K, both words are written without tenween; if rightly introduced here they would be with tenween,] (like qariyvaA='u and qaraAvaA='u, TA,) Good, or sweet, dates, (K.) full-grown, and ripening. (TA.) The leading lexicologists [except the author of the K] agree in mentioning kryvA' [only] in art. krv; like qryvA' in qrv: and the author of the K mentions both again in chapter v. Ibn-Esh-Sheybánee says, qryvA' and kryvA' signify a kind of date (tamor): and some say, a kind of full-grown, ripening date (busor), of a black colour, the skin of which quickly falls off: accord. to the Fs, a well-known kind of full-grown, green date; and said to be the best, or sweetest, kind of date in the full-grown, green state (TA.)

kar~aAvN *
: see kur~aAvN.

kur~aAvN *
(S, Msb, K) and kar~aAvN↓ (Kr, K) and karaAvN↓ (Aboo-'Alee El Kálee) [each a coll. gen. n.,] A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (S, Msb, K,) well-known, of foul odour, (Msb, TA,) and of disagreeable juice; (TA;) [the common leek; or allium porrum of Linn; or leeks:] kur~aAvapN is a more particular term; (Msb;) [i. e. it is the n. un. of kar~aAvN, signifying a single leek.]

A^amorN kaArivN *
, and kariyvN↓, An affair that presses severely upon one; that oppresses, afflicts, distresses, or vexes. (K.) ― -b2- karavatohu AlkawaArivu Affairs pressed heavily upon him; or oppressed him. (A.) Alkurobu AlkawaArivu [Oppressive sorrows, or anxieties.] (S.) (See Har. p. 245)

makoruwvN *
: see kariyvN.

R. Q. 1 karovaA^a *
, [inf. n, karovaA^apN;] and tkrvA^↓; [like krfA^ and tkrfA^;] It (hair, K, or a collection of clouds, TA, &c, K) became large in quantity, (K,) and intricate, or confused; in the dial. of the tribe of Asad; (TA;) and heaped up. (K.)

R. Q. 2
see 1.

kiroviy^N *
Clouds high and piled up, one upon another. (K.) ＝ -A2- kiroviy^N An egg-shell. (K, TA.) Accord. to Sb, from krav. (TA.)

karoviy^apN *
: see kiroviy^apN.

kiroviy^apN *
and karoviy^apN↓ Dense and tangled plants. (K.) ＝ -A2- kiroviy^apN and karoivy^apN↓ The froth of churned milk, when the milk of an ewe is milked upon it and it rises in consequence thereof. Accord. to Sb, from krv. (TA.)

busorN karaAvaA='u *
and kariyvaA='u: see art. krv.

1 karija *
, aor.
karaja
; (or karaja, inf. n. karajN, as in the L,) and Akrj↓; (K;) and kr~j↓; (S, K;) and tkr~j↓; (S, MA, K;) It (bread) spoiled, or became bad, or corrupt, (S, MA, K,) and was overspread with greenness; (S, K;) it became mouldy or musty. (MA.) ― -b2- karaja It (a thing) became corrupt. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- tkr~j↓ It (wheat, or food, TaEaAm,) became spoiled, and overspread with greenness. (L.)

2 kar~aja
see 1.

4 A^akoraja
see 1.

5 takar~aja
see 1.

kur~ajN *
A muhor [lit. a horse-colt, but app. meaning a mock colt, or hobby horse,] (K,) with which one plays: (TA:) [a thing] made (yut~axa*u) like a horse-colt, upon which one plays: (Lth:) an arabicized word, from kur~aho, (S, K,) which is the name of it in Persian. (S.) [Jereer, in two verses, mentions the jalaAjil, or little round bells, of a kr~j.]

xubozN kaArijN *
i. q. mukar~ajN [Bread that is spoiled, and overspread with greenness; mouldy bread]. (IAar, L.)

1 karada *
, (aor.
karuda
, S, L,) inf. n. karodN, He drove, (L, K,) drove away, and repelled, a people: (S, L:) accord. to some, he drove the enemy in a charge or assault: (L:) he drove away the enemy: (K:) he repelled them and drove them away with his sword. (L.) ― -b2- He turned him back from his opinion. (L.) ＝ -A2- He cut off [a thing.] (K.)

3 kArdhu *
, (K,) inf. n. mukaAradapN, (S,) He charged upon, or assaulted, or attacked, him, (S, K,) and repelled him, (K,) the latter doing the same. (S, K.)

karodN *
The neck; (S, L, K;) a Persian word, arabicized: (S, L:) or (properly, L) the base of the neck: (L, K:) or the place where the head is set upon the neck: i. q. qarodN: (L:) the back of the neck; as also karodanN↓ and qarodanN (IAar, T, L.)

kurodN *
a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is kurodapN↓, the latter signifying A ma$aArap, (O, L,) i. e. channel of water for irrigation, (TA, [but see this word, and what follows here below,]) of places, [or plots] of seed-
produce: (O, L, TA:) this is what is meant in the K by the saying that Alkurodu signifies Ald~aborapu mina AlmazaAriEi, and that the n. un. is with p: (TA:) an instance of agreement between the languages of the Arabs and the 'Ajam; or, as some assert, an Arabic word derived from AlmukaAradapu: (O:) or kurodN signifies a daborap, and is [originally] a Pers. word: and the pl. is kuruwdN: and kurodapN is like kurodN [in signification]: (L:) [see also daborapN, voce daborN:] or kurodapN signifies a piece of land, or of sown land, or one having a raised border; and its pl. is kuradN [app. a mistranscription for the coll. gen. n. kurodN]. (MA.)

Alkurodu *
A certain nation; [the Gordiæi: (Golius:) n. un. kurodiY~N:] pl. A^akoraAdN: (S, L, K:) respecting their origin authors differ: it is said that their ancestor was Kurd the son of 'Amr Muzeykiyà the son of 'Ámir Má-es-Semà, not 'Ámir the son of Má-es-Semà, as in the K, for Má-es-Semà was a surname of 'Ámir: (TA:) or they are the remains of the people whom Beewarásf, also called Ed-Dahhák, used to eat: (IKt, MF, TA:) or their ancestor was Kurd the son of Ken'án (or Canaan) the son of Koosh (or Cush) the son of Hám (or Ham) the son of Nooh (or Noah): they consist of countless tribes, differing in language and condition, but all are reduced to four principal tribes, the swrAn and the kwrAn and the kulhr and the lur: (Mohammad Efendee El-Kurdee:) or their ancestor was Kurd the son of 'Amr the son of 'Ámir the son of Saasa'ah: (Abu-l-Yakdhán:) El-Mes'oodee says, that some assert them to be of the descendants of Rabee'ah the son of Nizár: others, that they are of the descendants of Mudar the son of Nizár: others, that they are descended from Kurd the son of Ken'án the son of Koosh the son of Hám: and he adds, that they are apparently of the offspring of Hám, like the Persians: that among the known tribes of which they consist are the swrAny~p, the kwrAnyp, the EmAdyp, the HkAryp, the mHmwdyp, the bxtyp, the b$wyp, the jwbyp, the zrzAy^yp, the mhrAnyp, the jAwdAnyp, the rDAy^yp, the srwjyp, the hArwnyp, and the lryp: and that their countries are Persia, and 'Irák el-'Ajam, and Ádharbeeján, and Irbil, and El-Mósil. (Mo- hammad Efendee El-Kurdee.) [Many other assertions as to the origin of this people are made by other authors.]

karodanN *
: see karodN.

kurodapN *
: see kurodN.

kurodiy~apN *
an appellation of certain dogs [app. belonging to the kurod]. (M voce tadomuriy~apN.)

kirodiy~apN *
: see kirodiydapN.

kirodiydapN *
A large portion of dates. (L, K.) ― -b2- Also, The [kind of basket of palm-leaves called] jl~apN in which dates are put: (Seer, L, K:) or the dates remaining upon the sides in the lower part of the jul~ap: (S, L, K:) as also kirodiy~apN↓: (K:) pl. karaAdiydu (S, L, K) and kiraAdN. (K.)

makoruwdN *
A mustache cut off. (K.)

Q. 1 karodaHa *
, inf. n. karodaHapN, He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly; as also karotaHa and karomaHa. (S.) ― -b2- He (an ass) ran leaning on one side; as also karodama. (L.) ― -b3- He went slowly. (IAar.)

Q. 2 takarodaHa *
He went quickly in his walk; i. q. takarotaHa. (K.) ― -b2- He, or it, rolled. (S, K.) Ex. saqaTa mina Als~aToHi fatakarodaHa He fell from the flat top, or roof, of the house, and rolled. (As, S.)

karodaHapN *
A quick run, (K,) with short steps. (TA.) [See also Q. 1.]

karodaHaA='u *
, which accord. to analogy should be karodaHFY, A kind of walk, (K,) with short steps, and quick. (TA.)

kirodaAHN *
Running quickly; or a quick runner; (K;) with short steps. (TA.)
See Supplement
See arts. krbH and krdH and krmH and Supplement.

kurozN *
The [double bag, or double sack, called] xuroj (ISk, S, K) of the pastor, (K,) in which he carries his provisions and utensils, and which is also put upon the back of the [ram called] kar~aAz: (TA:) or a juwaAliq [or sack]: (A, Msb:) or a small jwAlq: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akoraAzN (ISd, TA) and [of mult.] kirazapN. (S, K.) [See baTiynN.] ― -b2- [See Supplement.]

kar~aAzN *
The ram that carries the xuroj [i. e. the kuroz q. v.] of the pastor: (S, Msb, K:) he goes before the people, (TA,) and has no horns; (S, Msb;) because that which has horns (AlA^aqoranu) diverts himself with smiting others with his horns. (S.)

2 kr~shu *
, (TA,) inf. n. takoriysN, (K, TA,) He put it, or placed it, namely, anything, one part upon another. (TA.) ― -b2- He put it together, one part to another. (TA.) ― -b3- He founded it, namely, a building. (K, TA.)

4 Akrst Ald~aAru *
The house had in it compacted dung and urine of camels or of sheep or goats: S, A, * TA:) and in like manner you say of a place: (TA:) and Akrst Ald~Ab~apu The beast of carriage had upon it, (K, TA,) i. e., upon its tail, (TA,) compacted dung and urine. (K, TA.) See kirosN.

5 tkr~s *
It (anything) became put, or placed, one part upon another. (TA.) ― -b2- It became compacted and cohering; (A, * TA;) as also tkArs↓. (TA.) ― -b3- It (the foundation of a building) became hard and strong. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He collected together fire-wood, &c. (Msb.)

6 takaAorasa
see 5.

kirosN *
Compacted, or caked, or a cake of, dung and urine of camels and of sheep or goats, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) in a house, and upon the traces of men's abode: (TA:) and also, compacted clay or mud: (TA:) pl. A^akoraAsN. (A, TA.) [Hence,] kirosu AlHawoDi The place in which the camels stand at the watering-trough or tank, and which in consequence becomes compacted [by the mixture of their dung and urine with the soil]. (TA.) ― -b2- kirosu binaA='K [The foundation, or lowest part of a building: see 2]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- One of the A^akoraAs [meaning series or strings of beads] of [the necklaces and similar ornaments called] qalaAy^id and wu$uH and the like: you say, qilaAdapN *aAtu kirosayoni [a necklace of two such series], and *aAtu A^akoraAsK valaAvapK [of three such series], when you join one part to another [in several places, by larger beads: see qilaAdapN mukorasapN, below]. (Lth, K. *)

karisN *
: see mukorisN.

kurosiY~N *
and (sometimes, S, Msb) kirosiY~N (S, Msb, K) A throne; syn. sariyrN: (K:) a chair: (TK:) a seat not larger than is sufficient for one person: (Bd, ii. 256:) [and a stool:] pl. karaAsiY~N (S, Msb, K) and sometimes karaAsK, agreeably with a rule mentioned by ISk. (Msb.) It is the place [or seat] of the king, and of the learned man: and hence, as used in the Kur ii. 256, it is explained as signifying (tropical:) Dominion: (A:) and (tropical:) the power of God, whereby He holds the heavens and the earth: (TA:) and (tropical:) knowledge: (A, K:) which last explanation is ascribed to I'Ab: but the truth is, that I'Ab explained it as there signifying the [foot-stool of God; or] place of the feet: but as to the Earo$ [of God], this is immeasurable: (Az, TA:) or it signifies the sphere of the stars. (TA, art. Er$.) [Hence,
also, you say,] huwa mino A^aholi AlkurosiY~i (tropical:) He is of the people of science. (TK.) [And hence,] AlkaraAsiY~u is also used [elliptically] to signify (tropical:) The learned men; accord. to Ktr. (A.) ― -b2- Also, A prop, or support, for a wall. (TA.) ― -b3- [*aAtu AlkurosiY~i The Constellation Cassiopeia: see xaDiybN.]

kiroyaAsN *
A privy on the top of the roof of a house, (S, A, * Msb, K,) with a conduit from the ground, (K,) or, as in some lexicons, to the ground: one that is below is not so called: (TA:) or the privy of an upper chamber: (MF:) of the measure fiEoyaAlN, (Az, Msb, K,) from kirosN, meaning, “ compacted dung and urine of camels, or of sheep or goats: ” (Az, * A, * K, TA:) so called because of the filth that adheres to it, and becomes compacted: (Az, TA:) incorrectly said by some to be also written kirobaAsN, with the single-pointed letter [b]: the pl. is karaAyiysu. (TA.)

kur~aAsN *
: see what next follows.

kur~aAsapN *
[A quire, or parcel, of paper, generally consisting of five sheets, forming ten leaves, of a book; also vulgarly called kar~aAsapN and kar~aAsN;] one of what are termed kur~aAsN↓ and karaAriysu; [kur~aAsN being a coll. gen. n. and karaAriysu a pl.;] (S, A, K;) a portion of a SaHiyfap [i. e. book or volume]: (A, K:) so called because compacted: (TA:) or from takar~asa signifying “ he collected together ” fire-wood, &c. (Msb.) You say, fiY h`*ihi Alkur~aAsapi Ea$oru waraqaAtK [In this quire of a book are ten leaves]. (A.) And h`*aA AlkitaAbu Eid~apu karaAriysa [This book is composed of a number of quires]. (A.) And qaraA^otu kur~aAsapF mino kitaAbi siybawayohi [I read a quire of the Book of Seebaweyh]. (A.) And Alt~aAjiru majoduhu fiY kiysihi waAlEaAlimu majoduhu fiY karaAriysihi [The merchant's glory is in his purse, and the learned man's glory is in his quires of books]. (A.)

mukorasN *
: see mukorisN. ― -b2- qilaAdapN mukorasapN and mukar~asapN↓ A necklace in which the pearls or other beads are strung upon two strings, and these are joined together by divisions of large beads: so in the TS and K, excepting that in the latter, fiY xayoTK is erroneously put for fiY xayoTayoni. (TA.) [See kirosN, last signification.] And [in like manner], naZomN mukar~asN↓ and mutakar~isN A string of beads one above another. (TA.)

rasomN mukorisN *
(S) (in the L and TA mukorasN, but the former, being agreeable with the verb, (see 4,) is probably the right reading,] Traces of men's abode in which is a compacted mixture of dung and urine of camels or of sheep or goats. (S, L, * TA. * [And accord. to the second and third of these authorities, karisN↓ seems to signify the same.])

mukar~asN *
: see mukorasN: the former, in two places.

mutakar~isN *
: see mukorasN: the former, in two places.

1 kari$a *
, said of skin: see 5. ＝ -A2- kari$a Alr~ajulu, aor.
kara$a
, (K, TA,) inf. n. kara$N, (TA,) (tropical:) The man came to have a numerous family, or household, after a while. (Sgh.) And (tropical:) The man came to have an army, or a military force, after having been alone. (K, TA.)

2 kr~$ *
inf. n. takoriy$N, He made what is termed mukar~a$ap. (Az, K.) You say, kar~i$uwA lanaA mino laHomi jazuwrikumo Make ye for us a mkr~$p of the flesh of your slaughtered camel. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) He contracted his face; or contracted it much; [making wrinkles in it like the plies of a kari$:] (K, TA:) and Astkr$↓ also signifies (tropical:) he shrank; contracted his face; frowned, or looked sternly or austerely or morosely. (Sh, TA.)

5 tkr~$ *
(tropical:) It (a man's face, S, A, K, and his skin, A, TA, or the skin of his face, or any skin, TA) contracted, or shrivelled, or shrank, (S, IF, A, K, TA,) and became like the kar$: (IF, TA:) and kari$a↓, aor.
kara$a
, (A, K, TA,) inf. n. kara$N, (A, TA,) signifies the same, (A, K, TA,) said of skin, (K, TA,) when touched by fire. (TA.) You say, kal~amotuhu bikalaAmK fatakar~a$a wajohuhu (tropical:) I spoke some words to him and his face contracted. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- tkr~$wA (tropical:) They collected, or assembled, themselves together. (Sgh, K.)

10 Astkr$t AlA_inofaHapu *
The stomach of a sucking kid became a kari$: (S, K:) i. e., when he pastured upon herbage; (K;) for it is called AnfHp as long as the kid does not eat; but when he eats, it is called kr$. (S.) ― -b2- Also Astkr$ He (a kid, and a boy,) became large in his stomach: or became hard in his palate, and wide in his belly, after he had become large: (TA:) or he (a lamb or kid or calf) became large in his belly: (IAar:) or he (a lamb or kid) became large in his belly, and ate much: (TA:) or he (a kid, A, and a boy, Az, TA) became large in his belly, and began to eat: (Az, A, TA,) but some disapprove of its being said of a boy, asserting that one says of a boy A_isotajofara. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2.

kiro$N *
: see kari$N.

kari$N *
and kiro$N↓ [The stomach, or man, of any ruminant animal;] the part of any ruminant, (S, K,) or of the animal that has a xuf~, [here meaning of the camel,] and of such as has a divided hoof, (A, Msb,) that corresponds to the maEidap of a man: (S, A, Msb, K:) [it is in most cases four-fold; consisting of the first stomach, commonly called the paunch, which is the largest, and has no rugæ upon its internal surface, but a villous coat, having innumerable blunt papillæ which give it a general roughness, and from this the food is forced back into the mouth to be ruminated, as it is also from the second; the honeycomb stomach, which is the second, and which is so called from the cells which form its internal coat; the omasum, which is the third, and smallest, stomach, by some called the millet, but commonly the manyplies, because its internal surface has many plies, or folds, and strata super strata; and the abomasum, or fourth stomach, commonly called the rennetbag, or runnet bag, and the red, or reed, which is next in size to the paunch, and has an internal villous coat like that of the human stomach, but with longer and looser inner plies, or folds, and in this alone the true digestive process takes place:] but it is only thus called after the animal has begun to eat; being previously called A_inofaHapN: (S, TA:) [or, accord. to some, the term is applied to the first and second stomachs, together; for it is said that] it empties itself into the qaTinap [or third stomach], as though it were yadu jiraAbK [so in my original, but this seems to be a mistranscription for lahu jiraAbN, meaning a provisionbag for the animal]: and it also pertains to the have or rabbit, and the jerboa: and is used [tropically] for that of man (TA:) it is of the fem gender: (S, K:) pl. [of pane.] A^akoraA$N (TA) and [of mult.] kuruw$N. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (S, TA,) A_ino wajadotu A_ilaY *`lika faA kari$K, [in the CK, erroneously, faAkori$o.] meaning, (tropical:) If I find to that a way; (S, K, * TA;) said by a man upon whom one has imposed a difficult task; and originating from the fact that a man divided a sheep, or goat, in pieces, and put them into its stomach to cook them; and it was said to him, “ Put in the head ” whereupon he replied in the above words. (S, TA.) You say also, maA wajadotu A_ilayohi faA kari$K (tropical:) I have not found to him, or it, a way. (TA.) And lawo wajadotu A_ilayohi faA kari$K, and baAba kari$K, and A^donaY fiY kari$K, meaning, (tropical:) Had I found to him, or it, as much way as the mouth of a stomach, and the entrance of a stomach, and the least mouth of a stomach, laA^atayotuhu [I had come to him, or I had done it]. (Lh, TA.) And it is said in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, lawo wajadotu A_ilaY damika faA kari$K la$aribati AlbaToHaA='u minoka, meaning, (tropical:) Had I found a way to [shed] thy blood [the small pebbles of the bottom of the water-course had drunk from thee]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] you say, of land (A^aroD), A_igobar~ato jilodatuhaA waraq~ato kari$uhaA [lit. Its skin became dusty, and its stomach became thin]; meaning, (tropical:) it became sterile. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A receptacle for perfumes, and for
clothes: in this sense also fem.: and a place of collection of anything. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And (tropical:) A man's family, or household: and his young children: (A, K:) or his family, or household, consisting of his young children. (S, Msb.) You say, jaA='a yajur~u kari$ahu (tropical:) He came dragging along his family, or household. (A, TA.) And Ealayohi kari$N mino EiyaAlK (tropical:) Upon him is dependent a large family. (A, * TA, in art. bqr.) And humo, (S,) or lahu, (A,) kari$N manovuwrapN, (S, A,) (tropical:) They are, (S,) or he has, (A,) scattered young children. (S, A.) And tazaw~aja fulaAnapa fanavarato lahu kari$ahaA, (S, A, *) and baTonahaA, (S,) (tropical:) He married, or took to wife, such a woman, and she bore to him many children. (S, A.) [See also art. nvr.] ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A company, or congregated body, (S, A, Msb, K,) of men: (S, A, Msb:) pl. A^akoraA$N. (A.) Hence the saying of Mohammad, AlA^anoSaAru kari$iY waEayobatiY (S, TA) (tropical:) The Ansár are my company, and my companions, whom I acquaint with my secrets, and in whom I trust, and upon whom I rely: (TA:) or the meaning is, they are my auxiliaries, from whom I derive aid; because the camel and the beast with a divided hoof draw the cud from the stomach: (TA:) or the depositories of my secrets and trusts, like as the kr$ is the place of the food of the beast: (A:) or the objects of my love and compassion like young children. (Msb.) [And hence, app.,] Alkari$aAni is an appellation applied to [the tribes of] ElAzd and 'Abd-el-Keys. (S.) ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) The main part, or body of a people or company of men: (A, TA:) pl. A^akoraA$N and kuruw$N: or, as some say, these are pls. having no sing. [in this sense.] (TA.) ＝ -A4- vawobu A^akoraA$K [app. from some peculiarity in its colours or texture,] (tropical:) A kind of garment, or cloth, of the description termed buruwd of [the fabric of] El-Yemen. (Az, TA.)

A^akora$u *
(tropical:) A man large in the belly: or, as some say, having large property: (TA:) and [the fem.] karo$aA='u a woman large in the belly (ISk, S, K *) and wide. (TA.) Also the latter, (tropical:) A she-ass bulky in the flanks: (S, K:) or bulky in the belly and flanks. (A.) And the same applied to a foot (qadam), (tropical:) Having much flesh, and even in the part of the sole which is generally hollow, (S, K,) and short in the toes. (S.) And the same applied to a leathern bucket (dalow), (tropical:) (tropical:) Having swollen sides: (A:) or large and with swollen sides. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the fem., (assumed tropical:) Distant relationship. (K.) You say, bayonahumo raHimN karo$aA='u (assumed tropical:) Between them is a distant relationship. (TA.)

takoriy$apN *
What is cooked in the stomachs of ruminants. (AA, K.) See also what next follows.

mukar~a$apN *
[A sort of haggess; or man stuffed with flesh-meat, or flesh-meat and fat, and cooked;] a piece of the stomach of a ruminant, stuffed with flesh-meat, and fastened together with a skewer, and cooked: (A:) or a sort of food, made of flesh-meat and fat, in a piece cut out from the stomach of a camel; (K;) a sort of food of the people of the desert, made by taking flesh-meat marbled with fat (laHom A^a$omaT), well cut up into small pieces, and putting with it fat cut up in like manner, then putting it into a piece cut out from the stomach of a camel, after it has been washed, and its smooth side which is without any villous substance or feces has been cleansed, and fastening its edges together with a skewer, and digging for it a hole for fire, of the size thereof, and throwing into it heated stones, and lighting a fire over them, so that they become of a red heat, like fire, when the coals are put aside from them, and the mkr~$h is buried therein, and hot ashes are put over it; then some thick and tough firewood is kindled over it, and it is left until it is thoroughly well cooked, whereupon it is taken out, having become like one piece, the fat having melted with the flesh, and it is eaten with dates, being sweet. (Az, TA.)

kiro$ab~N *
i. q. qiro$ab~N: (K:) or the former signifies Advanced in years, and hard, gross, or coarse: and the latter, a great eater, or voracious. (T.) The k is said to be substituted for q, or viciously pronounced for the latter letter. (MF.)
See Supplement

Q. 1 karofaA^ati Alqidoru *
The pot frothed, or raised a scum, when about to boil. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- karofaA^a, inf. n. karofaA^apN; and tkrfA^↓; (like krvA^ and tkrvA^, K, which are said to be changed from the former; TA;) It (a collection of clouds) became large in quantity, and confused, and heaped up. (K.) ― -b2- karofaw^uwA They became mixed together. (K.)

Q. 2 takarofaAa
see 1.

kirofiy^N *
i. q. kiroviy^N; (K;) Clouds high and piled up, one upon another. (S) And kirofiy^apN A portion of such clouds. (S.) ― -b2- kirofiy^N An egg-shell. (A'Obeyd, S.) It occurs again in art. krf. (TA.)

kirofiy^apN *
A ceratin tree, also called $afal~aHN. (K.)

karafosN *
, (S, Msb, K,) so written in the Bári' and the T, but in some copies of the S, karofasN, [which is wrong,] (Msb,) [The herb smallage; apium graveolens of Linnæus,] a well known herb, or leguminous plant, (S, Msb, K,) of the hottest of leguminous plants (mno A^aHar~i Albuquwli, TA, [but this is probably a mistake for mino A^aHoraAri Albuquwli of the leguminous plants that are eaten without being cooked, or that are slender and succulent or soft or sweet,]) the utilities of which are great; diuretic; a disperser of winds and flatulence; a cleanser of the kidneys and liver and bladder, opening obstructions thereof; a strengthener of the venereal faculty, especially its seeds pounded with sugar and clarified butter, wonderful when drunk three days, (K,) upon an empty stomach, with avoidance of hurtful things, (TA,) but injurious to the young in the womb, and to the pregnant, and to those affected with epilepsy: (K:) said by Lth to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language, (TA.) and thought to be so by Az: (Msb:) in the O said to be arabicized; and, in the language of the people of Ghazneh, called krfH [or krfj?] (TA.)

kurofusN *
Cotton: (K:) [like kurosufN, from which it appears to be formed by transposition: see also kirobaAsN.]

kurokubN *
, like kurokumN, A certain plant of sweet odour. (K.) The former word is a syn. of the latter. (TA.)
See Supplement

Q. 1 karomaHa *
, inf. n. karomaHapN, i. q. karotaHa, (S, art. krdH, and CK, and a MS copy of the K,) He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly: (S, ubi supra:) or i. q. karobaHa, the b being changed into m, (TA,) he ran at a slower pace than that termed karodamapN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- karomaHonaA fiY A=vaAri Alqawomi We ran heavily in the footsteps of, or after, the people, (AA, S, ubi supra, L.)

Q. 1 krnb *
, inf. n. karonabapN, He fed a guest with karoniyb. (K.) Ex. karonibuwA liDayofikumo faA_in~ahu lataoHaAnu Feed your guest with krnyb, for he is hungry. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, He ate [krnyb, or] dates with milk. (K.) ― -b3- AHei and others assert the n to be augmentative; but in the T, L, and K it is implied that it is radical. (MF.)

kuronubN *
, with damm; [so in the copies of the K in my hands, and in the O, and so accord. to
the TA; but I think that the correct reading is kurunobN, as the word is written by Golius, in one place, and by Freytag; although, in the K, by the words “ with damm, ” in the case of a quadriliteral word, is generally meant “ with damm to the first and third letters ”;] and karanobN; (K;) but it is commonly pronounced with damm [app. meaning to the first and second letters: kurunob being the name now commonly given to the brassica oleracea, or cabbage; in Greek κράμβη]: (TA:) the [vegetable also called] siloqN [properly beet; for which, possibly, cabbage may have been mistaken]: (AHn, K:) or a species thereof, (L, K,) sweeter and more tender than the qun~abiyT; of which the wild kind is bitter; and the quantity of two drachms of its roots, dried and pulverized, mixed with wine ($araAb), is a tried antidote against the bite of a viper. (Ibn-El-Beytár, K.) It is said, by the botanists, to be a Nabathean word, arabicized. (MF.)

karoniybN *
and kironiybN (K) and krnAb (so in the TA) i. q. majiyEa, (K,) which is the same as kudayoraA'u: (IAar:) Dates with milk. (T.)
See Supplement

1 kaz~a *
, [second pers. kazuzota,] (K,) aor.
kazu3a
, (MS, TA,) inf. n. kazaAzapN (S, A, K) and kuzuwzapN, (A, K,) It dried, or dried up; or became stiff, rigid, or tough; and contracted. (S, A, K.) You say, kaz~ato yaduhu His hand became dry, or stiff, rigid, or tough, and contracted. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] kaz~ato xuTaAhu (tropical:) His steps were [contracted, or] near together. (A, K.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] kaz~ato nafosuhu and Aktz~t↓ (tropical:) [His soul became contracted; meaning, he became niggardly]. (A.) And Alr~ajulu Aktz~↓ (tropical:) The man shrank [from giving]. (K, * TA.) You say, fulaAnN laA yahotaz~u wal`kin~ahu yakotaz~u (tropical:) [Such a one does not rejoice, or is not active, or prompt, and brisk, or cheerfully excited, to give, but he shrinks from giving]. (A, TA.) [kazazN (q. v. infra) seems to be an inf. n. of which the verb is kaz~a, second pers. kazizota, aor.
kaza3a
, in the sense of Aktz~↓ as explained above.] ― -b4- kuz~a He (a man) shrank, or became contracted, in consequence of the cold: (S:) or he became affected by what is termed kuzaAz: (A, K:) or he became affected by a rheum. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kaz~ahu Albarodu and Ald~aA='u [The cold, and disease, made him to shrink, or become contracted, and to be affected with a tremour]. (A.) ― -b2- kaz~a Al$~aYo'a, (S, K,) aor.
kazu3a
, inf. n. kaz~N, (TA,) He made the thing narrow, or strait. (S, K.) ― -b3- kaz~ati AlmaroA^apu dumolujahaA, (A, TA,) aor.
kazu3a
, (TA,) (tropical:) The woman filled her armlet with her arm. (A, TA.)

4 Akz~hu A@ll~`hu *
God smote him, or afflicted him, with what is termed kuzaAz. (K.)

8 A_ikotaza3a
see 1, in three places.

kaz~N *
Dry, or dried up; or stiff, rigid, or tough; and contracted: (A, K:) pl. kuz~N. (K.) You say, yadN kaz~apN A dry, or stiff, rigid, or tough, and contracted, hand. (A.) And xa$abapN kaz~apN A stiff, rigid, or tough, (TA,) or hard, (A,) and crooked, piece of wood. (A, TA.) And qanaApN kaz~apN A hard and crooked spear or spear-shaft. (TA.) And qawosN kaz~apN A stiff, rigid, or tough, bow: (S, A, K:) or a bow whereof the arrow does not go far, by reason of the narrowness of the former: (TA:) Aboo-Ziyád says, that the bow thus called is the smallest of bows: (AHn, TA:) pl. qisiY~N kuz~aAtN. (A.) And bakorapN kaz~apN A narrow pulley-sheave, that makes a loud creaking (S, K) by reason of its narrowness. (TA.) And *ahabN kaz~N Tough gold: (A:) or very hard gold. (K.) And jamalN kaz~N A hardy, strong camel. (TA.) ― -b2- rajulN kaz~N, (S, A,) and kaz~N Alyadayoni, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) A niggardly man. (S, A, K,) of little beneficence, (TA,) and of little compliance: (A, TA:) pl. kuz~N. (S.) ― -b3- wajohN kaz~N (assumed tropical:) A foul, or an ugly, face. (K.)

kazazN *
Hardness and crookedness in a piece of wood, or in a spear or spear-shaft. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Niggardliness, (K,) and littleness of compliance and of beneficence. (TA.) See 1.

kuzaAzN *
(S, A, K) and kuz~aAzN↓, (IAar, A, K,) or, accord. to Az, the latter is the correct form, and the former is vulgar, (A,) A contraction and tremour arising from cold: (A:) or a tremour arising from intense cold: (IAar, K:) or a certain disease arising from intense cold; (S, K;) being a spasmodic contraction so occasioned: or, accord. to the physicians, arising from the egress of much blood: (TA:) or a certain disease arising from cold, in consequence of which the patient trembles until he dies. (A.)

kuz~aAzN *
: see kuzaAzN.

makozuwzN *
Made narrow, or strait. (S.) ― -b2- A man affected by what is termed kuzaAz: (S, A, K:) or affected by a rheum. (TA.)

kuzobN *
i. q. kusobN. (K.) ― -b2- [Coll. gen. n., A kind of] hard trees. (K.)

kazabN *
Smallness and contraction of the mu$oT (or metatarsal bones) of the foot; which is a defect. (K.)

kawozabN *
Avaricious, or niggardly, and narrowminded. (K.)

makozuwbapN *
i. q. xilaAsiy~ap in colour; i. e., between black and white. (K.)

kuzoburapN *
, and sometimes, [in the present day commonly,] kuzobarapN, (S, K,) Arabic, and well known, (AHn,) [but J says] I think it is arabicized, (S,) [Chald. כּדּסְבָּר, (Gol.)] One of the kinds of seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; (S, K;) [coriander-seed: or the coriander-plant, accord. to the explanation of kusoburapN (which is said in the TA to be a dial. form of kzbrp) in the K.]
See Supplement

1 kasaA^ *
, aor.
kasa3a
, (S, K,) inf. n. kaso'N, (TA,) He, or it, pursued, or followed, another, (S, K,) as one follows a party which he has put to flight: like kasaEa. (S.) ― -b2- kasaA^a, (K,) inf. n. kaso'N, (TA,) He urged on a beast of carriage. in the track, or at the heels, of another. (K.) ＝ -A2- kasaA^a, (K,) inf. n. kaso'N, (TA,) He overcame a party in litigation or the like. (K.) ＝ -A3- kasaA^a (perhaps a mistake for ka$aA^a, TA,) He smote a person with a sword. (K.)

kaso'N *
inf. n. of 1. q. v. ＝ -A2- mr~a kaso'N mina All~ayoli A part of the night passed. (K.)

kuso'N *
and kusuwo'N↓ The hinder, or latter, part of anything: pl. A^akosaA'N. (S, K.) ― -b2- kuso'N Al$~ahori, and kusuwow^uhu↓, The latter part of the month; its last ten days, or about that period. (TA.) ― -b3- jaA'a fiY kuso'i Al$~ahori, and EalaY kusoy^ihi, He came in the latter part, or end, of the month. (TA.) ― -b4- jaA'a EalaY kuso'i Al$~ahori, and ElY A^akosaAy^ihi, and jiy^otuka EalaY kusaAy^ihi↓, [in the TA written, app. by a mistake of the transcriber, ElY ksA'h, and fiY kusaAy^ihi, [so in the TA,] He came, and I came to thee, at the end of the month, after the whole month had passed. (TA.) ― -b5- jiy^otu fiY A^akosaA='i Alqawomi I came among the latter of the people. (TA.) ― -b6- mar~uwA fiY A^akosaA='i Almunohazimiyna, and ElY A^akosaAy^ihimo, They went at the heels of the routed party. (TA.) rakiba kusoA^ahu He fell upon the back of his neck, or head. (K.)

kusaA='N *
: see kuso'N.

kusuwo'N *
: see kuso'N.

1 kasaba *
, aor.
kasiba
, inf. n. kasobN (S, K, Msb) and kisobN (K), He collected (wealth &c.]; (S,
K;) as also Aktsbhu↓. (S.) This is the original signification. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He gained, acquired, or earned, wealth or the like; as also Aktsb↓. (Msb.) kasabotu $ayoy^FA and Akotasabotuhu↓ are syn., [signifying I gained a thing]. (S.) ― -b3- Hence [also], kasaba and Aktsb↓ (S, K, Msb) and tks~b↓ (K) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance, or the like, (S, K,) for his family: (Msb:) or kasaba signifies he got, or obtained, or gained, acquired, or earned, [sustenance, &c.]; and Aktsb↓, he applied himself with art and diligence [to get, or obtain, or gain, acquire, or earn, sustenance &c.; he laboured to earn, or gain, sustenance]: (Sb, K:) [so] also tks~b↓ is explained by takal~afa Alkasoba he applied himself, as to a task, to gain, &c. (S.) ― -b4- kasaba is also said to signify, and originally, both he sought, or sought after, [sustenance]; and he laboured in seeking, or seeking after, sustenance. (TA.) ― -b5- Aktsb↓ has a more intensive signification than kasaba; and hence, in the last verse of the second chap. of the Kur [lahaA maA kasabato waEalayohaA maA A@kotasabato To it shall be given what reward it hath earned, and upon it shall be executed what punishment it hath drawn upon itself], the latter is used with reference to what is good; and the former, with reference to what is evil. (IJ.) You say, kasaba xayorFA (tropical:) [He gained, or earned, or did, good]: and Aktsb↓ $ar~FA (tropical:) [He gained, or earned, or did, evil]. (A.) ― -b6- [This distinction, however, is not always observed: for] kasaba signifies, He did either a good or an evil deed: [because he who does so earns, or draws upon himself, reward or punishment.] (Jel in ii. 281; and iii. 24; &c.) And Aktsb↓ He committed an act of which he was accusable. (Jel in xxxiii. 58.) kasaba A_ivomFA and Aktsbhu↓ signify He [committed, or] burdened himself with (taHam~ala), a sin, or crime. (Msb.) ― -b7- kasabahu maAlFA, (S, K,) and mAlA Aksbhu↓, (IAar, IAth, K,) but the former is the more approved: the latter is by Fr and some others rejected: (TA:) He caused him to gain, acquire, or earn, wealth: (IAth, Msb:) or he assisted him to gain, acquire, or earn, wealth. (IAth.) ksbhu EilomFA He caused him to gain, or acquire, knowledge. (Msb.) [In like manner,] AlEaboda Asotakosabotu↓ I caused the slave to gain, or make gain; the verb having here the sense of the measure A^afoEalotuhu; like as Aisotaxorajotuhu signifies A^axorajotuhu. (Msb.) [See an ex. voce A^adiymN.] ― -b8- nahaY Eano kasobi AlA_imaA'i [He (Mohammad) forbade the making female slaves to earn money, or the like, (by prostitution)]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b9- maA kasaba in the Kur cxi, 2, is said to signify His children. A man's children are among the things termed his kasob. (TA.) ― -b10- kasabahu EajabFA It occasioned, or caused, him to wonder. (TA, voce A^aEojaba.)

4 A^akosaba
see 1.

5 takas~aba
see 1.

8 A_ikotasaba
see 1 throughout.

kasobN *
inf. n. of 1. q. v. ― -b2- fulaAnN Tay~ibu Alkasobi, (S, K,) and Almakosabi↓, and Almakosibi↓, (K,) and Almakosibapi↓, and Alkisobapi↓, (S, K,) and Alkasiybapi↓, (IM,) [Such a one makes good gain: kasobN &c. signifying gain, acquisition, or earning: and also a deed, whether good or evil].

kusobN *
i. q. kunjArq [or kanojaArahu], a Persian word, called by some of the people of Es-Sawád kusobaj [or kusobah; i. e., The dregs of sesamegrain, or the like, from which the oil has been expressed]; (TA;) dregs remaining after the expression of oil: (S, K:) [as also kuzobN:] from the Persian k$b, (AM,) [or rather kusobah, or kusobaj]. See also tax~N.

kasobapu *
: see kasaAbi.

kisobap *
: see kasobN.

kasobiY~N *
: see AikotisaAbiY~N.

kasaAbi *
The wolf. (L, K.) ― -b2- A name of a bitch: (S:) one of the names of the bitch: (ISd:) as also kasobapu↓: (K:) as kusayobN↓ is a name of the dog; i. e., of the male: (K:) names thus used as ominous of gain, [or of capturing game]: (IM:) kasaAbi, as a name of a hunting bitch, means kaAsibapN. (TA, art. brH.)

kasuwbN *
[so in the copies of the K in my hands; but by the place in which it is mentioned in the TA, it is implied that it is kas~uwbN↓: see also lasuwbN] A thing; anything. maA lahu kasuwbN He has not anything. (K.) ＝ -A2- rajulN kasuwbN, and kas~aAbN↓, A man who makes much gain. (K.)

kusayobN *
: see kasaAbi. ― -b2- A_ibonu Alkusayobi Bastard. (K.)

kas~aAbN *
: see kasuwbN.

kas~uwbN *
A certain plant. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also kasuwbN.

AlkawaAsibu *
i. q. AljawaAriHu, (S, K,) here meaning The members (either of a man or of a bird) by means of which is gained, acquired, or earned, sustenance, or the like. (MF.) [The explanation in the TA, AljawaAriHu mina AlA_inosaAni waAlT~ayori, seems, at first sight, to signify preyers, whether men or birds: but this meaning I do not think to be the one intended.]

A^abuw kaAsibK *
The wolf. (K.)

AikotisaAbiY~N *
[Acquired knowledge, such as is acquired by study: as also kasobiY~N↓:] opp. to DaruwriY~N as meaning [natural or instinctive, or] such as the creature has by [Divine] appointment. (Kull p. 232.)

makosaibN *
, and makosibapN see kasobN.

kusoburapN *
and kusobarapN The plant of the julojulaAn; (K;) [i. e., the plant of which the fruit, or produce, is called AljulojulaAn;] dial. forms of kuzoburapN and kuzobarapN, q. v. (TA.)

kusotN *
i. q. qusoTN (K) and kusoTN, [i. e. Costus,] with which one fumigates. (Kr.)

1 ksj *
, [app. kasija, aor.
kasaja
,] inf. n. ksj, [app. kasajN,] He had no beard grown; [was naturally beardless]. From this it would seem that kwsj is an Arabic word. (IKoot, Msb.)

Q. Q. 1 kawosaja *
He was, or become, what is termed kawosajN; (K;) from which latter word the verb is derived. (Shifa el-Ghaleel.)

Q. Q. 2 mano TaAnato liHoyatuhu takawosaja Eaqoluhu *
(assumed tropical:) [He whose beard becometh long, his intellect becometh small.] (TA.)

kawosajN *
(Th, S, K, &c.) and kuwsajN, (Fr, K,) thus pronounced by some of the Arabs agreeably with its Persian original, (Fr,) but this latter form is disapproved by Yaakoob and ISk and IDrst, (TA,) and AHei says that SuwbajN and suwsanN are the only words of the measure fuwEalN, (MF,) and kuwsujN, (Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee,) a more strange form than that immediately preceding, (MF,) a word of well-known meaning, (K,) A man having no hair upon the side of his face [but only upon his chin]; (M;) i. q. A^avaT~u; (M, S;) whose cheeks are clear of hair; (Expositions of the Fs) [used in the present day to signify having a scanty, or small, beard, and that only on the chin:] an arabicized word, (S, &c,) originally kwsq, (Msb,) [or rather kuwsaho, which is Persian]. ― -b2- Also, Deficient in the teeth: (As, K:) from the Persian kwzh, (Sb,) [or rather kuwsaho]: [pl. kawasiju, occurring in the TA in art. vT.] A woman said to her husband Thou art kwsj: to which he replied, if I be kwsj, thou art divorced. And the matter being referred to the Imám Aboo-Haneefeh, he said, Let his teeth be numbered; and if they be twenty-eight, he is kwsj, and his wife is
divorced from him; but if they be thirty-two, he is not so, and she is not divorced. And they were numbered, and found to be thirty-two (MF.) ― -b3- Also, [The Xiphias, or sword-fish;] a certain fish (of the sea, S) that has a snout like a saw, (S, K,) and eats men; i. q. laxomN, (TA,) and jamalu AlmaA='i, (Mgh in art. jml,) or jamalu AlbaHori. (TA in that art.) ― -b4- Also, A slow hackney, or nag. (A, K.)

1 kasaHa *
, (aor.
kasiHa
, K, inf. n. kasoHN, Msb,) He swept a house, or chamber. (S, Msb, K,) [You say] kasaHati Alr~iyHu AlA^aroDa The wind swept off the dust from the surface of the ground. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] kasaHa (tropical:) He cleaned out a well, and a canal or channel of running water, &c. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And hence also,] (tropical:) He cut a thing off; destroyed it; did away with it, carried it off: (Msb:) [he swept it away.] ― -b4- kasaHonaA baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) We extirpated the sons of such a one. (A.) ― -b5- kasiHa, aor.
kasaHa
, inf. n. kasaHN, He had a heaviness in one of his legs, and dragged it when he walked: (T:) he was crippled in the legs, and in the arms: (L, K:) mostly used in relation to the legs. (L.) [See also kusaAHN.]

8 A^agaAruwA Ealayohimo faA@kotasaHuwhumo *
(tropical:) They made a hostile attack, or incursion, upon them, and took all their property. (S, K. *) ― -b2- A_ikotasaHonaA maAla baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) We took [or swept off] all the property of the sous of such a one, leaving them nothing. (L.) ― -b3- [In like manner you say] kasaHa mina AlmaAli maA $aA='a [(tropical:) He swept off what he pleased of the property]; as also kavaHa. (K, voce kavaHa.)

kasoHN *
Impotence, (K,) arising from a disease which attacks the hips, and weakens the leg. (TA.)

kasoHaAnu *
: see A^akosaHu

kusaAHN *
(L) and kusaAHapN↓ (K) The state of being crippled (zamaAnap) in the legs, and in the arms: (L, K:) mostly used in relation to the legs. (L.) [See 1.] ― -b2- kusaAHN A certain disease of camels, (L, K,) which renders them very lame, so that they cannot walk: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L.)

kasiyHN *
: see A^akosaHu. ― -b2- Also, Impotent (K) in walking, as though he swept the ground. (TA.)

kusayoHN *
: see A^akosaHu.

kusaAHapN *
Sweepings; (S, K;) dust that is swept from a house and thrown in a heap. (Lh.) ＝ -A2- See also kusaAHN.

A^akosaHu *
and kasoHaAnu↓ and kasiyHN↓ (L, K) and kusayoHN↓ (K) and mukas~aHN↓ (L) Having a heaviness in one of his legs, and dragging it when he walks: (L:) crippled in the legs, and in the arms: (L, K:) also the first (as explained by some, L,) lame, by nature, or by reason of a chronic ailment: and affected by a disease which deprives one of the power of walking: (S, L, K:) pl. kusoHN (L) and kusoHaAnN. (L, K.) AlS~adaqapu maAlu AlkusoHaAni waAlEuwraAni (S, L) Alms are the property of the crippled and the one-eyed. (L, from a trad.)

mikosaHapN *
A broom, or besom, or instrument with which one sweeps (S, K) snow, &c.; (S;) as also mikosaHN. (L.)

mukas~aHN *
: see A^kosaHN.

makosuwHN *
A camel severely lame, (L, K,) so that he cannot walk. (Aboo-Sa'eed, L.)

Q. 1 kasoHaba *
, inf. n. kasoHabapN, He walked in fear, hiding himself. (K.)

1 kasada *
, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
kasuda
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. kasaAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and kusuwdN; (K;) and kasuda; (L, K;) but the former is the verb in common use; (TA;) It (a thing, S, Msb, a commodity, &c., L) was, or became, unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (L, Msb, K.) The original meaning is It was, or became, in a bad, corrupt, or unsound state. (T, Msb.) ＝ -A2- kasadati Als~uwqu, (aor.
kasuda
, inf. n. kasaAdN, L,) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (S, * A, L, Msb, K.) See 4.

4 Aksd *
He (God) made a market stagnant, or dull with respect to traffic. (A, Msb) ― -b2- He (a man) found his market to be stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (S, IKtt, A, L, K.) [In most copies of the K, we find, wasuwqN kaAsidN waA^akosadu waA^akosadato suwquhumo, instead of wasuwqN kaAsidN waA^akosaduwA kasadato suwquhumo, which is the right reading, as is indicated in the TA.]

kasiydN *
: see kaAsidN. ― -b2- Also, of inferior condition; ignoble: syn. duwnN. (S, L, K.) So in the saying of the poet, (S, L,) Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Málik, surnamed Mo'owwidh-el-Hukamà, (IB, L,)
A_i*o kul~u HaY~K naAbitN biA^aruwmapK
nabota AlEiDaAhi famaAjidN wakasiydN
(S, L) meaning, Since every living man grows from a root, like the growth of the 'idáh, there is he who is noble, and he who is ignoble. (IB, L.)

kaAsidN *
and kasiydN↓ A thing, (S, Msb,) or commodity, &c., (L,) unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (L, Msb, K.) You say siloEapN kaAsidapN. (S.) ― -b2- suwqN kaAsidN, (S, L, Msb, K,) without p, (S, L, Msb,) or kaAsidapN, as in the T, (Msb) A market stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; (L, Msb, K;) i. e., *aAtu kasaAdK. (TA.)

1 kasarahu *
, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
kasira
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. kasorN; (Msb, TA;) and Aktsrhu↓: (K;) [He broke it: or the latter signifies he broke it off: or it is similar to A_iqotaTaEahu and the like and signifies he broke it off for himself: for] you say minohu TarafFA Aktsrtu↓ [I broke off, or broke off for myself, from it, an extremity]. (A.) You say kasarotuhu A@nokisaArFA↓ and A_inokasara kasorFA, putting each of the inf. ns. in the place of the other, because of their agreement in meaning, not in respect of being trans. and intrans. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- kusira He had his leg broken; his leg broke. (Mgh.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yakosiru Ealayoka Alfuwqa, (A, K,) or AlA^aroEaAZa, (K,) or yukas~iru↓, (as in the CK, * and in a MS copy of the K, but we find the former reading in art. rEZ in the K,) [lit., Such a one breaks against thee the notch of the arrow, or the sockets of the arrow-heads: meaning,] (tropical:) such a one is angry with thee: (A, K:) or is vehemently angry with thee. (K, art. rEZ, in which see further explanations.) ― -b4- [kusira bayonahumo rumoHN lit., A spear was broken among them: meaning, (assumed tropical:) a quarrel occurred among them. (Reiske, cited by Freytag, but whether from a classical author is not said; and explained by him as signifying Simultas inter eos intercessit.)] ― -b5- kasara AlkitaAba EalaY Eid~api A^abowaAbK wafuSuwlK (tropical:) [He divided the book, or writing, into a number of chapters and sections]. (A.) ― -b6- kasara Al$~aEora, aor.
kasira
, inf. n. kasorN, (assumed tropical:) [He broke the measure of the poetry;] he did not make the measure of the poetry correct. (TA.) ― -b7- kasarotu Alqawoma, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) I [broke, crushed, routed, or] defeated, the people or party. (Msb.) ― -b8- kasarotu xaSomiY (tropical:) [I defeated my adversary]. (A.) ― -b9- [kasara nafosahu (assumed tropical:) He broke, or subdued, his spirit. ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) He abased, or humbled, himself.] ― -b11- kasarotu mino saworatihi (tropical:) [I broke, or subdued, or abated, somewhat of his impetuosity, or violence, or tyranny, or anger]. (A.) ― -b12- kasara Humay~aA Alxamor biA@lomizaAji (tropical:) [He broke, or subdued, or abated, the intoxicating influence of the wine by the mixture of water]. (A.) ― -b13- kasara mino barodi AlmaA='i, and Har~ihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He abated, or allayed, somewhat of the coldness of the water, and its heat. (TA.) ― -b14- Aikosiro Ean~aA: see an ex. voce ruwbapN. ― -b15- [kasara AlEaTa$a (assumed tropical:) It abated, or allayed, thirst.] ― -b16- kasara mataAEahu (tropical:) He
sold his goods by retail, one piece of cloth after another: (IAar, K:) because, [on the contrary,] wholesale makes them to find purchasers readily. (TA) ― -b17- kasarotu Alr~ajula Eano muraAdihi (assumed tropical:) I turned the man, averted him, or turned him back, from his desire. (Msb.) ― -b18- yakosiru *anabahu baEoda maA A^a$aAlahu [app. (assumed tropical:) He contorts his tail after raising it], said of a camel. (K.) ― -b19- kasara Alv~awoba, and Aljiloda, (assumed tropical:) He folded, and he creased, the garment, or piece of cloth, and the skin. Ex. of the former signification, [in which the pronoun refers to a tent:] mino Hayovu yukosaru jaAnibaAhu [(assumed tropical:) Where its two sides are folded]. (S.) You say also kasara AlwisaAda, meaning (tropical:) He folded, or doubled, the pillow, or cushion, and leaned, or reclined, upon it. (K.) See also kaAsirN. ― -b20- kasara jafonahu naHowahu (assumed tropical:) [He blinked, (lit. he wrinkled his eyelid) towards him]. (Mgh. art. gmz.) You say also, riyHN HaAr~apN takosiru AlEayona Har~FA (assumed tropical:) [A hot wind, that makes the eye to blink, or contract and wrinkle the eyelids, by reason of heat]. (K, art. xwS.) And kasara Eayonahu, (A,) and kasara mino Tarofihi, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He contracted (gaD~a, q. v.,) his eye, or eyes; [so as to wrinkle the lids; in which sense the former phrase is used in the present day:] (K:) and kasara EalaY Tarofihi, accord. to Th, he contracted (gaD~a) his eye, or eyes, somewhat: (TA:) [or perhaps EalaY is here a mistake for EalaY~a, in which case we must read Tarofahu, so that the meaning would be as above with the addition at me:] and mukaAsarapu↓ AlEayonayoni signifies AlmugaADanapu [i. e. the contracting of the eyes so as to wrinkle the lids]. (S, K, in art. gDn.) ― -b21- kasara AlT~aAy^iru janaAHayohi, (A, TA,) aor.
kasira
, inf. n. kasorN; (TA;) and kasara alone, (S, A, K,) inf. n. kasorN and kusuwrN, (K,) or in this case, when the wings are not mentioned, kusuwrN [only]; which shows that a verb, when its objective complement is forgotten [or suppressed], and the inf. n. [for AlHadiyvu in my original I read AlHadavu] itself is desired [to be expressed], follows the way of an intrans. verb; (A;) [for fuEuwlN is by rule the measure of the inf. n. of an intrans. verb, of the measure faEala, such as qaEada, inf n. quEuwdN, and jalasa, inf. n. juluwsN, and faEolN of that of a trans. verb;] (tropical:) The bird contracted his wings, (S, A, K,) or contracted them somewhat, (TA,) so that he might descend in his flight, (S,) or in order to alight. (A, K.) ― -b22- [kasara AlHarofa, aor.
kasira
, inf. n. kasorN, He pronounced the letter with the vowel termed kesr: and he marked the letter with the sign of that vowel. A conv. phrase of lexicology and grammar.] ＝ -A2- See also 7.

2 ks~rhu *
, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. takosiyrN, (Msb,) is with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action] or multiplicity [of the objects] (S) [He broke it much, in pieces, or into many pieces: or many times, or repeatedly; or he broke it, meaning a number or collection of things.] ― -b2- fulaAnN yukas~iru Ealayoka Alfuwqa, or AlA^aroEaAZa: see 1. ― -b3- [ks~rhu also signifies He divided it (i. e. a number, and a measure,) into fractions.] ― -b4- ks~rhu AlkaraY (tropical:) [Drowsiness made him languid]. (A, TA in art. hyD.] ― -b5- [ks~r $aEarahu, inf. n. takosiyrN, (assumed tropical:) He crimped his hair, see raT~ala.] ＝ -A2- ks~r AlmaA='u AlwaAdiY (tropical:) The water made [the kusuwr, i. e.,] the turnings, bendings, or windings, (maEaATif,) of the valley, and the parts thereof eaten away by torrents, to flow with water. (Th.)

3 kaAosara
see 1.

5 tk~sr *
, (S, A, Msb, K,) quasi-pass. of 2, (Msb, K,) [It broke, or became broken, much, in pieces, or into many pieces; or many times, or repeatedly; or it (a number or collection of things) broke, or became broken.] ― -b2- [Said of water, and of sand, (assumed tropical:) It became rippled by the wind. And of crisp hair, (assumed tropical:) It became crimped; or became rimpled, as though crimped. (In these senses it is used in the S in art. Hbk, &c. See HibaAkN.) Also said of the skin, (assumed tropical:) It became wrinkled: see tagaD~ana. Said of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a coat of mail, and skin, (assumed tropical:) It became folded, and it became creased, much, or in several, or many places. See an ex. below, voce kisorN.] ― -b3- [And hence, as meaning, (assumed tropical:) It became contracted,] said also of the eye. (TA in art. x$E.) [See 1.] ― -b4- [(tropical:) He was, or became, languid, or loose in the joints. And (assumed tropical:) He affected languor, or languidness: a very common signification.] You say, fiyhi taxan~uvN watakas~urN (assumed tropical:) [In him is effeminacy, and affectation of languor or languidness]. (A.) And one says of an effeminate man, tks~r fiY kalaAmihi (assumed tropical:) [He affected languor, or languidness, in his speech], (IDrd, O, voce tafar~aka,) and also ma$oyihi [his walk]. (K, ibid.) See also 7.

7 Anksr *
, quasi-pass. of 1, (S, A, Msb, K,) [It broke, or became broken.] You say, kasarotuhu↓ A@nokisaArFA and Ainokasara kasorFA. (Sb, TA. See 1.) ― -b2- Anksrt Als~ihaAmu EalaY Alr~uw^uwsi (assumed tropical:) The portions became fractional to the several heads; were not divisible into whole numbers. (Msb.) ― -b3- Anksr Al$~iEoru (assumed tropical:) The poetry became [broken, or] incorrect in measure. (TA.) ― -b4- [Anksr Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people became broken, or defeated.] ― -b5- Anksr xaSomiY (tropical:) [My adversary became defeated.] (A.) ― -b6- [Anksrt nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) His spirit became broken, or subdued: and Anksr, alone, he became broken in spirit; his sharpness of temper, vehemence of mind, or fierceness, became broken, or subdued; he became meek, gentle, or humble.] ― -b7- [Anksr, said of a man, also signifies, very frequently, (tropical:) He became languid, or languishing. See the act. part. n., below. And see 5.] fatorapN and AinokisaArN and DaEofN are syn. (S, art. ftr.) ― -b8- Anksr Eani Al$~aYo'i (assumed tropical:) He lacked power, or ability, to do, or accomplish the thing. And Anksr [alone] (assumed tropical:) He, or it, (said of anything, [man or beast,]) remitted, flagged, or became remiss, in an affair, lacking power, or ability, to perform, or accomplish, it. (TA.) ― -b9- Anksr naZaru AlT~arofi (assumed tropical:) The look of the eye, or eyes, became languid, or languishing; syn. fatara. (IKtt, in TA, art. ftr.) And Anksr Tarofuhu (assumed tropical:) [His eye, or eyes, or sight, became languid, or languishing, or not sharp]. (T, K, art. ftr.) ― -b10- Also Anksr, said of the coldness of water, [and of cold, absolutely, and of the heat of water,] and of heat, [absolutely,] and of anything, (TA,) for instance, of a price, and so kasara↓, (Fr. in TA, art. qT,) (assumed tropical:) It abated, or became allayed; or, [said of heat,] it became languid, or faint. (TA.) ― -b11- Said of dough, (assumed tropical:) It became soft, and leavened, or good, and fit to be baked. (TA.) ― -b12- [Said of a garment, or piece of cloth, and skin, (assumed tropical:) It became folded; it became creased. Ex.:] yaTowiY Alv~iyaAba A^aw~ala Tay~ihaA Hat~aY tanokasira EalaY Tab~ihi [He folds the garments, or pieces of cloth, the first time of folding them, so that they may crease agreeably with his folding]. (S, K, voce qasaAmiY~N. [In one copy of the S, I find tatakas~ara in the place of tanokasira, which latter reading I find in a better copy of the same work.])

8 A_ikotasara
see 1, first sentence.

kasorN *
: see kisorN, throughout. ― -b2- (tropical:) A fraction, or broken part of an integral, as the half, and the tenth, and the fifth; (Msb;) what does not amount to an integral portion: (K:) pl. kusuwrN. (A, Msb.) You say, Daraba AlHus~aAbu Alkusuwra baEoDahaA fiY baEoDK (tropical:) [The calculator multiplied the fractions together]. (A.) ― -b3- Little in quantity or number: (ISd, K:) as though it were a fraction of much. (ISd.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A crease, wrinkle, ply plait, or fold, in skin, and in a garment or piece of cloth; (JK, S, * K, * voce gar~N, in the CK gur~; and so accord. to the explanation of the pl. in the present art. in the TA;) as also makosirN↓: (accord. to the explanations of its pl. in the S, Mgh, Msb voce gaDonN:) pl. of the former kusuwrN: (JK, S, voce gar~N; and TA in the present art.;) and of the latter, makaAsiru. (S, Mgh, Msb, voce gaDonN; &c.) ― -b5- See also kusuwrN, below. ＝ -A2- [As a conventional term in grammar, A vowel-sound, well known; the sign for which is termed kasorapN↓.]

kisorN *
and kasorN↓, (S, K, &c.,) the latter of which is [said to be] of higher authority (A^aEolaY) than the former, [but this is doubtful, for the former is certainly the more common,] (TA,)
A portion of a limb: or a complete limb: (K:) or a limb by itself, which is not mixed with another: (TA:) or half of a bone, with the flesh that is upon it: (K:) or a bone upon which there is not much flesh, (S, K,) and which is broken; otherwise it is not thus called: (S) or any bone: (AHeyth:) or a limb of a camel: (TA:) or of a human being or other: (ISd. TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akosaArN (TA) and [of mult.] kusuwrN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- kisru qabiyHK, (S, K,) and qabiyHK kasoru↓, (S,) The bone of the saAEid [here meaning the upper half of the arm, from the part next the middle to the elbow. (El-Umawee, S, K.) [See also qabiyHN. And ksr HasanK signifies The upper part of that bone.] ― -b3- Also kisorN and kasorN↓ The side of a bayot [or tent]: (K:) or the part of [each of] the two sides thereof that descends from the TariyqataAni [app. meaning the two outer poles of the middle row]; every tent having two such, on the right and left: (TA:) or the lowest $uq~ap [or oblong piece of cloth] of a [tent of the kind called] xibaA=': (A, K:) or the part of that $q~h which is folded or creased (takas~ara watavan~aY) upon the ground: (K:) or the lowest $q~p of a bayot [or tent], that is next the ground, from where its (the tent's) two sides are folded (mino Hayovu yukosaru jaAnibaAhu), on thy right hand, and thy left. (ISk, S.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or kasorN↓ [only], (TA,) [but for this limitation there appears no reason,] A side (K, TA) of anything; as, [for instance,] of a desert: (TA:) pl. A^akosaArN and kusuwrN [app. in all the senses: see above]. (K.) ― -b5- qidorN kisorN, and A^akosaArN, (TA,) and A_inaA='N A^akosaArN, (IAar,) and jafonapN A^akosaArN, (K,) A cooking-pot, (TA,) and a vessel, (IAar,) and a bowl, (K,) large, and [composed of several pieces] joined together: (IAar, K:) because of its greatness or its oldness: as though, in the second and following phrases, the term ksr applied to every distinct part of it. (TA.) ― -b6- See also kusuwrN, below.

kasorapN *
(assumed tropical:) A defeat. You say, waqaEa Ealayohimu Alkasorapu Defeat befell them. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also kasorN.

kisorapN *
(in some copies of the K kisorN, but this is a mistake, TA,) A piece of a broken thing: (S, K:) or rather a piece broken from a thing: (TA:) or a fragment, or broken piece, of a thing: (Msb:) pl. kisarN. (S, Msb, K.) You say, kisorapN mino Alxubozi A broken piece of bread. (Msb.) See also kusaArN.

kisoraY *
and kasoraY, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, accord. to Th and others, and it alone is allowed by Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, (Msb,) A name (TA) applied to the king of the Persians, (Msb, K, TA,) or a surname of the kings of the Persians, (S,) like Aln~ajaA$iY~u, a name of the king of Abyssinia, (TA), arabicized from xusorawo, (S, K,) which means “ possessing ample dominion, ” (K,) in the Persian language: so they say: but xusorawo is itself arabicized from xuw$o ruwo, which means, in that language, “ goodly in countenance ”: (TA:) [but that xsrw is an arabicized word may reasonably be doubted:] accord. to IDrst, it is changed into ksrY because there is no word in Arabic having the first letter with damm and ending with w; and the x is changed into k to shew that it is Arabicized: (MF:) the pl. is A^akaAsirapN, (S, Msb, K,) contr. to analogy, (S,) and kasaAsirapN and A^akaAsiru and kusuwrN, (K,) [all of which are also] contr. to analogy: (TA:) by rule it should be kisorawona, like Eiysawona (S, K) and muwsawona. (S.)

kisoriY~N *
: see kisorawiY~N.

kisorawiY~N *
and kisoriY~N↓ Of, or relating to, kisoraY; rel. ns. from kisoraY: (S, Msb, K:) and kasorawiY~N alone is the rel. n. from kasoraY. (Msb.) [In the TA, it is said that one should not say kasorawiY~N; but it seems that what is not allowable is kasoriY~N.]

kusaArN *
and kusaArapN [Fragments, or broken pieces or particles, that fall from a thing:] what breaks from a thing: (Sgh:) or what breaks in pieces from a thing, (K, TA,) and falls: (TA:) fragments, or broken pieces or particles, (duqaAq, ISk, S, and HuTaAm, S,) of fire-wood. (ISk, S.) You speak of the kusaAr of glass, and of a mug, and of aloes-wood. (A.)

kusuwrN *
(assumed tropical:) The turnings, bendings, or windings, (maEaATif, K, TA,) and parts eaten away by torrents, (jirafap, TA,) and ravines, ($iEaAb, K, TA,) of valleys, (K, TA,) and of mountains: (TA:) a pl. without a sing.: (K:) you do not say kasoru AlwaAdiY nor kisoru AlwAdY. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroDN *aAtu kusuwrK (tropical:) A land having [places of] ascent and descent. (S, A.) ― -b3- See also kasorN and kisorN.

kasiyrN *
i. q. makosuwrN↓, [Broken,] (S, K,) applied to a thing: (S:) and so the fem., without p: (TA:) pl. kasoraY, (S, K,) like as maroDaY is pl. of mariyDN, (S,) and kasaAraY: (K:) [and makaAsiyru is pl. of makosuwrN:] Abu-l-Hasan says, that Sb mentions the pl. makaAsiyru because it is of a kind proper to substs. (TA.) ― -b2- nAqp kasiyrN (S, K) i. q. makosuwrapN [lit., A broken she-camel,] (K,) is like the phrase kaf~N xaDiybN, (S, TA,) meaning maxoDuwbapN: (TA;) or a she-camel having one of its legs broken: (Mgh:) and $aApN kasiyrN a sheep, or goat, having one of its legs broken: ksyr being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mgh, Msb:) and kasiyrapN also, [app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] like naTiyHapN: (Msb:) kasiyrN, occurring in a trad. is explained as signifying a sheep, or goat, having a broken leg, that cannot walk; (IAth, * Mgh;) but this requires consideration. (Mgh.)

kaAsirN *
[Breaking]; fem. with p: pl. masc. and fem. kus~arN; and pl. fem. kawaAsiru also (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Folding or doubling, and leaning or reclining upon, a pillow or cushion. Hence the following. in a trad. of 'Omar, lA yazaAlu A^aHaduhumo kaAsirFA wisaAdahu Einoda A@moraA^apK mugoziyapK, meaning, (tropical:) Not one of them ceases to fold or double his pillow or cushion at the abode of a woman whose husband is absent in war, and to lean or recline upon it, and enter upon discourse with her. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) An eagle, (A, K,) and a hawk or falcon, (A,) contracting his wings, (A, K,) or contracting them somewhat, so that he may descend in his flight, (TA,) or in order to alight. (A, K.) ― -b4- AlkaAsiru ↓ The eagle. (S, M, K.)

AlA_ikosiyru *
i. q. AlkiymiyaA='u q. v. (Sgh, K.)

jamoEu Alt~akosiyri *
(assumed tropical:) [The broken plural;] the plural in which the composition of the singular is changed; (K;) the change being either apparent, as in rijaAlN, pl. of rajulN, or understood, as in fulokN, which is both sing. and pl., for the dammeh in the sing. in this case is like the dammeh of qufolN, and that in the pl. is like that of A^sodN. (Ibn- 'Akeel: see Dieterici's “ Alfijjah ” &c.; pp. 329 and 330.) ― -b2- Also takosiyrN (assumed tropical:) [The area of a circle]: in the circle are three things: daworN [or circumference] and quTorN [or diameter] and takosiyrN [or area], which [last] is the product of the multiplication of the half of the qTr by the half of the dwr: and it is sometimes called misaAHapN. You say, maA takosiyru daAy^irapK quToruhaA saboEapN wadaworuhaA A@vonaAni waEi$oruwna [What is the area of a circle of which the diameter is seven and its circumference two-and-twenty?]: and the answer is vamaAniyapN wavalaAvuwna waniSofN [Eight-and-thirty and a half]. (TA.) [It is scarcely necessary to add that this is not perfectly exact.]

makosirN *
A place of breaking, (K, TA,) of anything. (TA.) You say, EuwdN Sulobu Almakosiri [Wood, or a piece of wood, or a branch, or twig, hard in the place of breaking,] when you know its goodness by its breaking: (S, A:) and EuwdN Tay~ibu Almakosiri [Wood, &c., good in the place of breaking,] i. e. approved. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, rajulN Sulobu Almakosiri (A, L) (tropical:) A man who bears up
against difficulty, distress, or adversity: because one breaks a piece of wood, to try if it be hard or soft. (TA.) And of a pl. number, humo SilaAbu AlmakaAsiri. (A.) And fulaAnN ha$~u Almakosiri, (TA,) and Almukas~ari↓, (TA in art. h$, q. v.,) (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is easy, or compliant, when asked], which is an expression of praise when it means [lit.] that he is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; and of dispraise when it means [lit.] that be is one whose wood is weak.
