(TA.) And fulaAnN Tay~ibu Almakosiri (assumed tropical:) Such a one is praised when tried, proved, or tested: (S, TA:) and radiYo'u Almakosiri [dispraised when tried, &c.]. (TA.) [Wherefore it is said that] makosirN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The internal state; an internal, or intrinsic, quality; the intrinsic, or real, as opposed to the apparent, state, or to the aspect; syn. maxobarN. (K.) ― -b3- Also makosirN The lowest part (A^aSolN K, TA) of anything; and especially of a tree, where the branches are broken off. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence] it is said to be metonymically used as meaning (tropical:) Old property. (TA voce faroEN.) ― -b5- See also kasorN.

makosuwrN *
: see kasiyrN. ― -b2- sawoTN makosuwrN (assumed tropical:) A soft, weak, whip. (TA.)

mukas~arN *
pass. part. n. of 2, q. v. ― -b2- See also makosirN, with which it is made synonymous. ― -b3- (tropical:) A valley whose kusuwr (q. v.) flow with water: (K:) or are made to flow: (Th:) accord. to one relation of a saying in which it occurs, it is mukosarN. (TA.)

fulaAnN mukaAsiriY *
, (S,) or jaAriY mukaAsiriY, (ISd, K,) Such a one is my neighbour; (S;) the kisor (q. v.) of his tent is next the kisor of my tent. (S, ISd, K.)

munokasirN *
has for its pl. makaAsiyru, which is extr.; like masaAHiyqu, pl. of munosaHiqN. (TA in art. sHq.) raA^ayotuhu munokasirFA (tropical:) I saw him in a languid, or languishing state. (A.)

kusoTN *
i. q. qusoTN (K) The wood with which one fumigates; being a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.)

div1.superEntry: ksE ksf ksl ksm ksw See Supplement. k$ See kt and Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 ka$aA^a *
, aor.
ka$aAa
, He ate cucumber. (S.) ― -b2- ka$aA^a, (S, K.) inf. n. ka$o'N, (S,) He ate food: (TA:) or he ate food in the same manner as one eats cucumbers; (AZ, S, K;) chewing with the extreme grinders, or filling the mouth, (xaDomFA,) as in eating cucumbers and the like. (TA.) ― -b3- ka$aA^a and k$~A^↓, He ate flesh-meat: [the latter] only used with reference to flesh-meat. (TA.) ― -b4- ka$aA^a He ate a piece of ka$iYo'. (TA.) [See also 4 and 5.] ― -b5- ka$iy^a mina AlT~aEaAmi, aor.
ka$aAa
, inf. n. ka$o'N and ka$aA='N (K) and, accord. to some, ka$aA^N; (TA;) and tk$~A^↓; (K;) He was, or became, filled with food. (K.) ＝ -A2- ka$aA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. ka$o'N; (S;) and Ak$A^↓; (El-Umawee, S, K:) He roasted meat until it became dry. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- ka$iy^a It (a skin for water &c.) had its inner skin appearing through its outer; (K;) as happens when a skin has been long folded, and has dried and broken in that state. (TA) ― -b3- ka$iy^ato yaduhu His hand chapped; or its skin became rough and corrugated. (K.) ＝ -A3- ka$aA^a He peeled a thing: (Fr, K:) used with reference to a hide. (TA.) ＝ -A4- ka$aA^a wasaTahu He smote and cut his, or its, middle with a sword. (K, TA.) ＝ -A5- ka$aA^a Inivit feminam. (K.)

2 ka$~aAa
see 1.

4 Ak$A^ *
He ate. ka$iYo'. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And see 1.

5 tk$~A^ All~aHoma *
He ate dry meat [see ka$iY'], (S,) and was filled with it. (TA.) See 1. ＝ -A2- tk$~A^ It became peeled. (K.) ― -b2- tk$~A^ AlA^adiymu The hide became peeled: [i. e., its outer layer of skin, or scarf-skin, was shaven, or scraped off]. (S.)

ka$o'N *
inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Roughness and corrugation [or chapping] in the skin of the hand. (TA.)

ka$iy^N *
and ka$iYo'N Filled with food. (K.) ＝ -A2- ka$iYo'N Meat roasted until it becomes dry. (S.)

ku$oA^apN *
A vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss. (K.)

1 ka$aba *
, aor.
ka$uba
, inf. n. ka$obN; and k$~b↓, inf. n. tako$iybN; He ate flesh-meat and the like with vehemence. (K, TA.)

2 ka$~aba
see 1.

ka$uwvN *
(S, K) and ku$uwvN and ka$uwvaY and ka$uwvaA'u (of the fem. gender, Ibn-Buzruj, in TA, voce hinodabN) and A^uko$uwvN but this last is a bad word, (K,) [as also $akuwvaY and $akuwvaA'u,] [A species of cuscuta, or dodder;] a certain plant that clings to the branches of trees, having no root in the earth. (S, K.) [See also Al$~ajarapu Alxabiyvapu, in art. xbv. And see Alfaqodu and sakarN.] ― -b2- A poet says,
huwa Alka$uwvu falaA A^aSolN walaA waraqN
walaA nasiymN walaA Zil~N walaA vamaru
[He is the Kashooth: therefore (he has) no root nor leaves nor fragrance, nor shade nor fruit]. (S.)

1 ka$aHa laHu biAlEadaAwapi *
; and kA$Hhu↓, (S, L, K,) inf. n. mukaA$aHapN and ki$aAHN; (L;) signify the same, (S, K,) He determined, or resolved, upon enmity to him: (L:) was inimical to him, (L, K,) and broke friendship with him: (L:) hated him and was inimical to him: bore a secret enmity to him. (L.) ＝ -A2- ka$aHa He dispersed, (S, K,) and drove away, (S,) a people. (S, K.) ― -b2- ka$aHuwA Eani AlmaA='i, and Ank$HwA↓, They (a people, S) dispersed from the water: (S, K:) they went away from it, and dispersed: (TA:) they went back from it. (T.) ― -b3- ka$aHa He went back; retired. (A.) ＝ -A3- ka$aHahu He pierced, or stabbed, him in the part called ka$oHN. (TA.) ― -b2- ka$aHa; (L;) and k$~H↓, (Kr, L,) inf. n. tako$iyHN; (K;) He cauterized, (K,) or marked with a hot iron, a camel (L) in the part called ka$oHN. (L, K.) ― -b3- ku$iHa, inf. n. ka$oHN, He had a pain in his ka$oHN. (L.) ― -b4- Also, (inf n. as above, S,) He was cauterized for the disease called ka$aHN. (S, L, K.)

2 ka$~aHa
see 1.

3 kaAo$aHa
see 1.

7 A_inoka$aHa
see 1.

ka$oHN *
The Ha$aY [i. e. the flank; or part between the false ribs and the hip; also explained in the TA by the word xaASirap]: (L:) or the part between the hypochondre and the false ribs, (S, L, K,) and from near the navel to the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone: (L:) the part against which the sword hangs when a man is wearing it; and the part corresponding thereto on the other side: (T:) or each of the two sides of the belly, externally and internally, [or behind and before]; and so in a horse: (M:) or the waist: [see a verse of Imra-el-Keys cited voce mu*al~alN:] or the part from the top, or projecting portion, of the haunch-bone to the armpit: (L:) pl. ku$uwHN. (A.) ＝ -A2- TawaY ka$oHFA He determined upon a thing, or affair, and persevered in his determination. (T.) [See an ex. voce A^ab~a.] ― -b2- TawaY ka$oHahu EalaY AlA^amori He determined, or resolved, upon the thing, or affair, in his mind, syn. A^aDomarahu: (S, A, K:) and hid it, or concealed it: (S, K:) or, accord. to the L, and
other lexicons, he persevered in the thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b3- TawaY ka$oHahu He went away, and cut the ties of kindred. (L.) ― -b4- TawaY ka$oHahu Ean~iY He cut me, or cut the tie of friendship that united him to me, and broke off from me, abandoned me, or discarded me, (S, L, K,) and became inimical to me: (L:) he turned away from me. (L.) ― -b5- ka$oHN Either side of a wi$aAH; from which the k$H of the body is said to have its name, because the former hangs against the latter: (L:) or a wi$aAH [altogether]; so called because it hangs against the k$H of the body; in like manner as an A_izaAr is called HaqowN: (A:) pl. ku$uwHN (TA.) ＝ -A3- The kind of shells called cowries, or conchæ Veneris; syn. wadaEN: pl. ku$uwHN: (K:) or a wi$aAH made of such shells: A^awo$iHap were made of white shells of that kind. (Aboo-Sa'eed Es-Sukkaree.)

ka$aHN *
A certain disease (which attacks a man, S, K,) in the ka$oH, (meaning the flank, xaASirap, TA,) and for which he is cauterized: (S, L, K:) or the pleurisy, syn. *aAtu Aljanob. (K.)

ku$aAHapN *
, a subst., A determining, or resolving, upon enmity to another: hating enmity: secret enmity: estrangement of oneself from another. (L.)

ki$aAHN *
A mark made by burning with a hot iron in the part called k$H. (S, K.)

kaA$iHN *
One who determines, or resolves, upon enmity (yuDomiruhu) to another: (S, L, K:) a hating enemy: (L:) a secret enemy: as though he folded up enmity in his ka$oH; or as though he turned his ka$oH towards thee, and his face from thee; (ISd, L;) or because he conceals enmity in his ka$oH, in which is his liver, which is the seat of enmity and hatred; wherefore an enemy is called A^asowadu Alkabidi, as though enmity had burned his liver: (L:) or, accord. to some, one who estranges himself from another. (Msb.)

mako$uwHN *
A man cauterized for the disease called ka$aHN: (S, L, K:) a man cauterized with the mark called ki$aAHN, below the ribs. (L.) ― -b2- A man smitten with a sword in his ka$oH. (K.)
See Supplement

1 ka$ara Eano A^asonaAnihi *
, (M, A, K,) aor.
ka$ira
, inf. n. ka$orN; (M, K;) [and tk$~r↓, alone; (occurring in the S, K, voce kalaHa;)] He displayed his teeth, or grinned, (M, A, K,) in laughter, and otherwise. (M, K.) You say also ka$ara Eano naAbihi He (a camel) displayed his tusk: (S:) and he (a beast of prey) snarled by reason of irritation. (TA.) And ka$ara Eano A^anoyaAbihi He (an enemy, and a beast of prey,) displayed his dog-teeth, or tusks. (A.) And A_iko$iro Eano A^anoyaAbika (tropical:) Threaten thou. (A.) ― -b2- Also ka$ara, inf. n. as above, He smiled, or laughed a little without any sound, so as to display his teeth: (ISk, S, K: *) or he displayed his teeth in smiling. (TA.) And ka$ara A_ilayohi He smiled to him, displaying his teeth. (A.) ― -b3- And ka$ara fulaAnN lifulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one behaved ferociously to such a one, or became changed towards him, and threatened him. (TA.)

3 kA$rhu *
, (A, K,) inf. n. mukaA$arapN, (A,) He displayed his teeth to him, or grinned to him: (K:) or he laughed in his face; and conversed, or acted with him without shyness or aversion, boldly, or in a free and easy, or cheerful, manner (wabaAsaTahu). (TA.)

5 taka$~ara
see 1.

ki$orapN *
[The act of displaying the teeth, or grinning, to another: or laughing in the face of another, and looking at him in an open or a cheerful manner:] a subst. from kaA$ara, (K, TA,) like hijorapN from haAjara, and Ei$orapN from EaA$ara. (Az, TA.)

1 ka$aTa *
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ka$iTa
, (Msb, MS,) inf. n. ka$oTN, (Msb, K,) He removed, put off, took off, or stripped off, (S, Msb, K,) a thing (Msb, K) from (Eano) a thing which it covered; (K;) as, for instance, the housing, or covering, (S, K,) from a horse, (K,) or from the back of a horse; (S;) and the cover from a thing; (S;) and the skin from a slaughtered camel: (TA:) and qa$aTa is a dial. var. thereof; (Yaakoob, S;) the former being of the dial. of Kureysh, (Yaakoob, accord. to the TA,) or of Keys, (M in art. q$T,) and the latter of the dial. of Temeem and Asad; the k not being a substitute for the q: (Yaakoob, TA:) and Astk$T↓ signifies the same. (Ham., p. 693.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxxi. 11,] waA_i*aA Als~amaA='u ku$iTato And when the heaven shall be removed from its place, like as a roof is removed from its place; (Zj, K;) and in like manner qu$iTatN, (Zj, S, *) accord. to the reading of 'Abd-Allah [Ibn-Mes'ood]: (S:) or shall be pulled off and folded together. (Fr.) And you say also, ka$aTa AlHarofa He removed the letter from its place. (TA.) And ku$iTa rawoEuhu, (TA,) inf. n. ki$aATN, (K, * TA,) (tropical:) His fright, or fear, became removed; (K, * TA;) and so Ank$T↓ rwEh: (TA:) or the latter signifies (tropical:) his fright, or fear, went away. (S, K, TA.) And ka$aTa Ald~aAb~aha and qa$aTahaA [He removed the housing, or covering, from the beast of carriage]. (TA in art. q$T.) And ka$aTotu AlbaEiyra, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, Msb,) I skinned the camel: (S, Msb:) you should not say salaxotu; for the Arabs, in speaking of a camel, say only ka$aTotuhu and jal~adotuhu. (S.)

5 tk$~T Als~aHaAbu fiY Als~amaA='i *
The clouds became dissundered and dispersed in the sky. (TA.)

7 Ank$T Alt~uraAbu *
[The dust became removed, or cleared away, by the wind]. (T, TA in art. jwl.) See also 1.

10 A_isotako$aTa
see 1.

ku$oTN *
i. q. qusoTN. (AA in TA art. qsT.)

ki$aATN *
: see ku$iTa. ＝ -A2- The stripped skin of a slaughtered camel. (Lth, K.) Sometimes the latter is covered over with it; and one says, A_irofaEo EanohaA ki$aATahaA liA^anoZura A_ilaY laHomihaA [Take thou off from it its stripped skin, that I may look at its flesh.] (Lth, K. *)

ka$~aATN *
: see what next follows.

kaA$iTN *
A slaughterer [or skinner] of camels; as also ka$~aATN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [its pls.] ka$aTapN (Lth, K,) and kaA$iTuwna (M, TA) The owners of a skinned camel. (Lth, M, K.)

jazuwrN mako$uwTapN *
[A skinned slaughtered camel]. (K.)
See Supplement

1 kaZ~ahu *
, (S, K,) aor.
kaZu3a
, inf. n. kaZ~N, (S,) It (food, S, K, and in like manner drink, TA) affected him with kiZ~ap, q. v.; (S,) filled him so that he could not breathe: (K:) filled him, and made him heavy. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, made him sad, or sorrowful, by reason of much eating; inf. n. kaZ~apN. (Lth.) ― -b3- He filled it (namely a skin for water or milk) so as to make it stretch. (TA.) ― -b4- [And hence, app.,] He made it (namely a rope) firm, or fast. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b5- kaZ~a AlgayoZu Sadorahu [in the TA kaZ~ah, which is evidently a mistranscription,] (assumed tropical:) Wrath, or rage, filled his bosom: and AlgayoZu A_ikotaZ~ahu↓ signifies the same as kaZ~ahu (assumed tropical:) [wrath, or rage, filled him]. (TA.) ― -b6- kaZ~ahu AlA^amoru, (S, K,) aor.
kaZu3a
, inf. n. kaZ~N (TA) and kaZaAZN and kaZaAZapN, (K,) (tropical:) The affair, or case, oppressed him with grief; (S, K, TA;) distressed him; (K, TA;) filled him with grief,
or disquietude, or anxiety, and burdened him. (TA.) ― -b7- kaZ~a xaSomahu (assumed tropical:) He bridled his adversary so that he found no way of escape. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8.

3 kaAZ~a Alqawomu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA *
, inf. n. mukaAZ~apN and kiZaAZN, (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, straitened one another, or crowded together, and clave together, in the place of fight, in war; as also tkAZ~wA↓. (TA.) kiZaAZN signifies [likewise] (assumed tropical:) Long cleaving, or holding fast, (K, TA,) notwithstanding difficulty: (TA:) and vehement striving for the mastery in war or fight; as also mukaAZ~apN: (S, K:) and the latter, [or both,] (assumed tropical:) the exceeding the ordinary bounds in enmity; as also takaAZ~N↓. (TA.) You say, bayonahomo kiZaAZN (assumed tropical:) [Between them is vehement striving for the mastery in fight]. (S.) And it is said in a prov., layosa A^axuw AlkiZaAZi mano yasoA^amuhu (assumed tropical:) [He who is fitted for vehement striving for the mastery is not he who turns away from it with disgust]: meaning kaAZ~ihimo maA kaAZ~uwka (assumed tropical:) [Strive thou vehemently for the mastery with them as long as they so strive with thee]; i. e. do not thou turn away from them with disgust unless they so turn away from thee. (TA.) [Meyd relates it thus: A^axuw AlkiZaAZi mano laA yasoA^amuhu (assumed tropical:) He who is fitted for vehement striving for the mastery is he who does not turn away from it with disgust.] You say also, Alqawomu takaAZ~a↓ (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, exceeded the ordinary bounds in enmity. (S.) See also kiZaAZN below.

6 takaAoZa3a
see 3, in three places.

8 AktZ~ *
He became filled by food so that he could not breathe, (K,) and in like manner by drink. (TA.) It is also said of the belly. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a water-course) became straitened by the abundance of its flow of water; (S;) as also kaZ~a↓, [aor., accord. to general rule,
kaZi3a
;] (TA;) and so AktZ~ biAlmaA='i: (K:) and AktZ~ bivajiyji AlmaA='i (tropical:) it (a valley) became filled by the rain and torrent. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1 and 2.] ― -b3- AktZ~ Alqawomu fiY Almasojidi (assumed tropical:) The people straitened, or crowded, one another in the mosque. (TA.) ― -b4- AktZ~hu AlgayoZu: see 1.

R. Q. 1 kaZokaZa *
, inf. n. kaZokaZapN, It (a skin for water or milk) stretched when being filled: (Lth, K:) was seen to become even [more and more] as often as water was poured into it. (O, K.) [See also 8, and R. Q. 2.]

R. Q. 2 takaZokaZa *
He erected himself, sitting, as often as he filled his belly, (Lth, K,) becoming filled so that he could not breathe, (K,) after being seen to be in a bending posture, (Lth,) while eating. (K.) ― -b2- It (a skin for water or milk) became filled, or full. (TA.) [See also 8, and R. Q. 1.]

kaZ~u *
[originally an inf. n. ― -b2- Used as a simple subst.,] (tropical:) Grief, or disquietude, or anxiety, that fills the bosom: so in the saying of 'Omar Ibn- 'Abd-el-'Azeez, in speaking of death, wakaZ~N layosa kaAlokaZ~i, meaning And grief, &c., that is not like other grief, &c., but more vehement. (TA.) [See also ganoZN.] ＝ -A2- It is also used as an epithet: you say rajulN kaZ~N (tropical:) A man whom affairs oppress, or distress, and overcome, so that he is unable to perform them. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. *) ― -b2- And rajulN laZ~N kaZ~N (assumed tropical:) A man, hard, or difficult, in disposition. (S, L: in some copies of the former, kaZ~N laZ~N.) ISd thinks that kZ~ is here an imitative sequent. (TA in art. lZ, q. v.)

kiZ~apN *
Repletion, or the state of being much filled, with food or drink: (M, Mgh, * K:) and a thing that befalls (S, A, K) a man, (S,) or an animal, (A,) in consequence of impletion [or repletion] with food: (S, A, K:) pl. A^akiZ~apN. (TA.) Hence the trad. of En-Nakha'ee, AlA^akiZ~apu EalaY AlA^akiZ~api masomanapN makosalapN masoqamapN [Repletions upon repletions are causes of fattening, rendering heavy or lazy, diseasing]. (TA.)

kiZaAZN *
: see 3, of which it is an inf. n. ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Difficulty, or distress, and fatigue, (K, TA,) in an affair, such as takes away the breath. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Grief, or disquietude, or anxiety, occasioned by war, filling the heart. (L.)

kaZiyZN *
A man replete with food. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A skin for water or milk filled so as to be made to stretch; as also makoZuwZN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man oppressed, or distressed [and overcome, (see kaZ~N,)] by affairs, so as to be unable to perform them; as also makoZuwZN↓ and mukaZ~aZN↓: (K:) or all these signify (tropical:) grieved, and full of heaviness. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Angry, or enraged, in the most vehement degree. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A state of fulness, or impletion. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A mutual straitening, or crowding together. (TA.) You say, EalaY baAbi fulaAnK kaZiyZN (tropical:) At the door of such a one is a crowding together. (Har, p. 341.)

h`*aA AlT~aEaAmu makaZ~apN *
This food is a cause of indigestion, and heaviness of the stomach. (TA.)

mukaZ~aZN *
: see kaZiyZN; the latter in two places.

makoZuwZN *
: see kaZiyZN; the latter in two places.

1 kaZaba *
, aor.
kaZuba
, inf. n. kuZuwbN, He became full of fat: (IAar, K:) like HaZaba. (TA.)

1 kaZara Alqawosa *
, (K,) aor.
kaZura
, (TK,) inf. n. kaZorN, (TA,) He made to the bow a kuZor, or notch to receive the ring of the string. (K.) ― -b2- kaZara Alz~anodapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He cut in the [piece of wood called] zndp a notch [from which to produce fire]. (K.)

kuZoru Alqawosi *
The notch in the curved extremity of the bow, in which is the string; (As, S;) the notch of the bow, into which falls the ring of the string: (A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akoZaArN (A) and [of mult.] kiZaArN and kiZaArapN. (TA.) ― -b2- kuZoru Alz~anodapi The notch [from which the fire is produced] in the [piece of wood called] zndp. You say Aln~aAru tasiylu mino kuZori Alz~anodapi Fire flows from the notch of the zndp. (A.)

kiZorN *
The piece of sinew which is tied upon the base of the notch of an arrow. (IDrd, K.)
See Supplement

kaEaba Alv~adoYu *
, aor.
kaEiba
and
kaEuba
, (it seems to be implied in one place in the K, that the aor. is
kaEaba
; but this is not the case; TA,) inf. n. kuEuwbN and kiEaAbapN (by MF written kaEaAbapN) and kuEuwbapN; and kE~b↓, inf. n. takoEiybN; The girl's breast swelled, or became prominent or protuberant, (K,) and round: (TA:) [or began to swell, &c.: see kaAEibN]: or they use the term tafoliykN; then nuhuwdN; and then takoEiybN; [as applied to the successive stages of growth of the breast]. (TA.) kaEabati AljaAriyapu, aor.
kaEuba
, (and
kaEiba
, TA,) inf. n. kuEuwbN; and kE~bt↓; [and tkE~bt↓; (A, TA in art. Ej;)] The girl had breasts beginning to swell, or become prominent, or protuberant: (IAth, S:) [or had swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: see kaAEibN]. ＝ -A2- kaEabahu, inf. n. kaEobN, He beat him on a hard, or tough, part; as the head, and the like: (TA:) [and so kE~bh↓: for it is mentioned in the TA, that a certain king was surnamed AlmukaE~ibu from his beating the protuberances of people's heads]. ＝ -A3- kaEaba, aor.
kaEaba
; (K;) and kE~b↓, inf. n. takoEiybN; (TA;) He filled a vessel (K) &c. (TA.)

2 kaE~aba
[kE~b It (a reed, or cane,) put forth, or produced, its jointed stem. ― -b2- Hence the phrase:] A_in~iY A^araY Al$~ar~a kaE~aba [(assumed tropical:) Verily I see the evil to have grown, like reeds when they put forth their jointed stems.] (TA, voce nab~aba.) ― -b3- kE~b lababahaA He put to her breast-band [the pronoun app. referring to daAb~ap “ a beast of carriage ”] edges, or borders, like kuEuwb [app. meaning play-bones, or dice, or similar things.]. (TA.) ― -b4- kE~b, inf. n. takoEiybN, He folded a garment, or piece of cloth, hard, or firmly, accord. to some, in a square form. (TA.) See also mukaE~abN. ― -b5- He made it square, (K,) [or rather of a cubic form]. ― -b6- And see 1 in four places.

4 AkEb *
, inf. n. A_ikoEaAbN, He hastened: (K:) or he went away, paying no regard to anything: (TA:) or, inf. n. kaEaAbN, he went away injuriously (muDaAr~FA [an act. part. n.]) not caring for what was behind him, [or for the people whom he left behind him]: like kal~ala. (Aboo-Sa'eed.)

kaEobN *
Any joint, juncture, or place of division, of the bones. (K.) ― -b2- Also, [and more commonly, The ankle-bone, or talus;] in a man, what projects above the tarsus, where the foot is set on; (TA;) what projects above the foot; (K;) the bone that projects at the place of junction of the shank and the foot; (AA, As, S, Msb;) each foot has two bones thus termed; one on the right and the other on the left; (Msb;) each of the two bones that project on either side of the foot; (K, TA:) or the anklejoint, or tarsal-joint; the joint that is between the shank and the foot: (IAar, &c., Msb:) As rejected the saying of the [common] people, that it is in the upper part (Zahor) of the foot: (S:) some persons say, that it is each of the two bones that are in the upper part (Zahor) of the foot: so say the Shee'ah: and in like manner Yahyà Ibn-El-Hárith speaks of the kiEaAb as in the middle of the foot: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akoEubN and [of mult.] kuEuwbN and kiEaAbN. (K.) ― -b3- jaAriyapN daromaA'u AlkuEuwbi A girl the heads of whose bones are not big [or prominent]. ― -b4- Also employed with reference to any quadruped; meaning, in a horse, What is between each waZiyf and saAq: or between the bone of the wZyf and the bone of the sAq; which projects backwards: [by this is meant, not the fetlock-joint, or hind fetlock-joint, but the hock: for it has been shown, voce Euroquwb, that the term kaEob, with reference to quadrupeds, is sometimes applied to what anatomists term the tarsus]. (TA.) ― -b5- kaEobN and kaEobapN↓ [An ossicle] with which one plays; [a play-bone; a cockal-bone; the superior bone of the tarsus, called by anatomists astragalus or as tali, a little bone, somewhat oblong, taken from the foot of a sheep, or the like, thrown in play, like a die:] (Lh, K:) the die (faS~) that is used in the game of tables, or backgammon, (Aln~arod); (TA;) [any die that is used in play]: pl. (of the former word, TA) kiEaAbN and (of the latter, TA,) kuEobN and kaEabaAtN. (K: the last so written accord. to the TA; but in the CK kaEobaAtN.) The playing with the kEb is forbidden (Kur v. 92]. (TA.) ― -b6- A conventional term of arithmeticians [a cube]. (K.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A piece of clarified butter; (S;) such [a lump, or compact piece] as is termed kutolap, thereof: (K:) and [a lump] of dates [compacted together]: (M, voce fidorapN:) a piece of clarified butter, or of fat or grease. (TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) What is termed a Sum~ap (or what is poured out at once, or what remains in a vessel, &c., or a small quantity,) of milk, (K,) or of clarified butter. (TA.) ― -b9- (tropical:) [A knot, or joint, of a reed or cane;] what is between each two internodal portions of a reed or cane; (K;) the prominent part that is at the extremity of each of the internodal portions of a spear [of reed or cane]: (S:) or an internodal portion, or portion that is between each two knots, or joints, of a reed or cane: (Msb:) pl. kuEuwbN and kiEaAbN. (TA.) ― -b10- By SArwA kEAbA, in the following verse,
raA^ayotu Al$~aEoba mino kaEobK wakaAnuwA
mina Al$~anoaA=ni qado SaAruwA kiEaAbaA
the poet means, they were divided and opposed in mind or opinion, so that each portion that was of one mind, or opinion, became a party by itself. (AAF.) [He seems to compare them to play-bones thrown on the ground; or to the several joints, or knots, of a reed, or cane; or to a spear not equal, or uniform, in the joints, or knots, of its cane-shaft.] ― -b11- rumoHN bikaEobK waAHidK A spear with equal, or uniform, knots, or joints; not having one knot, or joint, thicker than another. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Eminence, or nobility, and glory. (K.) ― -b2- rajulN EaAliY AlkaEobi A man eminent, or noble, and successful in his enterprises. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aEolaY All~`hu kaEobahu May God exalt his glory! (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- laA yazaAlu kaEobuka EaAlyFA May thy glory not cease to be exalted! See EaAlK, in art. Elw. (TA.) ― -b5- EalaA kaEobuka biY Thy nobility, or glory, hath exalted me. (TA.) ― -b6- This signification is taken from the kaEob of a cane: and kaEobN is applied to Anything elevated. (IAth.)

kuEobN *
A girl's or woman's, breast, (K,) that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant. (TA.) See also kaAEibN.

kaEobapN *
see kaEobN. ― -b2- Any square [or cubic] house, or chamber, or the like. (K.) ― -b3- A chamber of the kind called gurofap: (K:) thought by ISd to be so called because of its square [or cubic] form. (TA.) ― -b4- AlkaEobapu The Sacred House; [the square, or cubic, building, in the centre of the Temple of Mekkeh]: (S, K:) said to be so called because of its square [or cubic] form: (S:) or because of its height and its square form: also called kaEobapu Albayoti [The Kaabeh of the House (of God)]. (TA.) ― -b5- AlkaEabaAtu, (K,) or *uw AlkaEabaAti, (S, K,) A house [or temple] belonging to the tribe of Rabee'ah, who used to compass it, or perform circuits round it, [as is done round the Kaabeh of Mekkeh]. (S, K: in one copy of the S, written *uw AlkaEabayoni.)

kuEobapN *
A girl's virginity, or maidenhead: (K:) [the virgineal membrane: as shown by a verse cited in the TA].

kuEokub~N *
: see kuEokub~apN.

kuEokub~apN *
A nuwnap of hair: this is made by a woman's disposing her hair in four plaits, and inserting them, one in another; thus they (i. e. the plaits, TA) become [what are termed] kuEokub~N↓ [a coll. gen. n., of which kEkb~p is the n. un.]. (K.) ― -b2- Also, and kuEokubiy~apN, A certain mode of combing, or dressing, the hair. (K.) ― -b3- [These words are inserted in this art. in the K: but I think that they should be in a separate art., as quadriliteral-radical words; being of the same class as simosaArN &c.]

jaAriyapN kaEaAbN *
A virgin. (TA.) See kaAEibN.

jaAriyapN kaAEibN *
, (this is the most common of the epithets here mentioned, TA,) and kaEaAbN↓, (S, K,) and mukaE~ibN↓, (K,) and kaAEibapN, (KL,) and, as written by some, mukaE~ibapN↓, (TA,) A girl whose breasts are beginning to swell, or become prominent, or protuberant: (IAth, S:) or having swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: see 1: (K, TA:) pl. of the first kawaAEibu and [of the first or second] kiEaAbN; the latter mentioned by Th; the former occurring in the Kur lxxviii. 33. (TA.) ― -b2- vadoYN kaAEibN. and mukaE~ibN↓, and mukaE~abN↓, (in some copies of the K, mukoEabN, in either case extr., the forms being those of pass. part. ns., and the signification that of an act. part. n.,]) and mutakaE~ibN↓, A girl's breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant: (K:) [or beginning to swell, &c,: see 1, and see also kuEobN].

mukaE~abN *
see kaAEibN. ― -b2- A burod, (S, K,) and a garment, or piece of cloth, variegated, or figured, (S, K,) with squares. (Lh, S.) Some explain it as signifying variegated, or figured, without applying it particularly to a garment, or piece of cloth, or to a brd. (TA.) ― -b3- A garment, or piece of cloth, folded hard or firmly, (S, K,) accord. to some, in a square form. (TA.) ― -b4- wajodN mukaE~ibN A hard and projecting face. (TA.) ― -b5- mukaE~abapN The kind of basket called dawoHal~apN (K) and $awogarapN and wa$axapN. (TA.)

mukaE~ibN *
: see kaAEibN and 1.

mutakaE~ibN *
: see kaAEibN.
See Supplement

4 AkEt *
, (inf. n. A_ikoEaAtN, TA,) He went away quickly. (TS, K.) ＝ -A2- He sat down. (TS, K.) ＝ -A3- He mounted [his beast] swollen with anger. (TS, K.)

kaEotN *
Short: fem. with p (S, K:) an epithet applied to a man, and, with p, to a woman. (AZ, S.)

kuEotapN *
The cover of a glass bottle. (K.) So in the scholia in certain of the copies of the S, relied upon for accuracy. (TS, L.)

kuEayotN *
The [bird called] bulobulN: (S, K:) a small bird (EuSofuwrN) called by the people of ElMedeeneh nugarN: (IAth:) pl. kiEotaAnN. (S, K.)

Q. 2 takaEovabati AlEaraArapu *
The ErArp (with an unpointed E meftoohah, the name of a certain plant; (TA;) in the CK, giraArap, or sack;) became collected together, and round. (K.)

rakabN kaEovabN *
(as also kavoEabN, TA) A large (and full and prominent, TA) pubes, (S, K,) or pudendum: (TA:) a prominent, compact, pubes. (Fr.) Pudendum muliebre. (ISk.) ― -b2- kaEovabN (as also kavoEabN, TA) A woman having a large (and full and prominent, TA) pubes, (K,) or pudendum. (TA.)

kaEodabN *
and kaEodabapN A base, unmanly, person. (K.)

kuEodubapN *
Bubbles that float upon the surface of water; (K;) resulting from rain: (TA:) a bubble floating upon the surface of water &c. (TA): or a spider's web: (AA:) ― -b2- Also, Stones. (TA.) ― -b3- All these significations are also assigned to juEodubapN. (TA, art. jEdb, q. v.)
See Supplement

Q. 1 kaEosaba *
He ran (K) vehemently: like kaEoZala: (TA:) and fled: (K:) like kaEosama: (TA:) or he ran slowly: or he walked quickly: or he walked in the manner of a drunken man. (K.)

kuEokubN *
&c.: see art. kEb.
See Supplement

kaEonabN *
Short: (K:) an epithet applied to a man. (Az.) ＝ -A2- AlkaEonabu and AlkuEaAnibu The lion. (K.) ＝ -A3- kaEaAnibu Knobs, or protuberances, (EujarN,) of the head. (K.) kaEonabN A man having knobs, or protuberances, (EujarN,) on his head. (K.)

tayosN mukaEonabu Alqaroni *
A he-goat having the horn curved so as to resemble a ring: (K:) like mu$aEonab, q. v. (TA.)

kaAgadN *
, (Msb, K,) and kaAgidN, (L, TA,) Paper; syn. qiroTaAsN [which seems to be properly paper made of the papyrus]: (K:) a Persian word, (L,) arabicized. (L, K.) The d is sometimes changed into *, (Msb, TA,) and into T. (TA.)

[
kaAgaidiY~N *
A maker, or seller, of paper.]

kaAga*N *
i. q. kaAgadN. (L, K.)

1 kafaA^a *
He turned a thing over; as a man turns over a cake of bread in his band until it becomes even. yatakaf~aA^u↓ occurs in a trad. respecting the Day of Resurrection, accord. to one relation, for yakofaA^u, in this sense: it is said that the earth will be like a single cake of bread, which God will turn over in his hand, as a man in a journey turns over a cake of bread. (TA.) kafaA^a, (Ks, S, K,) inf. n. kafN'N and kafaA='apN; (TA;) and AkfA^↓, (IAar, S, K,) and AktfA^↓; (S, K;) but the first word is said to be the most chaste; He inverted, or turned upside-down, (S, K,) a vessel &c. (S, TA.) [You say] kufiy^ato jafonatuhu [His bowl was turned upside-down; meaning] (tropical:) He was slain: a phrase similar to huriyqa rifoduhu. (A in art. rfd.) ― -b2- kafaA^a (TA) and AkfA^↓, (Ks, and rejected by As, (TA,) He inclined, or made to turn aside or incline, (S, K,) a bow, in shooting with it, and a vessel, (Ks, S,) &c. (TA.) And kafaA^a (TA) and AkfA^↓, (K,) and AnkfA^↓ (TA) He, or it, inclined: intrans. (K, TA.) ― -b3- kafaA^ahu Eano $aYo, (S, * K, * TA,) inf. n. kafo'N, (S, TA,) He turned him away, or back from a thing; (S, K, TA;) as from a thing that he desired to do, to another thing. (S, TA.) And kafaA^a Eano $aYo'K He turned away, or back, from a thing: intrans. (TA.) [See also 4 and 7.] kafaA^a Alqawumu The people turned away, or back. (K.) [See also 7.] ― -b4- kafaA^a He drove away a man, (K,) or camels. (L.) ― -b5- kafaA^a AlA_ibila He made an assault upon the camels, and took them away. (TA.) ― -b6- kafaA^a He followed, or pursued, another. (K.) ― -b7- kafaA^a Alganamu fiY Al$~iEobi The sheep entered the ravine. (K.) ― -b8- kafaA^a lawonuhu, and lwnh AkfA^↓, and lwnh tkf~A^↓, (TA,) and lwzh AnkfA^↓, (K,) (as also Ankft lwnh, TA,) (tropical:) His, or its, colour changed. (K.)

3 kAfA^hu EalaY $aYo'i *
, inf. n. mukaAfaA^apu and kifaA^'N, He requited, compensated, or recompensed, him for a thing. (S, K.) ― -b2- maA liY bihi qibalN walaA kifaA='N I have not power to requite him. (S.) ― -b3- kAfA^h, (K,) inf. n. mukaAfaA^apN and kifaA='N, (TA,) He was like him; was equal to him; equalled him. (K.) ＝ -A2- kAfA^h He watched him; observed him. (K.) ＝ -A3- kAfA^, (K,) inf. n. mukaAfaA^apN, (TA,) He repelled; turned, or put away; kept away, or off; withstood, or resisted. (K, TA.) ― -b2- kAfA^ bayona faArisayoni birumoHihi He thrust this horseman, and then that, with his spear. (K, TA.) ― -b3- kAfA^ byn AlbaEiyrayoni He stabbed this camel, and then that. (Z.) ＝ -A4- laA mukaAfaA^apa EinodiY fiY ka*aA There is no concealment with me in respect of such a thing; as also lA muHaAjaApa. (TA in art. Hjw.)

4 A^akofaAa
See 1, in four places. ― -b2- AkfA^ fiY sayorihi Eani AlqaSodi, (TA,) or kafaA^a, (K,) He deviated, or turned aside, in his journey, from the object he had in view. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- AkfA^ AlA_ibila kafoA^atayoni He divided the camels into two equal numbers, setting apart the one half for breeding during one year, and the other half for breeding during the next. It was esteemed the best plan, by the Arabs, to leave a she-camel for one year after her breeding, without suffering the stallion to cover her; in like manner as land is left fallow for a year. (S, TA.) ― -b2- The same is also said of sheep &c. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AkfA^h A_ibilahu waganamahu (S, * K, * TA) He assigned to him the profits, (K,) or the profits for a year, (S,) of his camels and his sheep or goats; (K, TA;) i.e., their hair and wool, milk, and young ones. (S, TA.) ＝ -A4- AkfA^t AlA_ibilu Many of the camels had young ones in their wombs. (K.) ＝ -A5- AkfA^ Albayota, (K,) inf. n. A_ikofaA='N, (S,) He made for the tent a kifaA='. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A6- AkfA^, (K,) inf. n. A_ikofaA'N, (TA,) in poetry, accord. to a commentary on the Káfee, He used as the rawiY~ two letters having their places of utterance near to each other; as T with d: [such is the signification of the verb accord. to general usage in the present day:] or, accord. to the Ahkám el-Asás, he changed the rwY~ from r to l, or l to m: or he made a similar change of one letter to another having its place of utterance near to that of the former: or it has another signification, given below, accord. to the same authority: (TA:) or he used different letters in the rhymes; (S, K;) whether letters having their places of utterance near to each other, or the contrary; (TA;) or in some m and in some n and in some d, and in some T, and
in some H, and in some x, &c.; as says AZ; and this is the meaning known to the Arabs: (S:) or he used different vowels in the rwY~: (Fr, S:) or i. q. A^aqowaY: (S, K:) or, accord. to the Ahkám el-Asás, it signifies either as explained above on that authority, (TA,) or he used different final inflections in the rhymes: (K:) or he changed the final vowel in the rhyme; ending one verse with Dam~ap, and another with kasorap, [which are the two vowels that resemble each other]: (TA:) [see a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. gyb:] or he impaired the end of a verse in any way. (K.) Eloquent Arabs explained the meaning of the verb in this last manner to Akh, without defining any particular kind of impairment: but one made it to consist in the use of different letters. (TA.)

5 tkf~A^ *
It (a vessel &c.) was inverted, or turned upside-down. (TA.) See also 1, in two places. ― -b2- tkf~A^ (as also tk~fY, inf. n. takaf~K; but the original word is that with hemzeh;) He inclined forwards, in walking, as a ship inclines in her course. Mohammad is said to have walked in this manner, which is indicative of strength. (TA.) [And so] tkf~A^t She (a woman) moved her body from side to side, in walking, as the tall palm-tree moves from side to side. (S.) [And] She (a ship) inclined forwards in her course. (TA.) [See an ex., voce A^aEoraba, in this sense; or, as implied in the S, in the sense immediately preceding.]

6 takaAfaA= *
They two were like, or equal, each to the other. (S, K.) ― -b2- tatakaAfaA^u dimaAw^uhumo Their blood (i. e., the blood of the Muslims,) shall be equally retaliated, or expiated: (A 'Obeyd, S:) i. e., the noble shall have no advantage over the ignoble in the retaliation or expiation of blood. (A 'Obeyd.)

7 AnkfA^ *
He turned, or was turned, away, or back, from a thing that he desired to do; (S;) [see also 1;] he returned, or went back, or reverted. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) or kafaA^a↓, (K,) It (a party) became routed, defeated, or put to flight. (K, TA.) ― -b3- See 1, in two places.

8 A_ikotafaAa
See 1. ― -b2- AktfA^ A^aholiyhimo waA^amowaAlahumo [He carried off their families and their goods.] (TA, from a trad.; mentioned next after the explanation of kafaA^a AlA_ibila.)

10 AstkfA^h A_ibilahu *
He asked him for a year's produce of his camels; i.e., their young ones in the womb in one year; (S, TA;) or their hair and wool, milk, and young ones, of one year. (TA.) ― -b2- AstkfA^h naxolapF He asked him for a year's produce of a palm-tree. (TA.)

kafo'N *
and kufo'N and kifo'N and kufuw^N see kifaA'N, and for kifo'N see also kafiYo'N.

kafoA^apN *
and kufoA^apN↓ (S, K) The young ones in the wombs of camels, in one year: or those after the dams have not conceived for one year or more: (K:) or a year's produce of camels [&c.]; i. e., their hair and wool, and their milk, as well as their young ones. (AZ, S, K.) You say A^aEoTiniY kfA^pa naAqatika Give me the year's produce, &c., of thy she-camel. (S.) ― -b2- ― -b3- And, both words (tropical:) A year's produce of a palm-tree. (K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A year's produce of a piece of land. (K.) See also 4.

kufoA^apN *
: see kafoA^apN.

kafaA='N *
(K) and kafaA^'apN↓ (S, K) Likeness; equality. (S, K.) ― -b2- kafaA^'N A slight inclination, to one side, of a camel's hump, and the like. This is the slightest of faults in a camel; for when the camel grows fat, his hump becomes erect. (TA.)

kafaA='N *
, originally an inf. n. [of 3], and kufo'N↓ and kufuwo'N [&c., as in the following examples,] Like; equal; a match. (S.) ― -b2- h`*aA kifaAw^uhu, and kafiyoy^atuhu↓, and kafiyw^uhu↓, and kufow^uhu↓, and kafow^uhu↓, and kifow^uhu↓, (in the CK, kafuw^uhu,) and kufuwow^uhu↓, (in the CK, kufuw^uhu,) This is like, or equal to, him or it: (K:) And laA kifaA='a lahu There is no one, or nothing, like, or equal, to him, or it. (S.) ― -b3- Zj says, that the words of the Kur-án, walamo yakuno lahu kufuw^FA A^aHadN (cxii. 4,) may be read in four different ways: kufuw^FA↓ and kufoy^FA↓ and kifoy^FA↓ (in which three ways the word has been read) and kifaA'F (in which last way it has not been read.) Ibn-Ketheer and AA and Ibn-'Ámir and Ks read kufuw^FA: Hamzeh read kufoy^FA; and, in a case of pause, kufaA, without hemzeh. (TA,) ― -b4- Pl. (of kufo'N and kifo'N, and kufuw^N, and perhaps of kafo'N also, MF,) A^akofaA='N and (of all the above forms excepting kifaA='N, MF,) kifaA='N. (K.) ― -b5- kifaA='N As much as is equal to another thing. (L.) ― -b6- AlHamodu lil~hi kifaA='a AlwaAjibi Praise be to God, as much as is incumbent. (K.) ＝ -A2- kifaA='N A curtain (sutorap) extending from the top to the bottom of a tent, at the hinder part: or an oblong piece of staff at the hinder part of the kind of tent called xibaA': or a kisaA=' that is thrown upon a xbA', so as to reach the ground: (K:) or an oblong piece of stuff, or two such pieces well sewed together, attached by the kind of wooden pin called xilaAl to the hinder part of a xbA': (S:) or the hinder part of a tent: pl. A^akofiy^apN. (TA.) See miZal~apN in art. Zl.

kafiYo'u All~awoni *
, and Allwn makofuwo'u↓, (K,) and Allwn makotafiy^u↓, (TA,) (tropical:) Changed in colour: (K:) said of the countenance and of other things: as also mukotafitu Allwn. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, mukofaA^u Alwajohi Changed in countenance. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See kifaA='N. ＝ -A3- kafiYo'N and kifo'N↓ (as in the CK and a MS. copy of the K) or kifiYo'N (as in the TA) The bottom, or interior, or inside, (baTon,) of a valley. (K.)

kufuwo'N *
: see kifaA='N.

kafaA='apN *
: see kafaA='N. ― -b2- In marriage, Equality of the husband and wife in rank, religion, lineage house, &c. (L,)

A^akofaA^u *
, fem. kafoA^aY, A camel whose hump inclines slightly to one side. (TA.) ― -b2- A camel's hump inclining to one side. (ISh.)

mukofiy^u AlZ~aEoni *
The last of the days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi. (TA.) [See Ejwz.]

makofuwo'u All~wn *
: see kafiYo'N.

mukaAfiy^N *
Being like, or equal to: equalling. (S.) ― -b2- Also, in the following words of a trad., kaAna laA yaqobalu Alv~anaA='a A_il~aA min m~ukaAfiy^i, said to signify One of known sincerity in professing himself a Muslim: (IAmb:) or one not transgressing his proper bounds, nor falling short with respect to that [religion] to which God hath exalted him- (Az.) ― -b3- $aAtaAni mukaAfiy^ataAni, (S, K,) and mukaAfaA^ataAni. (K,) as the relaters of trads. say, (S,) in a trad. respecting the Eaqiyqap for a male child, (S, TA,) Two sheep, or goats, of equal age. (S, K.) Some assign to these words meanings slightly differing from the above; as, similar, one to another: also, slaughtered, one immediately after the other: (TA:) or slaughtered, one opposite to the other. (S.)

mukotafiy^u All~wn *
: see kafiYo'N.

1 kafata *
, [aor.
kafita
,] inf. n. kafotN, It (a thing) turned over, lit, back for belly: (K:) or, as in a copy of the L, he turned a thing over, back for belly. (TA.) ― -b2- kafatahu, (K,) or kafatahu Eano wajohihi, (S,) aor.
kafita
, (K,) inf. n. kafotN; and kf~th↓; (TA;) He turned him away, averted him, or diverted him, from his course, or design. (S, K.) (You say) kafatahu Eano HaAjatihi He withheld him, restrained him, or debarred him, from the thing that he wanted. (As.) ― -b3- All~`hu kf~thu↓ God took him; syn. qabaDahu: meaning he died: and so kftp All~`h Alyh. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kafatN, [aor.
kafita
, (S, K) inf. n. kafotN and kifaAtN and kafiytN and kafataAnN, (K,) He, or it, hastened, or was quick, or swift: (S:) it (a bird &c.) hastened, or was quick, or swift, in flying, and running, and contracted itself therein: (K:) it (a solid-hoofed animal) contracted its fore-legs quickly in running: (Az:) the kind of running and flying termed kafataAnN is
like a turning aside, or starting aside, (HayadaAnN) with violence, or vehemence. (TA.) ＝ -A3- kafatahu, [aor.
kafita
,] inf. n. kafotN, He drove him, or urged him on, vehemently. (S.) ― -b2- kafata Al$~aYo'a A_ilayohi, (aor.
kafita
, inf. n. kafotN, S,); and kf~th↓; (but the latter has an intensive signification; S;) He drew the thing together to himself, (S, K,) and contracted it, grasped it, or took it. (K.) [See an ex. of the latter verb in a verse cited voce raAjilapN.] ― -b3- A_ikofituwA SiboyaAnakumo biAll~ayoli (S) Draw together your boys, and confine them in the houses, or tents, at night. (A 'Obeyd.) Said by Mohammad. ― -b4- nuhiynaA A^ano nakofita Alv~iyaAba fiY AlS~alaApi We have been forbidden to draw together the clothes [that are upon us] in prayer: meaning, in the inclination of the body, and in prostration. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- kafata Ald~iroEa biAls~ayofi, aor.
kafita
; and kf~thA↓; which latter has an intensive signification; He hung the coat of mail [i.e. the lower part of it] by means of, or upon, the sword [which he was wearing], and then drew it together to him. Zuheyr says, describing a coat of mail, of which the wearer had hung upon the sword the redundant lower portions, and drawn it together to him,
wa mufaADapK kaA@ln~ahoYi tanosijuhu AlS~abaA
bayoDaA'a kaf~ata faDolahaA bimuhan~adi
[And an ample coat of mail, like the pool which the east wind ripples in transverse directions; white; the redundant lower parts of which he had hung upon the sword of Indian steel, and which he had then drawn together to him.] (TA.)

2 kaf~ata
see 1, in two places.

3 kAfthu *
He contended with him in running, or in a race. (K.) ＝ -A2- maAta kifaAtFA, and mukaAfatapF, He died suddenly. (K.)

7 Ankft *
He turned away, or became averted, or diverted, [Eano wajohihi from his course, or design]. (K.) ― -b2- He returned [En wjhh from his course, or design; and] A_ilaY manozilihi to his abode. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He, or it, became contracted; (K;) and so Astkft↓. (TA in art. skf.) ― -b2- It (a garment) was drawn up, or tucked up, and contracted. (TA.) ― -b3- He was compact in make. (K, TA.) ― -b4- He (a horse) was lean, lank, slender, light of flesh, or lank in the belly. (K.) ＝ -A3- Ankft lawonuhu His, or its, colour changed. (TA, art. kfA^.)

8 Aktft AlmaAla *
He took the whole of the property, (K,) and drew it together to himself. (TA.)

10 A_isotakofata
see 7.

kafotN *
and kafiytN↓ (and kafitN↓, Ks) A man quick or swift, (S, K,) and light, active, or agile, and slender: (K:) so too a horse. (TA.) ― -b2- EadowN kafiytN↓, and kifaAtN↓, [the latter originally an inf. n.] A quick, or swift, running: and so a passing by, or through. (L.) ― -b3- [Hence] kafotN (tropical:) Death. (K.) ＝ -A2- xubozN kafotN Bread without seasoning; without savoury food. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also kifotN.

kifotN *
(S, Z, K, &c.) and kafotN↓ (Fr. K) and kafitN↓ (Z) A small cooking-pot. (S, K, &c.) It is said, in a proverb, kifotN A_ilaY way^iy~apK [A small cooking-pot (put) next to a large one]: i.e. a calamity next to which is another calamity. (S, TA.) Applied to him who oppresses a man, and compels him to do that which is disagreeable to him, and then adds to his oppression of him. (A 'Obeyd.) [See also Freytag, Arab. Prov. ii. 349.] ＝ -A2- See kafiytN.

kafitN *
: see kafotN and kifotN.

farasN kufatN *
, and kufatapN, A horse that leaps, springs, or bounds, with his whole body and limbs, and so that one cannot get possession of him, or obtain the mastery over him. (K.) See also art. klt.

kft *
[written without the syll. points] A certain herb. (See kaf~u Alkalobi, in art. klb.)

kifaAtN *
A place in which a thing is drawn together, or comprehended, (S, K,) and collected, or congregated. (K.) So in the words of the Kur [lxxvii. 25 and 26,] A^alamo najoEali A@loA^aroDa kifaAtFA A^aHoyaA'F waA^amowaAtFA [Have we not made the earth a place which comprehends the living and the dead? meaning kifaAta A^aHoyaA'K waA^amowaAtK:] (S:) EshShaabee, pointing to the houses of El-Koofeh, said, h`*ihi kifaAtu AlA^aHoyaA'$; and then, turning to its tombs, he said, h`dhi kifaAtu AlA^amowaAti; meaning to explain the above text of the Kur: but ISd thinks, that kfAtA in this text is an inf. n., and that AHyA' and AmwAtA are governed by it in the acc. case. (TA.)

kafiytN *
: see kafotN. ― -b2- One who contends with another in running, or in a race. (TA.) kafiytN, as used in the following trad., in which Mohammad says, Hub~ibi A_ilaY~a Aln~isaA'u waAlT~iybu waruziqotu Alkafiyta [Women and perfumes have been made objects of love, or pleasant, to me; and I have been supplied with, or have received, &c.], signifies Food by which the body is sustained; or, sufficient to sustain life: or what sustains life: (TA:) or that by which food necessary for the support of life is drawn, or collected, together, (K,) and properly prepared for use: (TA:) [or the means of acquiring subsistence, &c.:] or coition; [meaning power for coition;] so accord. to El-Hasan: or strength for coition: or certain food that was sent down to Mohammad from heaven, of which he ate, and whereby he received strength for coition: he is related to have said, that Gabriel came to him with a cooking-pot called Alkafiytu, from which he derived the strength of forty men in coition: but Sgh says, in the TS, that the descent of the cookingpot from heaven is not accepted as true by the authors on the traditions. (TA.) ― -b3- See kifotN. ＝ -A2- kafiytN A traveller's provision-bag that does not lose [or suffer to escape] anything (K) of what is put into it: you say jiraAbN kfytN: (TA:) as also kifotN↓. (K.)

Alkaf~aAtu *
The lion. (TS, K.)

mukofitN *
One who wears two coats of mail with a garment between them: (K:) or who wears a long coat of mail, and draws together its skirt by means of hooks, or the like, to loops in its middle part, to disencumber himself of the lower part. (T.)

1 kafaHahu *
, (S, K,) inf. n. kafoHN; (S;) and kaAfaHahu↓, inf. n. mukaAfaHapN and kifaAHN; (K;) [the latter form of the verb the more common;] He faced him; confronted him; encountered him; met him face to face: (S, K, TA:) or he met him, or encountered him, face to face, suddenly, or unexpectedly. (T, M.) [You say] laqiytuhu kifaAHFA↓, (S,) and mukaAfaHapF↓, and kafoHFA, (TA.) I met him face to face. (TA.) [And] kal~amahu A@ll~`hu kifaAHFA↓ God spoke to him face to face, without anything intervening between them. (TA from a trad.) ― -b2- kafaHahaA, (K,) aor.
kafaHa
; (S;) and kaAfaHahaA↓, inf. n. as above; (K;) He kissed her suddenly, unexpectedly, or unawares: (K:) or he met her face to face, or encountered her, with a kiss: (S:) or he kissed her with full ability, and completely, without snatching the kiss: (T:) or he made his skin to meet, and come in contact with hers. (A 'Obeyd.) ― -b3- kaAfaHuwA↓ (in war) signifies They contended together with swords face to face: (L:) or kaAfaHuwhumo↓, they encountered them in war face to face, having before their faces neither shield nor anything else. (As, S.) ― -b4- Also Eanohu kAfH↓ He contended for him, and defended him. (L.) ― -b5- Als~amuwma kaAfaHotu↓ (tropical:) [I faced, or encountered, the hot wind called samuwm]. (A.) ― -b6- bimaA saA='ahu kAfHhu↓ (tropical:) [He encountered him with that which displeased or vexed him]. (A.) ― -b7- kAfHhu↓, inf. n. mukaAfaHapN, (tropical:) He refelled him by an argument, a plea, a proof, or an evidence: as though the argument &c. were likened to a sword, or other weapon. (MF.) ＝ -A2- kafaHa lijaAma Ald~aAb~api, (inf. n. kafoHN, TA,) He drew, or pulled, the bridle and bit of the beast of carriage; as
also A^akofaHahu↓: (K:) or, as in the T and M, kafaHa Ald~aAb~apa biAlil~jaAmi he pulled the beast of carriage by the bridle and bit. (TA.) [See also 4.]

3 kaAofaHa
See 1, throughout. ― -b2- fulaAnN yukaAfiHu AlA^umuwra (tropical:) Such a one superintends, manages, or conducts, affairs himself, or in his own person. (S, A.)

4 AkfH Ald~aAb~apa *
, inf. n. A_ikofaAHN, He put the bit to the mouth of the beast of carriage, striking the mouth with it, in order that the beast might take it into its mouth. (T, S.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 takaf~aHati Als~amaAy^imu *
(tropical:) The hot winds called smAy^m met, or encountered, one another. (L.)

6 takaAfaHuwA *
[They faced, confronted, or encountered, one another; or met face to face]. (A.) ― -b2- takaAfaHati AlkibaA$u [The rams butted one another.] (A.) ― -b3- takaAfaHati AlA^amowaAju (tropical:) The waves met and dashed together.] (A.)

entry.key: A^aSaAbahu mina Als~amuwm lafoHN wamina AlHaruwri kafoHN

superEntry.entry:
A^aSaAbahu mina Als~amuwm lafoHN wamina AlHaruwri kafoHN *
(tropical:) [A burning gust of the hot day-wind smote him, and a blast of the hot night-wind meeting him in the face]. (A.)

kafiyHN *
A husband: (K:) so called because he beholds his wife face to face. (TA.) ― -b2- A bedfellow, syn. DajiyEN, (A, K,) of a woman. (TA.) ― -b3- A guest coming suddenly, or unexpectedly. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Like; or equal; syn. kufo'N, (S, K,) and nadiydN. (TA.)

mukaAfiHN *
(tropical:) One who superintends, manages, or conducts, affairs himself, or in his own person. (TA.) See 3.

1 kafara Al$~aYo'a *
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c,) aor., in the sense first explained below
kafira
, (S, K, &c.;) [respecting which Fei observes,] ElFárábee, whom J follows, says that it is like yaDoribu, but in a trustworthy copy of the T it is written
kafura
, and this is the proper form, because they say that kafara Aln~iEomapa [of which the aor. is
kafura
] is borrowed from kafara Al$~aYo'a in the sense which is first explained below; (Msb;) and MF says, that the saying of J, following his maternal uncle Aboo-Nasr El-Fárábee, that the aor. of this verb is
kafira
, is doubtless a mistake; but to this, [says SM,] I reply, that it is correctly
kafira
, as J and F and other leading lexicologists have said; though the aor. of the verb of kuforN as meaning the contr. of A_iyomaAnN is
kafura
; (TA;) [or, if this latter verb be taken from the former, the aor. of the former may have been originally
kafira
and
kafura
, and general usage may have afterwards applied the aor.
kafira
to one signification, while the aor.
kafura
has been applied by very few persons to that signification, but by all to the significations thence derived;] inf. n. kaforN; (S, Msb;) and kf~rhu↓, (A, Mgh, K,) inf. n. takofiyrN; (TA;) He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, the thing: (S, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K: *) or he covered the thing so as to destroy it: (Az, TA:) and kafara Ealayohi, aor. [and inf. n.] as above, he covered it; covered it over. (K,) You say kafara Alba*ora A@lomabo*uwra He covered the sown seed with earth. (TA.) And kafara Als~aHaAbu Als~amaA='a The clouds covered the sky. (A.) Lebeed says,
fiY layolapK kafara Aln~ujuwma gamaAmuhaA
In a night whereof the clouds that covered the sky concealed the stars. (Msb.) You say also kafarahu All~ayolu, and kafara Ealayohi, The night covered it with its blackness. (TA.) And kafarati Alr~iyHu Alr~asoma The wind covered the trace or mark [with dust.] (A.) And kafara fawoqa diroEihi He clad himself with a garment over his coat of mail. And diroEahu bivawobK kaf~ara↓ He covered his coat of mail with a garment. (TA.) And kafara mataAEahu He put his goods in a receptacle. (TA.) And kafara A@lomataAEa fiY AlwiEaA='i He covered, or concealed, the goods in the receptacle. (A.) And kaf~ara↓ nafosahu biAls~ilaAHi He covered himself with the arms. (A.) And kafara Aljaholu EalaY Eilomi fulaAnK Ignorance covered over the knowledge of such a one. (TA.) wakayofa takofuruwna, [thus, with damm as the vowel of the aor.,] in the Kur, iii. 96, has been explained as signifying And wherefore do ye cover the familiarity and love in which ye were living? (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb, TA,) kafara, (S,) and kafara Aln~iEomapa, and biAln~iEomapi; (Msb;) and kafara niEomapa A@ll~`hi, and biniEomapi A@ll~`hi; (K;) aor.
kafura
, (TA,) inf. n. kuforaAnN. (S, K,) which is the most common form in this case, (El-Basáïr,) and kufuwrN, (S, K,) and kuforN; (El-Basáïr;) He covered, or concealed, (Msb,) and denied, or disacknowledged, the favour or benefit [conferred upon him]; (S, Msb;) he was ungrateful, or unthankful, or behaved ungratefully or unthankfully; contr. of $akara; (S;) and he denied, or disacknowledged, and concealed, or covered, the favour or benefit of God: (K:) God's favours or benefits are the signs which show to those who have discrimination that their Creator is one, without partner, and that He has sent apostles with miraculous signs and revealed scriptures and manifest proofs. (Az, TA.) walaA nakofuruka, in the prayer [termed Alqunuwtu], means walaA nakofuru niEomataka [And we will not deny, or disacknowledge, thy favour; or we will not be ungrateful, or unthankful, for it]. (Msb.) [The verb when used in this sense, seems, from what has been said above, to be a Haqiyqap Eurofiy~ap, or word so much used in a particular tropical sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper.] ― -b3- And hence, kafara, inf. n. kuforaAnN, is used to signify [absolutely] He denied, or disacknowledged. (TA.) [See the act. part. n., below: and see 3. See also art. f, p. 2322 a.] You say kafara biAlS~aAniEi He denied the Creator. (Msb.) ― -b4- Hence also, (TA.) kafara, (S, Msb,) aor.
kafura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. kufurN, (S, Msb, K,) which is the most common form in this case, (El-Basáïr,) and kaforN (K) and kuforaAnN (Msb, K) and kufuwrN, (K,) He disbelieved; he became an unbeliever, or infidel; contr. of A=mana, inf. n. A_iyomaAnN. (S, K.) You say kafara biA@ll~`hi (S, Msb) He disbelieved in God: (S:) because he who does so conceals, or covers, the truth, and the favours of the liberal Dispenser of favours [who is God]. (MF.) [Also, as shown above, He denied God.] It is related in a trad. of 'Abd-El-Melik, that he wrote to El- Hajjáj, mano A^aqar~a biAlkufori faxal~i sabiylahu, meaning, Whosoever confesses the unbelief of him who opposes the Benoo-Marwán, and goes forth against them, let him go his way. (TA.) See also kuforN, below. ― -b5- [He blasphemed: a signification very common in the present day.] ― -b6- Also, kafara bika*aA He declared himself to be clear, or quit, of such a thing. (Msb.) In this sense it is used in the Kur xiv. 27. (Msb, TA.) ― -b7- And kafara also signifies He was remiss, or fell short of his duty, with respect to the law, and neglected the gratitude or thankfulness to God which was incumbent on him. So in the Kur xxx. 43; as is shown by its being opposed to Eamila SaAliHFA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kafara lahu, inf. n. kaforN: see 2.

2 kf~rhu *
, inf. n. takofiyrN: see 1, first signification, in three places. ＝ -A2- Hence, kaf~ara Al*~anoba It (war in the cause of God [or the like]) covered, or concealed, the crime or sin: (Mgh:) (or expiated it: or annulled it; for] tkfyr with respect to acts of disobedience is like A_iHobaATN with respect to reward. (S, K.) The saying in the Kur [v. 70.] lakaf~aronaA Eanohumo say~iy^aAtihimo means, We would cover, or conceal, their sins, so that they should become as though they had not been: or it may mean, We would do away with their sins; as is indicated by another saying in the Kur [xi. 116,] “ good actions do away with sins. ” (El-Basáïr.) kaf~ara A@ll~`hu Eanohu Al*~anoba signifies God effaced his sin. (Msb.) ― -b2- And kaf~ara Eano yamiynihi [He expiated his oath;] he performed, (Msb,) or gave, (K,) what is termed kaf~aArap [i. e. a fast, or alms, for the expiation of his oath]: (Msb, K:) takofiyrN of an oath is the doing what is incumbent, or obligatory, for the violation, or breaking, thereof: (S:) kaf~ara yamiynahu is a vulgar phrase. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- kaf~arahu as syn. with A^akofarahu: see 4. ＝ -A4- kaf~ara lahu, inf. n. takofiyrN, (A, Mgh, TA,) He did
obeisance to him, lowering his head, or bowing, and bending himself, and putting his hand upon his breast: (Mgh:) or put his hand upon his breast and bent himself down to him: (TA:) or he made a sign of humbling himself to him; did obeisance to him: (A:) namely, an Eiloj [or unbeliever of the Persians or other foreigners] (A, Mgh) or a *im~iY~ [or free non- Muslim subject of a Muslim government, i. e., a Christian, a Jew, or a Sabian] (Mgh) to the king; (A, Mgh;) or a slave to his master, or to his dihoqaAn [or chief]: (TA:) and kafara↓, [aor.
kafura
, accord. to the rule of of the K,] (TK,) inf. n. kaforN, (K,) he (a Persian, faArisiY~N, K, and so in the L and other lexicons, but in the TS faAris, without Y, which is probably a mistake of copyists, TA) paid honour to his king, (K, TA,) by making a sing with his head, near to prostration: (TA:) takofiyrN is a man's humbling himself to another, (S, K, TA,) bending himself, and lowering his head, nearly in the manner termed rukuwEN; as one does when he desires to pay honour to his friend; (TA;) or as the Eiloj does to the dihoqaAn: (S:) and the tkfyr of the people of the scriptures [or Christians and Jews, and Sabians] one's lowering his head to his friend, like the tasoliym with the Muslims: or one's putting his hand, or his two hands, upon his breast: (TA:) and tkfyr in prayer is the bending one's self much in the state of standing, before the action termed rukuwEN; the doing of which was disapproved by Mohammad, accord. to a trad. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A_i*aA A^aSobaHa A@bonu A=dama faA_in~a AlA^aEoDaA='a tukaf~iru kul~uhaA lil~isaAni When the son of Adam rises in the morning, verily all the members abase themselves to the tongue, (Mgh, TA,) and confess obedience to it, and humbly submit to its command. (TA.) ― -b2- takofiyrN also signifies The crowning a king with a crown, [because] when he, or it, is seen, obeisance is done to him (A_i*aA ruy^iYa kuf~ira lahu). (K.) ― -b3- See also takofiyrN below.

3 kaAfaraniY Haq~iY *
He denied, or disacknowledged, to me my right, or just claim. (A, Mgh, K.) Hence the saying of 'Ámir, A_i*aA A^aqar~a Einoda AlqaADiY bi$aYo'K vum~a kaAfara [When he confesses a thing in the presence of the Kádee, then denies, or disacknowledges: kaAfara being thus used in the sense of kafara]. But as to the saying of Mohammad [the lawyer], rjulN lahu EalaY A=xara dayonN fakaAfarahu bihi siniyna [A man who owed to another a debt, and denied to him, in the case of it, for years], he seems to have made it imply the meaning of AlmumaATalap, and therefore to have made it trans. in the same manner as AlmmATlp is trans. (Mgh.)

4 Akfrhu *
, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and kf~rhu↓, (A, Mgh, Msb,) [the latter of which is the more common in the present day,] He called him a kaAfir [i. e. a disbeliever, an unbeliever, or an infidel]: (S, Mgh, K:) he attributed, or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, disbelief, or infidelity: (S, A, Msb:) or he said to him kafarota [Thou hast become an unbeliever, or infidel, or Thou hast blasphemed: in this last sense, “ he said to him Thou hast blasphemed, ” kf~rhu, to which alone it is assigned in the Msb, is very commonly used in the present day]. (Msb.) Hence the saying, laA tukofiro A^aHadFA mino A^aholi qibolatika Do not thou attribute or impute disbelief or infidelity to any one of the people of thy kibleh; (S, TA;) i. e., do not thou call any such a disbeliever, &c.; or do not thou make him such by thine assertion and thy saying. (TA.) laA tukaf~iruwA A^ahola qibolatikumo is not authorized by the relation, though it be allowable as a dial. form. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Also] A^akofarotuhu, inf. n. A_ikofaArN, I made him a disbeliever, an unbeliever, or an infidel; I compelled him to become a disbeliever, &c. (Msb.) And A^akofara fulaAnN SaAHibahu Such a one compelled his companion by evil treatment to become disobedient after he had been obedient. (Mgh.) And A^akofara Alr~ajulu muTiyEahu The man compelled him who had obeyed him to disobey him: (T, TA:) or he made him to be under a necessity to disobey him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Akfr He (a man, TA) kept, or confined himself, to the kafor, (K,) i. e. qaroyap [town or village]; (TA;) as also Aktfr↓. (IAar, K.)

5 tkf~r biAls~ilaAHi *
He covered himself with the arms. And tkf~r biAlv~awobi He enveloped himself entirely with the garment. (A.)

8 A_ikotafara
see 4, last signification.

kaforN *
The darkness and blackness of night; [because it conceals things;] as also, sometimes, kiforN↓. (S, K.) [See also kaAfirN.] See a verse cited voce *ukaA='u. ＝ -A2- Earth, or dust; because it conceals what is beneath it. (Lh.) ＝ -A3- [Hence also] A grave, or sepulchre: (S, K:) pl. kufuwrN. (S.) Whence the saying, A^all~hum~a A@gofiro liA^aholi Alkufuwri [O God, pardon the people of the graves]. (S.) ＝ -A4- [And hence, perhaps,] A town, or village; [generally the latter;] syn. qaroyapN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a Syriac word, and mostly used by the people of Syria [and of Egypt]: or, accord. to El-Harbee, land that is far from men, by which no one passes: (TA:) pl. kufuwrN: (S, Msb:) in the present day, it is applied in Egypt to any small qaroyap [or village] by the side of a great qaroyap [or town]: they say Alqaroyapu AlfulaAniy~apu wakaforuhaA [Such a town and its village]: and sometimes one qaroyap has a number of kufuwr. (TA.) Hence the saying of Mo'áwiyeh, A^aholu Alkufuwri humo A^aholu Alqubuwri [The people of the villages are the people of the graves]; meaning, that they are as the dead; they do not see the great towns and the performance of the congregational prayers of Friday: (S, Mgh:) by Alkfwr he meant the villages (AlquraY) remote from the great towns and from the places where the people of science assemble, so that ignorance prevails among their inhabitants, and they are most quickly affected by innovations in religion and by natural desires which cause to err. (Az, TA.) Hence also the trad. (of Aboo-Hureyreh, TA), layuxorijan~akumu A@lr~uwmu minohaA kaforFA kaforFA [The Greeks will assuredly expel you from them, town by town, or village by village]; (S, * TA;) i. e. from the furFY of Syria. (S, TA.) ― -b2- kaforN EalaY kaforK also signifies One upon another; or one part upon another. (TA.)

kuforN *
: see 1. [As a simple subst., Ingratitude, &c. ― -b2- And particularly Denial, or disacknowledgment, of favours or benefits, and especially of those conferred by God: and disbelief, unbelief; infidelity.] It is of four kinds: kuforu A_inokaArK the denial, or disacknowledgment, of God, with the heart and the tongue, having no knowledge of what is told one of the unity of God [&c.]: and kuforu juHuwdK the acknowledgment with the heart without confessing with the tongue: [or the disacknowledgment of God with the tongue while the heart acknowledges Him:] and kuforu AlmuEaAnadapi the knowledge of God with the heart, and confession with the tongue, with refusal to accept [the truth]: and kuforu Aln~ifaAqi the confession with the tongue with disbelief in the heart: all of these are unpardonable: (L, TA:) the greatest kufor is the denial, or disacknowledgment, of the unity [of God], or of the prophetic office [of Mohammad and others], or of the law of God. (El-Basáïr.) [Also, Blasphemy. Its pl., as a simple subst. in all these senses, is said to be kufuwrN.]. Akh says, that kufuwrFA [in the accus. case] in the Kur xvii. 101, [to which may be added v. 91 of the same ch., and xxv. 52,] is pl. of kuforN, like as buruwdN is pl. of burodN. (S.) ＝ -A2- Tar, or pitch, syn. qiyrN; with which ships are smeared; (K;) of which there are three sorts, kuforN and qiyrN and ziftN: kfr is melted, and then ships are smeared with it: [whence, app., its name, from its being a covering:] zft is used for smearing skins for wine, &c. (ISh.)

kiforN *
: see kaforN.

kafarN *
: see kaAfuwrN.

kaforapN *
: see kaAfirN.

kufar~aY *
, and its variations: see kaAfuwrN.

kafuwrN *
: see kAfr.

kaf~aArN *
: see kAfr.

kaf~aArapN *
a subst. from takofiyru Alyamiyni, (S,) or an intensive epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; signifying [An expiation for a sin or crime or a violated oath;] an action, or a quality, which has the effect of effacing a wrong action or sin or crime; (TA;) that which covers, or conceals, sins or crimes; such as the kf~Arp of oaths [violated], and that of [the kind of divorce termed] ZihaAr, and of unintentional homicide; (T, TA;) an expiation (maA kuf~ira bihi), such as an alms-giving, and a fasting, and the like: (K:) pl. kaf~aAraAtN. (T, TA.)

kaAfirN *
A sower: (S, K:) or a tiller of the ground: (Msb:) because he covers over the seed with earth: (S, Msb: *) pl. kuf~aArN. (S, TA.) The pl. is said by some to be thus used in the Kur lvii. 19. (TA.) ― -b2- Dark clouds, or a dark cloud; (K;) because it conceals what is beneath it. (TA.) ― -b3- Night: (K:) or intensely black night; because it conceals everything by its darkness. (S.) ― -b4- The darkness; (K;) because it covers what is beneath it; (TA;) as also kaforapN↓, accord. to the copies of the K; but in the L, kaforN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b5- The sea; (S, A, K;) for the same reason. (TA.) Thaalabeh Ibn- So'eyr El-Mazinee says, (S, TA,) describing a male and a female ostrich and their returning to their eggs at sunset, (TA,)
fata*ak~araA vaqalFA raviydFA baEodamaA
A^aloqato *ukaA='u yamiynahaA fiY kaAfiri
[And they remembered goods placed side by side, after the sun had cast its right side into a sea]; i. e., the sun had begun to set: or the poet may mean [by kAfr] night: (S, TA:) but Sgh says, that the right reading is ta*ak~arato; the pronoun referring to the female ostrich. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, A great river: (S, K:) used in this sense by El-Mutalemmis: (S:) and a great valley. (K.) ― -b7- [A man] staying, or abiding, [in a place,] and hiding himself. (TA.) [See an ex. voce Earo$N.] ― -b8- [A man] wearing arms; covered with arms: (Az, K:) as also mukaf~irN↓ (A, K) and mutakaf~irN↓ (S, A) and mukaf~arN↓: (A:) or this last signifies bound fast in iron; (K, TA;) as though covered and concealed by it: (TA:) pl. of the first, kuf~aArN. (K.) Hence the following, (K,) said by Mohammad during the pilgrimage of valediction, (TA,) laA tarojiEuwA biEodiY kuf~aArFA yaDoribu baEoDukumo riqaAba baEoDK (K) [Do not ye become again, after me, i. e., after my death,] wearers of arms, preparing yourselves for fight, [one party of you smiting the necks of others;] as though he meant thereby to forbid war: (AM, TA:) or [do not ye become unbelievers, after me, &c.; i. e.,] do not ye call people unbelievers, and so become unbelievers [yourselves]. (AM, K, TA.) ― -b9- A coat of mail; (Sgh, K;) because it conceals what is beneath it. (TA.) ― -b10- One who has covered his coat of mail with a garment worn over it. (S.) ― -b11- kaAfiru Ald~uruwEi A garment that is worn over the coat of mail. (A.) ＝ -A2- One who denies, or disacknowledges, the favours or benefits of God: (K:) [ungrateful; unthankful; especially to God:] one who denies, or disacknowledges, the unity [of God], and the prophetic office [of Mohammad and others], and the law of God, altogether, accord. to the common conventional acceptation: a disbeliever; an unbeliever; an infidel; a miscreant; contr. of muw^ominN: (El- Basáïr:) because he conceals the favours of God: (S:) or because his heart is covered; as though it were of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (IDrd, TA:) or because kufor covers his heart altogether: (Lth, TA:) i. e. having a covering to his heart: or because, when God invites him to acknowledge his unity, He invites him to accept his favours; and when he refuses to do so, he covers the favour of God, excluding it from him: (Az, TA:) fem. with p: (S, Msb, K:) pl. masc. kafarapN, (S, Msb, K,) the most common pl. of kAfr in the first of the senses explained above, (El-Basáïr,) and kuf~aArN, (S, Msb, K,) the most common pl. of the same in the last of those senses, as contr. of mw^mn, (El-Basáïr,) and kifaArN (S, K) and kaAfiruwna: (Msb:) and pl. fem. kawaAfiru (S, Msb, K) and kaAfiraAtN: (Msb:) and rajulN kaf~aArN↓, and kafuwrN↓ signify the same as kaAfirN: (K:) or kafuwrN is an intensive epithet, meaning very ungrateful, or unthankful, [&c., especially to God]: so in the Kur xxii. 65, and xliii. 14: and kaf~aArN has a more intensive signification than kafuwrN, [meaning habitually ungrateful, &c.:] os in the Kur A 23: but sometimes it is used in the sense of kafuwrN; as in the Kur xiv. 37: (ElBasáïr:) kafuwrN↓ is fem. as well as masc.; (TA;) and its pl. is kufurN, (K, * TA,) also both masc. and fem.; and it has no unbroken pl. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, simply, Denying, or disacknowledging; a denier, or disacknowledger: followed bybi before the thing denied: pl. kaAfiruwna: (S, TA;) so in the Kur ii. 38, (TA,) and xxviii. 48. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Also, Blaspheming; a blasphemer.] ＝ -A3- See also kaAfuwrN.

kaAfuwrN *
The spathe, or envelope of the TaloE [or spadix], (As, S, K, TA,) or upper covering thereof, (TA,) of a palm-tree; (As, S, K, TA;) the kim~ of a palm-tree: (Mgh, Msb:) as also kufar~aY↓, (S, Mgh, Msb,) with damm to the k and fet-h to the f and teshdeed to the r, (Mgh, Msb,) or kufur~aY, [so in the copies of the K, and so I have found it written in other works, so that both forms appear to be correct,] and kafar~aY and kifir~aY, (K, * TA,) and kaAfirN↓ (AHn, K) and kafarN↓: (K:) so called because it conceals what is within it: (Mgh, Msb:) or, accord. to AA and Fr, the TaloE [by which they probably mean the spathe, for, as is said in the Mgh, it is applied by some to the kim~ (or spathe) before it bursts open]: (S:) [kfr~Y↓ is sometimes masc., though more properly and commonly fem.:] IAar says, I heard Umm-Rabáh say. h`*ihi kfr~Y and h`*aA kf~rY: (TA:) the pl. of kaAfuwrN is kawaAfiyru; and the pl. of kaAfirN is kawaAfiru. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The zamaE of the grape-vine; (K, TA;) i. e., the leaves which cover what is within them of the raceme; likened to the kAfwr of the TlE; (TA;) the kim~ [or calyx] of the grapes, before the blossom comes forth; because they cover the unopened raceme; accord. to IF, as also kufar~aY↓: (Msb:) pl. kawaAfiyru and kawaAfiru, accord. to the K; but it is well known that the former is pl. of kAfwr, and the latter of kAfr. (TA.) ― -b3- And, accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) The envelope [or calyx] of any plant. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Camphor;] a kind of perfume, (S, K,) well known, from certain trees [the laurus camphora of Linn.] in the mountains of the sea of India and China, which afford shadow to many people or creatures, (K,) by reason of its greatness and its many spreading branches, (TA,) which leopards or panthers frequent, and the wood of which is white and easily broken; the kAfwr is found within it, and is of various kinds, in colour red, and becoming white only by taSoEiyd [or sublimation]. (K.) ＝ -A3- Accord. to the M, A mixture of perfume, composed of the spathe (kAfwr) of the spadix of the palm-tree. (TA.) ＝ -A4- A certain spring, or fountain, in paradise. (Fr. K.) So in the Kur [lxxvi. 5,] A_in~a A@loA^aboraAra ya$orabuwna mino kaA^osK kaAna mizaAjuhaA kaAfuwrFA [Verily the pious shall drink a cup of wine whereof the mixture is Káfoor]. (Fr.) IDrd says, that it should be imperfectly decl., because it is a fem. [proper] name, determinate, of more than three letters; but it is made perfectly decl. for the conformity of the ends of the verses: Th says, that it is made perfectly decl. because it is used by way of comparison; and that if it were a [proper] name of the spring, or fountain, it would be imperfectly decl.: Th means, says ISd, whereof the mixture is like kAfwr [or camphor]: and Zj says, that it may mean that the taste of perfume and kAfwr is in it, or that it is mixed with kAfwr. (TA.) ＝ -A5- A certain plant, (Lth, K,) [which I believe to he the same as the camphorata Monspeliensis, see my “ Thousand and One Nights, ” ch. xxviii. note 6,] of sweet odour, (ISd, K,) the flower of which is (Lth, K) white, (Lth,) like the flower of the A^uqoHuwaAn [or camomile]. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A6- IDrd says, I do not think the kAfwr is Arabic, because they sometimes say qafuwrN and qaAfuwrN. (TA.)

A^akofaru *
[More, or most, ungrateful or unthank-
ful, especially to God; or disbelieving or unbelieving]. (TA.)

takofiyrN *
, as a subst., The crown of a king. (ISd, K.)

mukof~arN *
A bird covered with feathers. (A.) See also kaAfirN: and see makofuwrN. ＝ -A2- One who, though beneficent, is regarded, or treated, with ingratitude; (K;) a benefactor whose beneficence is not gratefully acknowledged. (A.)

mukaf~irN *
: see kaAfirN.

ramaAdN makofuwrN *
Ashes upon which the wind has swept the dust so that it has covered them. (S.) See also mukaf~arN.

mutakaf~irN *
: see kaAfirN.
See Supplement

Q. Q. 1
kawokaba, (S, K,) inf. n. kawokabapN (K) It (iron) glistened; was lustrous, or bright. (S, K.) See also mukawokibN.

kawokabN *
i. q. najomN, A star; an asterism; a constellation: as also kawokabapN↓: (S, K:) or Alkwkbp is an appellation given to the planet Venus; and for the rest of the stars, the masc. word kwkb is used: (Az:) but Venus is called also Alkwkb. (MF.) [Pl. kawaAkibu.] ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, kwkb is a quadriliteral-radical word; the w being a radical letter: it is also said to be from wkb, or from kwb; though k is not one of the letters of augmentation; so that here it must be augmentative contrary to rule. (TA.) [But I rather think that it is an arabicized word, from the Hebrew כוֹכָב; and that ignorance of its being so has caused the Arabs to dispute respecting its formation.] ― -b3- *ahabuwA taHota kul~i kawokabK They became dispersed [as though under every tract of heaven]. (AO, S, K.) ― -b4- kawokabN (assumed tropical:) Drops [of dew] that fall upon herbage in the night, (K,) and become like stars. (TA.) ― -b5- The source, or spring, of a well. (K.) ― -b6- Water. (El-Muärrij, K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The lustre, or brightness, or glistening, of iron. (S, K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A sword. (K.) ― -b9- A nail: (K:) [or more probably, (assumed tropical:) its head, as in Golius] ― -b10- kawokabN (AZ, K) and kawokabapN↓ (TA) (assumed tropical:) A whiteness in the eye: (K:) a whiteness in the black part of the eye, whether the sight be gone in consequence thereof, or not. (AZ.) ― -b11- kawokabN A tract, such as is termed xiT~ap, differing in colour from the land in which it lies. (K.) ― -b12- (assumed tropical:) A youth nearly of the age of puberty: (K:) a youth who has attained the period of adolescence, and whose face has become beautiful, is called kawokabN mumotaliy^N (a full star), like as he is called badorN. (TA.) [See $aAdixN, and muTab~ixu.] ― -b13- (assumed tropical:) The chief, lord, or prince, and horseman, or cavalier, of a people. (K.) ― -b14- (assumed tropical:) A man with his arms; an armed man. (K.) ― -b15- (assumed tropical:) What is tall of plants. (K.) ― -b16- A mountain: (K [but Freytag mentions, that in some copies, for jabalN, is read xayolN, horses and horsemen, or a troop of horse:]) or the main part thereof. (TA.) ― -b17- The greater part, chief part, main, gross, mass, or bulk, of a thing: (S, K:) as of herbage, water, an army. (TA.) ― -b18- (tropical:) The flower, or flowers, of a garden, or meadow. (TS, K.) ― -b19- The fuTor [toadstool, or mushroom], a well-known plant: (AHn, K:) I do not mention it, says AHn, from a learned man: but kwkb is [explained by lexicologists only as] the name of a well-known plant, called kwkbu AlA^aroDi: (L:) perhaps a species of the fuTor. (El-Mak- disee, cited by MF.) ＝ -A2- Vehemence of heat: (K:) the greater part of the heat. (TA.) ― -b2- The medicament called Taloq, q. v., [which defends the person who is anointed therewith from the burning of fire]. (K: explained by the words AlT~aloqu mina AlA^adowiyapi: in some copies of the K, mn AlA^awodiyapi. [This is wrong: kawokabu AlA^aroDi means Talc: see TalaqN.]) ＝ -A3- yawomN *uw kawaAkiba A day of difficulties, distresses, or calamities. (K.) ＝ -A4- kawokabN A place of con- finement. (K.)

kawokabapN *
see kawokabN. ＝ -A2- An assembly; a company; a congregated body. (K.) Said by some to be figurative in this sense.

daEawoA daEowapF kawokabiy~apF *
[They uttered an imprecation like that of Kowkebeeyeh]: a proverb. Alkawokabiy~apu was a town the people of which were oppressed by its governor, wherefore they uttered an imprecation against him, and he died immediately after it. (K.)

A^amoEazu mukawokibN *
(assumed tropical:) A hard tract with glistening pebbles: also called DuHFY mukawokibN. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 kalaA^ahu *
, (S, K,) aor.
kalaAa
, inf. n. kalo'N (K) and kilaA='apN (S, K) and kilaA='N (K) [but respecting this last see a verse of Jemeel cited below], He (i. e. God, S) guarded him, or kept him, or kept him safely. (S, K.) ― -b2- A_i*ohabuwA fiY kilaA='api All~`hi Go ye in the safe keeping of God. (S, TA.) ― -b3- In the following verse of Jemeel,
fakuwniY bixayorK fiY kilaA='i wagiboTapK
waA_ino kunoti qado A^azomaEoti SaromiY wabigoDatiY
