[Then be thou in prosperity, in safe keeping (of God), and in happy condition, even if thou have firmly resolved to cut me and to detest me], kilaA='N may be an inf. n.; or it may be pl. of kilaA^'apN; or it may be put for kilaA='apN, the p being elided by a necessary poetical licence. (Abu-l- Hasan.) ― -b4- The verb is also used without hemzeh, thus; kalaAtu, yakoluwkumo; and kalayotu, yakolaAkumo; in the dial. of Kureysh; inf. n. kilaAyapN: as the pass. part. n. of both, makoluw~N is more commonly used than makoliY~N, which is correctly used as the pass. part. n. of kalayotu. (TA.) ― -b5- kalaA^a Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) He acted as a scout (rabiyoy^ap) for the party, or people. (TA.) ― -b6- kalaA^a baSarahu fiY $aYo'K, (K, TA, [in the CK naZarahu,]) or A^akolaA^ahu↓, (S,) He repeatedly turned his eye to a thing; looked at it again and again. (S, K.) ― -b7- kalaA^a Aln~ajoma (tropical:) He watched the star, to see when it would rise. (A.) ＝ -A2- kalaA^a Ald~ayonu, (S, K,) or kaluw^a, inf. n. kuluw'N, act. part. n. kaAliy^N, (A,) The debt, or its payment, was put off, or postponed, or delayed. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- kalaA^a Eumoruhu (tropical:) His life came to an end: (K:) or was long, and was delayed. (A.) ― -b3- kalaA^a [unless this be a mistake for kl~A^↓] He postponed, or delayed, a thing. (TA, art. nasaA^a.) ＝ -A3- kalaA^a, (K,) inf. n. kalo'N, (As,) He beat with a whip. (As, K.) ＝ -A4- kalaA^ati Aln~aAqapu, (S, K,) and AklA^t↓, (S,) The she-camel ate kalaA^, or herbage. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) ＝ -A5- kalaA^ati AlA^aroDu, (K,) and kaliy^at, and AklA^t↓, (S, K,) inf. n. A_kolaA='N, (TA,) and AstklA^t↓, (K,) The land contained, (S,) or abounded with, (K,) kalaA^, or herbage. (S, K.)

2 kl~A^ *
, inf. n. takoliYo'N and takoliy^apN, He brought a ship near to the bank of the river, (K,) and moored it. (TA.) ― -b2- kl~A^ (assumed tropical:) He retained, detained, or confined, a person: (K:) app. from the verb as used with reference to a ship; and therefore tropical. (TA.) ― -b3- kl~A^, (K,) inf. n. takoliYo'N, (TA,) He came to a place, and stopped there. (TA.) ― -b4- kl~A^, inf. n. takoliy^apN, He came to a place sheltered from the wind. (S) ― -b5- kl~A^ He came to a person (K) on an affair. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kl~A^ fiY A^amorK (tropical:) He looked into, or considered attentively, a thing. (K.) See 4. ― -b2- kl~A^fiyhi (tropical:) He regarded him attentively, and was pleased with
him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- kl~A^ fiY AlT~aEaAmi wagayorihi, inf. n. takoliYo'N; (S, * TA;) and AklA^↓, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ikolaA='N; (S;) He paid in advance (A^asolama, K, and A^asolafa, S, K) for corn or other food, &c. (S, K, TA.) [Here the original signification of postponement or delay is involved: for he who pays in advance for a thing grants a delay in the delivery thereof.] IAar cites the following verse:
famano yuHosino A_ilayohimo laA yukal~iay^o
A_ilaY jaAzK bi*aAka walaA kariymi
[So that he who does a good action to them does not pay in advance to one who will recompence for that (action), nor to him who is generous]. (TA.) See 1 and 5.

3 kAlA^ *
, inf. n. mukaAlaA^apN, and kilaA^'N, He watched, or observed. (TA.)

4 A^akolaAa
See 1 in three places. ＝ -A2- AklA^t Eayonuhu (tropical:) His eye was sleepless, or wakeful. (A.) ― -b2- AklA^ Eayonahu, and kl~A^↓, (tropical:) He made his eye sleepless, or wakeful. (A.) ＝ -A3- AklA^ Eumurahu (tropical:) He brought his life to its close. (K.) See 1.

5 tkl~A^ *
; and kl~A^↓, inf. n. takoliYo'N; He bought on credit. [This is the explanation given in the TK, and it appears to be correct. It is also there said, that takal~aA^otuhu signifies A^axa*otuhu nasoyoy^apF, I took it, or bought it, on credit: and kal~aA^otu fiY AlT~aEaAmi, Ax*th bAln~syy^pi, I took, or bought, the food on credit, but the latter I render differently. (See 2, above.) In the K we read AlkaAliy^u wAlkuloA^apu biAlD~am~i Aln~asiyoy^apu wAlEurobuwnu wtakal~aA^otu wkal~aA^otu takoliyoy^FA A^xa*otuhu. IbrD thinks that the last word should be A^x~arotu “ I postponed, or delayed ”: but I rather think that it should be A^axa*otuhaA, meaning A^axa*otu nasiyoy^apF I took, or bought, on credit. in the TA we read, AO says, takal~aA^otu kuloA^apF wkal~aA^otu takoliyoy^FA A_isotanosaA^otu nasiyoy^apa A^aYo A^axa*otuhu waAln~asiyoy^apu Alt~aA^oxiyru waka*`lika A_isotakolaA^otu kuloA^apF: but the words AY Ax*th seem to have been added by SM; for in the S we find, on the authority of AO, takal~aA^otu A^aYo A@sosanosaA^otu nasiyoy^apF waka*`lika A@sotakolaA^otu kuloA^apF biAlD~am~i wahuwa mina Alt~aA^oxiyri: whence it seems, that tkl~A^, (or tkl~A^ kuloA^apF, and kuloA^apF kl~A^↓, see above,) and kulA^apF AlstklA^↓, signify He asked for a delay of the period of the payment of a debt.] See 8.

8 AktlA^ minohu *
(assumed tropical:) He preserved, or guarded, himself from him or it; had a care of, or was cautious of, him or it. (S, K. *) ― -b2- AktlA^t EayonY (assumed tropical:) My eye was wakeful, vigilant, or cautious. (S.) ＝ -A2- AktlA^ kuloA^apF, and tkl~A^hA↓, He received a kuloA^ap [i. e., an earnest, or money paid in advance]. (K.)

10 A_isotakolaAa
see 1 and 5.

kalaA^N *
Fresh herbage; syn. Eu$obN: (S, K:) applied to the Eurowap, nSiY~, and Sil~iyaAn: (Az:) or pasture, or what cattle &c. feed upon: (TA:) or herbage. whether fresh or dry either fresh pasture or fodder: (S, K:) or it comprises the Sil~ayaAn naSiY~, Halamap, $iyH, Earofaj, the various kinds of Eurowap, and what are termed Eu$ob, baqol, and the like: or it is applied to the herbs called bql, and to trees: a gen. n., having no sing.; or its sing. is kalaA='N. (TA.)

kuloA^apN *
: see 5 and kaAly^N.

A^aroDN kaliy^apN *
, (S, K,) and makolaA^opN↓, (K,) and mukoliy^apN↓, (S,) A land containing, (S,) or abounding with, (K,) kalaA^, or herbage. (S, K.) ― -b2- The ↓last is also said to signify A land with the pasture of which its camels have been satiated. (TA.) ― -b3- See a trad. quoted in art. faDolN.

EayonN kaluwo'N *
(tropical:) A strong eye, which sleep does not overcome. (TA.) ― -b2- kaluwo'N AlEayoni (tropical:) A man, or a camel, (male or female,) having a strong eye, which sleep does not overcome: (K:) or, a sleepless, or wakeful, eye. (A.) ― -b3- maroA^apN kaluwo'u All~ayoli (tropical:) [A woman who is sleepless at night]. (TA.) See 4.

kal~aA='N *
and mukal~aA^N↓ A station of ships, (S, K,) near the bank of a river, or near what is called the jud~: (TA:) the former is masc. and fem.; or, accord. to Sb, it is of the measure faE~aAlN; and therefore masc., and perfectly declinable: (S:) so called because it keeps the vessels safe (yakolaw^uhaA) from the wind: but accord. to Th, it is of the measure faEolaA='u; and therefore fem., [and imperfectly declinable; from kal~a;] so called because the wind there becomes slackened: or a place where ships are moored, near the bank of a river: (TA:) or a place sheltered from the wind. (S.) ― -b2- Also, The bank of a river. (S, K.) ― -b3- Dual of kl~A', kal~aA A=ni and kal~aAwaAni: pl. kal~aA^uwwna. (TA.) ― -b4- mano Ear~aDa Ear~aDonaA lahu wamano ma$aY EalaY Alkal~aA='i A^aloqayonaAhu fiY Aln~ahori, (TA,) or qa*afonaAhu fiY Aln~ahori, (K in art. ErD,) or fY AlmaA='i, (TA in that art.) (tropical:) Him who indirectly calumniates we will treat in a similar manner; (meaning, we will inflict upon him a chastisement less than that termed AlHad~;) and him who walks upon the bank of the river (i. e., who openly calumniates, and so, as it were, embarks on the river of the Huduwd, [pl. of Had~N,]) we will cast into that river; meaning, we will inflict upon him the chastisement termed AlHad~. (TA; and K * in art. ErD.)

kaAliy^N *
(S, K) and kuloA^apN↓ (K) i. q. nasiyoy^apN, [app. bearing both of the two significations immediately following, and clearly shown in the S &c. to bear the latter of them: A postponement, or delay, in the time of the payment of a debt, &c. See also nusoA^apN, and kalaA^a. ― -b2- Also, both words, like nasiyoy^apN, A debt of which the payment is deferred by a creditor to a future period.] (S, K.) ― -b3- Ex., nahaY Eani AlkaAliy^i biAlkaAliy^, i. e., Aln~asiyoy^ap bAln~asiyoy^ap, He (Mohammad) forbade [exchanging] a debt to be paid at a future time for a similar debt. (S, TA.) [See the Jámi' es-Sagheer, and Mishkát el-Masábeeh, ii., 21.] What is forbidden by this is, a man's buying a thing on credit for a certain period, and, when the period of payment is come, and he finds not that wherewith to pay the debt, his saying, Sell it to me on credit for a further period, for something additional: whereupon he [thus] sells it to him: (TK:) or, a man's paying money for, wheat, or the like, to be given at a certain period, and, when the period comes, the debtor's saying, I have not wheat; etc.; but sell thou it to me on credit for a certain period. (AObeyd, Msb.) See A^ajalN.] kaAlK is also used for kaAliy^N. (S.) [See an ex. voce naAjizN.] The pl. of the latter is kwaAliy^u. (TA.) ― -b4- Also kuluA^apN↓, Money paid at a period after the purchase, for food. (S.) ― -b5- Also kaAliy^N and kuloA^apN↓, An earnest, or money paid in advance. (K.)

A^akolaA^u *
(tropical:) Longer, or longest; more, or most, protracted. (TA.) ― -b2- balaga All~`hu bika A^akolaA^a AlEumuri (S, A) i. e. (tropical:) [May God cause thee to reach, or attain,] the extreme, or most distant, period of life! (S, TA.)

makolaA^apN *
and mukoliy^apN: see kaliy^apN.

lloEayoni fiyhaA makoluwo'N *
(tropical:) The eye is constantly fixed upon her: [or has in her an object that is watched (by it):] as though watching her because pleased with her. (A.)

mukal~aA^N *
: see kalA~a'N.

1 kaliba *
, aor.
kalaba
, inf. n. kalabN, He (a dog) was seized with madness, in consequence of eating human flesh. (K.) See also kalabN and kalibN. ― -b2- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, He (a man) was seized with madness like that of dogs, in consequence of his having been bitten by a [mad] dog; [was seized with hydrophobia]. (K.) So also a camel. (S, K.) See also kalabN and kalibN. ― -b3- kuliba, like EaniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He lost his reason by the kind of madness termed kalab. (K.) See kalaAbN. ― -b4- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (assumed tropical:) He was angry (K) Ealayohi with him; and thus resembled one afflicted with
the disease called kalab. (TA.) ― -b5- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (assumed tropical:) He was light-witted; weak and stupid, or foolish; ignorant; deficient in intellect: syn. safiha: (K:) and thus resembled one afflicted with the disease called kalab. (TA.) ― -b6- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (assumed tropical:) He thirsted. (K.) From kaliba signifying “ he was seized with the disease of dogs, and died of thirst: ” for the person afflicted with this disease thirsts, and when he sees water, is frightened at it. (TA.) ― -b7- kaliba EalaY $aYo'K, (TA,) inf. n. kalabN, (tropical:) He was eager for, or desired with avidity, a thing. (K, TA.) ― -b8- In like manner, Aln~aAsu EalaY AlA^amori takaAlaba↓ (tropical:) The people were eager for the thing, as though they were dogs. ― -b9- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (tropical:) He ate voraciously, without becoming satiated. (K.) ― -b10- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, He (a person bitten by a mad dog) cried out, [or barked]. (K.) ― -b11- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN; (so accord. to the TA; but accord. to some copies of the K, kalaba;) and Astklb↓; He (a dog) had the habit of eating men. (TA.) ― -b12- kalaba, aor
kaliba
; (K: but in some copies, kaliba, aor.
kalaba
; [which is evidently the right reading;]) and Astklb↓; He (a man in a desert place, TA,) barked, in order that dogs might hear him and bark, and that one might be guided thereby to him [to receive or direct him]. (K.) ― -b13- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN and makolabapN, (assumed tropical:) He performed the office of a pimp. (As, IAar, K.) [This office seems to be thus compared with that which a dog performs, in inviting travellers, by his bark, to enjoy his master's hospitality.] ― -b14- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (assumed tropical:) It (a tree), not having sufficient watering, had rough leaves, without losing their moisture, so that they caught to the garments of those who passed by, thus annoying them like a dog. (ADk, K. *) ― -b15- kaliba (assumed tropical:) It (a tree) became stripped of its leaves, and rugged, or scabrous, so that it caught to men's garments, and annoyed the persons passing by, like a dog. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kalaba AlmazAdapN, aor.
kaluba
, (inf. n. kalobN, TA,) He inserted a strap, thong, or strip of leather, (kalob,) between the two edges of the mzAdp, in sewing them: (S:) or Alkalobu is the action of a woman who sews a skin, when, finding the thong too short, she inserts into the hole a double thong, and puts through it [i. e. through the loop thus formed] the end of the deficient thong, and then makes it to come out [on the other side of the skin, by pulling the loop through]. (IDrd.) See kulobapN. ― -b2- kalabati Als~ayori aor.
kaluba
, inf. n. kalobN, She (a female sewer of skins or the like), finding the thong [with which she was sewing] too short, doubled a thong, through which she put the end of the deficient thong [in order to draw it through]: (TA:) or kalaba Als~ayora, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he sewed the thong, or strip of leather, between two other thongs, or strips. (IAar.) ＝ -A3- kaliba Ealayohi Alqid~u (tropical:) The strap or thong of untanned hide pressed painfully upon him, by his being exposed with it to the sun or air, and its drying. (TA.) kaliba Ealayohi Ald~ahoru, inf. n. kalabN, (tropical:) Fortune pressed severely upon him. (TA, from a trad.) See also kaliybN, and 6. ― -b2- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, (tropical:) It (winter, S, K, cold, &c., S,) became severe, or intense: (S, K:) he (an enemy) pressed hard, or vehemently, upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A4- kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, It (a rope) fell between the cheek and wheel of the pulley. (K.) ＝ -A5- kalabahu, aor.
kaluba
, He struck him with a kul~aAb, or spur. (S, K.)

kl~b *
, inf. n. takoliybN, He trained a dog to hunt: and sometimes, he trained a fahod, or a bird of prey, to take game. (L.) See the act. part. n.

3 kAlbhu *
, inf. n. mukaAlabapN (S, K, TA) and kilaAbN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acted in an evil manner, or injuriously, towards him; or contended against him: (S, K:) he straitened, or distressed, him, (K,) as dogs do, one to another, when set upon each other: (TA:) he acted with open enmity, or hostility, to him: (Msb:) and takaAlubN↓ (inf. n. of 6) is syn. with mukaAlabapN. (S.) ＝ -A2- kaAlabati AlA_ibilu, (inf. n. mukaAlabapN, TA,) The camels fed upon kalaAliyb, i. e., the thorns of trees. (K.) ― -b2- Also sometimes signifying The camels pastured upon dry, or tough, H$ [app. a mistake for xa$~ “ what is very rough ”]. (TA.)

4 A^akolaba *
His camels became affected with the disease called kalabN; (S, K;) i. e., with a madness like that which arises from the dog. (TA.)

6 takaAolaba
See 3 and 1. ― -b2- humo yatakaAlabuwna EalaY ka*aA They leap, or rush, together upon such a thing [in an evil, or injurious, or contentious, manner]. (S.) Alt~akaAlubu is syn. with Alt~awaAvubu: (S, K:) [and so also, accord. to the CK, is Alt~akolAabu, which I suppose to be an intensive inf. n. of kaliba].

8 Aktlb *
He made use of a kulobap, i. e., a thong of leather, &c. in sewing a skin &c. [See kulobap.] (Lh.)

10 A_isotakolaba
see 1 ＝ -A2- and see 10 in art. sEl.

kalobN *
a word of well-known signification, [The dog:] (S:) or any wounding animal of prey: (L, K, &c.:) but whether birds [of prey] are comprised in this term is a point that requires consideration: (Esh-Shiháb El-Khafájee:) and especially applied to the barking animal [or dog]: (K:) or rather, this is its proper signification; and it admits no other: (MF:) sometimes used as an epithet; as in the ex. A_imoraA^apN kalobapN [A woman like a bitch; a woman who is a bitch]: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akolubN and (of mult., TA,) kilaAbN (S, K) and kaliybN, which is a rare [form of] pl., like EabiydN, pl. of EabodN, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] (S,) and (pl. of A^akolubN, S,) A^akaAlibu (S, K) and (pl. of kilaAbN, TA,) kilaAbaAtN (K) and (also pl. of kilaAbN) A^akaAliybu: (Msb:) kilaAbN is also used as a pl. of pauc.; valaAvapu kilaAbK being said for vlAvpN mina AlkilaAbi; or klAb being used in this case for A^akolubK: (Sb:) kaliybN and kaAlibN↓ signify a pack, or collected number, of dogs: (K:) [both are quasi-pl. ns. in my opinion, though the former is called a pl. in the S:] accord. to some, the former, if masc., is a quasipl. n.; and if fem., a pl.: (MF:) the latter is like jaAmilN and baAqirN [which are both quasi-pl. ns.]. (L.) The pl. of kalobapN [the fem.] is kilaAbN and kalabaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- fulaAnN biwaAdiY Alkalobi (tropical:) [Such a one is in the valley of the dog:] said of one whom no one cares for, and who has no place of abode or resort, but is like a dog, which one sees ever going forth into the desert. ― -b3- kaf~a Eanohu kilaAbahu (tropical:) He left reviling him, and injuring or annoying him: [lit., restrained from him his dogs]. (A.) See also kalabN. ― -b4- AlkilaAbu ElY Albaqar i, (S, K,) the first word being in the nom. case as an inchoative, (TA,) and AlkilaAba, (S, K,) put in the acc. case as governed by a verb understood, (TA,) or AlkiraAbu and AlkiraAba; (Kh, S, art. krb, K;) of which readings, that of AlklAb is the one generally adopted; (TA;) or they are two distinct proverbs, each having its proper meaning; (Meyd;) the former signifying, [if we read AlkilaAba,] Send the dogs against the wild oxen: i. e., leave a man and his art: (S, K:) [but accord. to MF, this is the meaning if we read krAb; but if we read klAb, the signification is, as explained above, “ Send the dogs &c., ” and the proverb is applied on the occasion of instigating one set of people against another set, without caring for what may happen to them:] or it alludes to a man's having little care or solicitude for the state, or case, or affair, of his companion. (A 'Obeyd.) If we read AlklAbu, the meaning is The dogs are upon, or against, the wild oxen: and in like manner, if we read AlkrAbu, the meaning is “ The turning over of the soil is the work of the oxen: ” if AlkrAba, “ Leave the turning over of the soil to the oxen. ” (MF, from expositions of the Fs.) ― -b5- [kalobN kalibN seems also to signify A fierce, or furious, dog. See EaqanobaApN.] ― -b6- kalobu Albar~i The dog of the desert; i. e. the wolf. (K, voce *iy^ob.) ― -b7- kalobN is also especially applied to A lion. (K, TA.) ― -b8- The first increase of water in a valley. (Nh, K.) ― -b9- A piece of iron at the head of the
pivot, or axis, of a mill. (K.) ― -b10- A piece of wood by which a wall is propped, or supported. (K.) ― -b11- A certain fish (K) in the form of a dog. (TA.) [kalobu AlbaHori and Alkalobu AlbaHoriY~u are appellations now applied to The shark.] ＝ -A2- kalobN A strap, or thong, cut from an untanned skin, and mukal~abN↓ is A man bound with a kalob, i. e., with a strap, or thong, cut from an untanned skin. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The extremity of a hill of the kind called A^akamap. (K.) ＝ -A4- kalobN (and kul~aAbN↓, TA,) The nail that is in the hilt of a sword, (S, K,) in which is [fixed] the *uw^aAbap [or cord or other ligature by which the hilt is occasionally attached to the guard]: (S:) or a nail in the hilt of a sword, with which is another [nail] called AlEajuwzu: (L:) and (so accord. to the K: but accord. to the TA, the [cord or ligature, itself, which is called the] *w^Abp, of a sword. (K.) ＝ -A5- kalobN A strap, thong, or strip of leather, (or a red A^aHomar [probably a mistake for A=xar, another] strap, &c., K,) which is put between the two edges of a skin (S, K) when it is sewed. (S.) ＝ -A6- kalobu Alfarasi The line, or streak, that is in the middle of the horse's back. (S, K.) ― -b2- A_isotawaY EalaY kalobi farasihi He sat firmly upon the line, or streak, in the middle of his horse's back. (S.) ― -b3- kalobN (S, K) and kal~aAbN↓ (K) An iron at the edge of a camel's saddle of the kind called raHol: (K:) a bent, or crooked, or hooked, iron, by which the traveller hangs, from the saddle (rHl), his travelling-provisions (S,) and his A^adaAwiY. (TA.) See also fahodN. ― -b4- kalobN Anything with which a thing is made firm, or fast, or is bound: syn. kul~umaA wuv~iqa bihi $aYo'N, (as in some copies of the K,) or A^uwviqa (as in others): so called because it holds fast a thing like a dog. (TA.) ― -b5- kalobN i. q. $aEiyrapN [app. meaning the $Eyrp of the handle of a knife &c.]. (S.) ― -b6- lisaAnu Alkalobi A certain plant; (K;) [cynoglossum, or dog's tongue]. ― -b7- kaf~u Alkalobi A certain spreading herb, (K,) which grows in the plain low tracts of Nejd; thus called when it has dried, in which case it is likened to the paw of a dog; but while it continues green, it is called kft. (TA.) ― -b8- A^um~u kalobK A certain small thorny tree, (K,) which grows in rugged ground, and upon the mountains, having yellow leaves, and rough; when it is put in motion, it diffuses a most fetid and foul smell: so called because of its thorns, or because it stinks like a dog when rain falls upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A7- A^um~u kalobapa Fever. (K.) So called because it keeps to a man with much tenacity, like a dog. (TA.) ― -b2- laqiytu minohu A@sota Alkalobapi, a prov.: see AisotN in art. sth. ＝ -A8- Alkalobu AlA^akobaru The constellation of Canis Major: and its principal star, Sirius. (El-Kazweenee &c.) ― -b2- Alkalobu AlA^aSogaru, also called Alklb Almutaqad~imu, The constellation of Canis Minor: and its principal star, Procyon. (El-Kazweenee &c.) ― -b3- Alkalobu [or kalobu Alr~aAEiY] A certain star, over against Ald~alowu (q. v.), [which is] below; in the path of which is a red star, called Alr~aAEiY: (TA:) klb AlrAEY is a name given to a star between the feet, or legs, of Cepheus; and AlrEY, to that which is upon his left foot, or leg; (El-Kazweenee;) [app., from their longitudes, the same two stars to which the above quotation from the TA relates: but the same two names are also given to two other stars.] ― -b4- klb AlrEY is [likewise] a name given to The star which is on, or in, the head of Hercules; [for AlHAwY, an evident mistake in my MS. of El-Kazweenee, I read AljaAviY;] that in the head of Ophiuchus (AlHaw~aA'u) being called AlrAEY. (El-Kazweenee.) ― -b5- [AlkalobaAni, accord. to Freytag, A name of the two stars υ and κ which belong to Taurus: but accord. to my MS. of El-Kazweenee, the two stars that are near together on the ears of Taurus are called AlkuloyataAni.] ― -b6- kilaAbu Al$~itaA'i The stars, or asterisms, of the beginning of winter; namely, Al*~iraAEu and Alm~avorapu and AlT~arofu and Aljabohapu [the 7th, 8th, 9th, and 10th, of the Mansions of the Moon: so called because they set aurorally in the winter: the first so set, about the period of the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 3rd of January: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl]. (TA.)

kalabN *
(S, K) and kulaAbN↓ (Lth) Madness which affects a dog in consequence of eating human flesh. (K.) ― -b2- Also, Madness like that of dogs, which affects a man in consequence of his having been bitten by a [mad] dog: (K:) [a disorder] resembling madness, or diobolical possession: (S:) a disease that befalls a man from the bite of a mad dog, occasioning what resembles madness, or diabolical possession, so that whomsoever he bites, that person also becomes in like manner affected, abstaining from drinking water until he dies of thirst: the Arabs concur in the assertion that its cure is a drop of the blood of a king, mixed with water, and given to the patient to drink. (TA.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, it originates from a disease which befalls the standing corn &c., and which is not removed until the sun rises upon it: if cattle eat of it before that, they die: wherefore Mohammad forbade pasturing by night: but sometimes a camel runs away, and eats of such pasture before sunrise, and dies in consequence: then a dog comes, and eats of its flesh, and becomes mad; and if it bite a man, he also becomes mad, and when he hears the barking of a dog, answers it [by barking]. (TA.) ― -b3- dimaA'u Almuluwki A^a$ofaY mina Alkalabi [The blood of kings has cured of canine madness]: or, accord. to another reading, dimaA'u Almuluwki $ifaA'u Alkalabi [The blood of kings is the cure for canine madness]. A proverb, explained by what is quoted from Lh, voce kalibN. But some reject this explanation, and assert the meaning to be, that, when a man is enraged [by desire of obtaining revenge], and takes his blood revenge, the blood is the cure of his rage, though not really drunk. (TA.) See also kalibN and kaliba. ― -b4- [Also kalabN A madness like that of the dog, affecting camels. (See 4.)] ― -b5- kalabN and kulobapN↓ (tropical:) Vehemence; severity; pressure; affliction: (K, TA:) severity, or intenseness of cold &c.; like julobapu: (S:) severity and sharpness of winter: (K, for the former word; and TA, for the latter) also the latter, accord. to the TA, [and the former also, as appears from its verb,] severity, or pressure, of him or fortune, and of everything: (TA:) and the latter, straitness, or difficulty, (K,) of life: (TA:) and drought: (K:) or distress arising from drought or from government &c. (AHn.) ― -b6- dafaEotu Eanoka kalaba fulaAnK (tropical:) I have averted from thee the evil, or mischief, and injurious conduct, of such a one. (S.) See also kalobN.

kalibN *
A dog or man affected with the disease called kalabN: (S, TA:) ― -b2- A dog accustomed to eating human flesh, and in consequence seized with what resembles madness, or diabolical possession, so that when it wounds a man, he also becomes in like manner affected (Lth. S) by the disease called kulaAbN, barking like a dog, reading his clothes upon himself. wounding others, and at last dying of thirst, refusing to drink. (Lth.) ― -b3- A man thus affected is termed kalibN and kaliybN↓: pl. of the former kalibuwna, and of the latter (or of the former accord. to the S) kalobaY. (TA.) When a man thus affected bites another, they come to a man of noble rank, and he drops for them some blood from his finger, which they give to drink to the patient, and he becomes cured. (Lh.) See also kalabN and kaliba. ― -b4- kalibN A dog habituated to eating men. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) An importunate beggar. (A.) ― -b6- dahorN kalibN (tropical:) Fortune that presses severely and injuriously upon its subjects. (TA.) ― -b7- kalibN A tree of which the leaves are rough, in consequence of its not having sufficient watering, without losing their moisture, so that they catch to the garments of those who pass by, thus annoying them like a dog. (ADk.)

kalobapN *
(assumed tropical:) A thorny tree, destitute of branches: (K:) so called because it catches to [the garments of] those who pass by it, like a dog: (TA:) a rugged tree, with branches standing out apart, and tough thorns. (TA.) ― -b2- A small thorny plant, of the kind called $iros, resembling
the $kAEA [or $ukaAEaY, or $ukaAEap], of the description termed *ukuwr: (TA:) or a certain thorny tree, (K,) of the kind called EiDaAh, having [what is termed] jrA'; (TA;) as also kalibapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- kalobatAani The implement with which the blacksmith takes hold of hot iron; [his forceps]. (S, K.) ― -b2- HadiydapN *aAtu kalobatayoni [An iron with two curved ends, forming a forceps]. You also say HadiydataAni *awaAtaA klbtyn, and HadaAy^idu *awaAtu klbtyn. (TA.)

kulobapN *
The shop of a vintner. (AHn, K.) ＝ -A2- The hairs that grow upon each side of the fore part of the nose and mouth of a dog or cat: (Z, K:) wrongly explained as signifying the nails of a dog. (Z.) ＝ -A3- A thong, or a strand (TaAqap) of the fibres of the palm-tree (liyf), with which skins and the like are sewed: (K, TA:) [see A_iqotafaA^a:] or a thong, or [so in the O and in the TA, art. qfA^; but here, in the latter, instead of “ or, ” “ behind, ” which is evidently a mistake;] a strand (TaAqap) of the fibres of the palm-tree, used in the same manner as the shoe-maker's awl that has, at its head, a perforation vaqobN [so in the O, in the TA Hjr a strange mistranscription: what is meant is doubtless an eye, like that of a needle, and it is by means of an implement with an eye at the end that the operation here described is commonly performed in the present day:] the thong, or the thread, or string, is inserted into the klbp, which is doubled: thus it enters the place [or hole] of the sewing, and the sewer introduces his hand into the A_idaAwap [q.v., i. e., the vessel upon which he is employed in working], and stretches the thong of leather, or the thread, or string, (O, L, TA,) in the klbp. (L, TA.) [See kalaba.]

A^aroDN kalibapN *
(tropical:) Land which has not sufficient watering, and of which the plants, in consequence, become dry: (S:) or rugged land, and such as is termed quf~, in which there are neither trees nor herbage, and which is not a mountain. (Aboo-Kheyreh.) ― -b2- A^aroDN kalibapu Al$~ajari Land upon which the rain called Alr~abiyE does not fall: (TA:) or rugged, dry, land, upon which that rain does not fall, and which does not become soft. (ADk.) ― -b3- See kalobapN.

kalaAbN *
[perhaps inf. n. of kuliba] The departure of reason by the kind of madness termed kalab. (K.)

kulaAbN *
: see kalabN.

kaliybN *
: see kalobN and kalibN. ― -b2- Respecting this word in the following verse of TaäbbataSharran,
A_i*aA AlHarobu A^awolatoka Alkaliyba fawal~ihaA
kaliybaka waA@Eolamo A^an~ahaA sawofa tanojaliY
[When war sets over thee &c.] there are two opinions: one, that by klyb is meant mukaAlib (see 2): the other, that it is an inf. n. of kalibati AlHarobu [“ The war became vehement, severe, or fierce ”]: the former is the more valid. (IM.)

kal~aAbN *
: see kalobN and mukal~ibN.

kul~aAbN *
(S, K) and kal~uwbN↓ (K) A spur; (S, K;) the iron instrument that is in the boot of him who breaks in a horse. (S.) ― -b2- kul~aAbN and kal~uwbN↓ (and kul~uwbN↓, MF, art. sbH q. v.,) [A flesh-hook;] an iron implement with which meat is taken out of the cooking-pot: pl. kalaAliybu: (S:) an iron flesh-hook, with prongs: (R, which gives this as the explanation of the latter word:) a hooked iron; like xuT~aAf: (Fr. &c.) a piece of wood at the head of which is a hook, ('Eyn,) of the same or of iron: (T:) an iron instrument for roasting flesh-meat: syn. saf~uwd. (Lh.) See kalobN. ― -b3- kalaAliybu (tropical:) The talons of a falcon: (K:) pl. of kal~uwbN. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The thorns of a tree. (K.)

kul~uwbN *
and kal~uwbN: see kul~aAbN.

kalotabaAnN *
A pimp: from kaliba, q. v., (As, IAar, K) Sb, however, does not mention the measure faEotalaAnN. ISd thinks it most probable that kaliba is a triliteral-radical, and kltbAn a quadriliteralradical [or rather a quasi-quadriliteral-radical], like zarima and A_izoraA^am~ &c. (L.) See also qaroTabaAnN and qalotabaAnN, and art. kltb.

kaAlibN *
: see kalobN, and mukal~ibN.

tikil~aAbapN *
A clamourous, very noisy, very garrulous, woman, of evil disposition. (TA, voce jal~aAbap.)

mukal~abN *
A dog trained and accustomed to hunt. (L.) See the verb. ＝ -A2- A captive, or prisoner, (S,) having the feet shackled, or bound; (S, K;) i. q. mukab~alN, from which it is formed by transposition, (S,) accord. to some. (TA.)

mukal~ibN *
One who trains dogs to hunt; (S, K;) as also kal~aAbN↓: and sometimes signifying one who trains the fahod, and birds of prey, to take game: see Kur v. 6: one who possesses dogs trained to hunt, and hunts with them; (L;) as also kaAlibN↓, pl. kul~aAbN: (R:) or kaAlibN and kal~aAbN (S, L, K) signify an owner, or a possessor, of dogs; (L, K;) the former being similar to taAmirN &c. (S.)

mutakaAlibN *
an appellation given by the people of El-Yemen to (tropical:) A deputy, or an agent; because of his acting injuriously, or contentiously, towards them over whom he is appointed as such. (TA.)

kalobavN *
and kulaAbivN A hard and strong man. (IDrd, L.) ― -b2- Also, and kulobuvN and kulabivN, Niggardly, or stingy, and contracted [in disposition]. (K.) [See also kunobuvN.]

1 kalatahu *
, aor.
kalita
, inf. n. kalotN, IF,) He collected it together: (IF, K:) like kaladahu. (IF.) ― -b2- kalatahu fiY AlA_inaA'i, aor.
kalita
, He poured it into the vessel. (Az, K.) ＝ -A2- kalata $ayoy^FA (or kalata bihi, Sgh) He threw, or cast, a thing. (K.) ＝ -A3- kalata, [aor.
kalita
,] He urged a horse to run, by striking him with his feet; syn. rakaDa. (Aboo-Mihjen, K.)

7 Anklt *
It (beverage, TA) poured out, or forth; or was, or became, poured out, or forth. (K.) ＝ -A2- He (a man, TA) shrunk; or became contracted. (K.)

8 Aktlthu *
He drank it. (Fr, K, TA.)

kulotapN *
A lot, portion, or set portion, of food (K) &c. (TA.) ― -b2- A little; a small portion; somewhat; syn. nubo*apN; (K;) of a thing. (TA.)

farasN fulatapN kulatapN *
A horse that leaps, springs, or bounds, with his whole body and limbs. (K, TA.)

kltp *
(probably a mistake for kulobapN, TA,) Vehemence; severity; pressure; affliction. (TS.)

A_imoraA^apN kaluwtN *
i. q. jamuwEN. (TA.)

kaliytN *
and kil~iytN↓ An oblong stone (resembling a biroTiyl, TA) with which the hole of a hyena is stopped up: (K:) so (yusad~u bihi) accord. to IDrd.: or, as in some copies yusobaru bh, is probed: or, as in the TS, yusotaru bh, is covered: after this is applied, the earth is dug away to find the hyena: mentioned by IAar. (TA.)

farasN ful~atN kul~atN *
, and fulatN kulatN, A swift horse. (K.)

kil~iytN *
: see kaliytN.

rajulN miSolatN mikolatN *
A man who is sharp, acute, or penetrating, in the transacting of affairs. (TS, L.) [See also mikolavN.]

Q. 1 kalotaba *
, inf. n. kalotabapN, He acted as a pimp. (IAar.) See kalotabaAnN. ― -b2- [Freytag assigns to this verb the signification Dissimulations, astutia, usus est in rebus; as from the K,
with the same inf. n.: but I do not find it in any copy of that work. See, however, the next para.]

kalotabN *
and kulotubN Dissimulation, or craftiness, or deceit, in affairs: (K:) [or i. q. kalovabN, q. v.]

kalotabaAnN *
A pimp: (K:) from Alkalabu: [see kaliba]. (TA.)

7 Anklv *
He advanced: preceded: syn. taqad~ama. (K.)

mikolavN *
A man (TA) penetrating (maADK) in affairs. (K.) See mikolatN.

kalovabN *
and kulaAvibN Contracted [in hand or mind]: avaricious: (K:) dissembling, or using craft, or deceit, in affairs: app. a dial. syn. of kalotabN. (TA.) See also kalobavN.

kiylajapN *
, (S, and so accord. to the Mgh and the Msb and Es-Sakháwee, TA, but in some copies of the K kayolajapN,) as also kylqp and kylkp, (Shifà el-Ghaleel,) A certain measure, mikoyaAlN, (S, K,) used in El-'Irák, consisting of two menns and seven-eighths of a menn; the menn (man~) being two pounds; [consequently, five pounds and three quarters]: (Msb:) or half a SaAE: (Az, in Mgh and Msb, voce kur~N:) [from the Persian kiylaho:] pl. kiylajaAtN (Msb:) and kayaAlijN and kayaAlijapN, (S, K,) in which last the klH is added because it is a foreign word. (S.)

1 kalaHa *
, aor.
kalaHa
, inf. n. kuluwHN and kulaAHN; (S, K;) and tlk~H↓, and AklH↓, (K,) and Aklw~H↓; (A;) He (a man, S) grinned, or displayed his teeth, (M, rendered in the S and K by taka$~ara), frowning, or contracting his face, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- kalaHa fiY wajohihi He frightened him; namely a child, and a madman. (A.)

2 kl~H wajohahu *
He contracted his face much. (A.)

3 mukaAlaHapN *
[inf. n. of kAlHhu He contended with him for superiority in strength;] i. q. mu$aAd~apN. (S.) [And so mujaAlaHapN.]

4 A^akolaHahu *
He (or it, L) made him to grin, or display his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (L, K.) ― -b2- See 1.

5 tkl~H *
(tropical:) He smiled: see 1. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) tkl~H Albaroqu (tropical:) The lightning flashed in continued succession: (S, L, K:) also, it continued, and became concealed, in a white cloud. (L.)

13
see 1.

kalaHapN *
(tropical:) The mouth and parts around it. So in the phrase maA A^aqobaHa kalaHatahu How ugly is his mouth with the parts around it! (S, K.)

kalaAHi *
: see kulaAHN.

kulaAHN *
(S, K) and kalaAHi↓, the latter [indecl.] like qaTaAmi, (K,) (tropical:) A year of dearth, scarcity, drought, sterility, or barrenness. (S, K.) You say A^aSaAbatohumo sanapN kulaAHN A year of dearth, &c., befell them. (TA.) See kaAliHN.

kaAliHN *
, act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- Also, Having the lip withdrawn from the teeth. (Zj, L.) So in the Kur xxiii. 106, accord. to Zj. (L.) ＝ -A2- dahorN kaAliHN (tropical:) Severe, distressing, or afflictive, fortune, or time; (S, K;) as also kulaAHN↓. (TA.)

kawolaHN *
Foul, unseemly, or ugly; syn. qabiyHN: (K;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

balaA='N mukoliHN *
A trial, or an affliction, which, by its severity, makes men grin and frown. (L, from a trad.)

Q. 1 kaloHabahu *
He struck him with a sword. (K.)

kaloHabapN *
: of this word, Az says, It is not known what it is: but it is related, on the authority of IAar, that it signifies The sound, and flame, of fire; or its sounding, and flaming: (as explained in the K:) or, accord. to the RA, it signifies its sound, or sounding, in what is slender, or small, as a lamp and the like. (TA.) [See also HadomN.]

5 tkl~d *
He (a man) was, or became, thick and firm in flesh. (L.) ― -b2- See also Q. Q. 3.

R. Q. 3 A_ikolanodada *
: see Q. Q. 3.

Q. Q. 3 A_ikolanodaY *
He (a man, Lh, and a camel, S, L) was, or became, thick, big, gross, or coarse, and strong; (Lh, S, L, K;) like A_iEolanodaY; (S, L;) as also A_ikolanodada↓ (Lh, L) and takal~ada↓: (K:) he, or it, was, or became, hard; (K;) and strong; as also A_ikolanodada↓. (TA.)

kaladN *
[a coll. gen. n.] Rugged lands: (Msb, K:) n. un. with p: (Msb, K:) or [hills such as are termed] A_ikaAm: n. un. with p: and kalanodFY↓ also signifies a hill of this kind: (K:) also, a hard place without pebbles; (S, K;) as also kaladapN and kalanodFY↓: (TA:) or the last two words signify a piece of rugged ground or land. (S.) The Arabs use the expression Dab~u kaladapK, because the Db~ burrows only in hard ground. (L.) ― -b2- A^abuw kaladapK [in some copies of the K, kalodapK] a surname of The male hyena. (L, K.)

kalanodFY *
: see kaladN.

mukolanodK *
Strong, and thick, big, gross, or coarse, as also mukolanodidN↓: (K:) and the ↓latter, hard: (S, L:) and strong in make, and big: and, the former, accord. to some, strong; applied in a general manner: or a hard and strong camel; (L;) as also the latter. (TA.)

mukolanodidN *
: see mukolanodK.

1 kalasa *
: see 2.

2 kl~s *
, inf. n. takoliysN, He plastered (Tar~a) a building with kilos; as also kalasa↓, inf. n. kalosN: he made smooth [with plaster]: when a thing is thickly plastered, it is termed muqaromadN. (TA.) See kilosN. ― -b2- As used by the alchemists, [He calcined a substance;] he dissolved a body so that it became like kilos. (TA.)

kilosN *
(S, K) and by poetic licence. kil~isN↓ (IJ) i. q. SaAruwjN [i. e. Quick time, and the mixtures thereof, with which are plastered tanks, or cisterns, and baths, &c.], (S, K.) or the like thereof, (TA,) with which one builds: (S, TA:) or that with which a wall, or the inside of a palace or the like, is plastered, resembling jiS [or gypsum], without baked bricks. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, describing El-Hadr, a city between the Tigris and Euphrates, (TA,)
$aAdahu maromarFA wajal~alahu kilo
sFA falilT~ayori fiY *uraAhu wukuwru
[He raised it high, of marble, and covered it with quick time, and there were nests for the birds in its tops]: or, accord. to As, the right reading is waxal~alahu kilosFA, with x, meaning, and put SArwj into the interstices of its stones; and he used to laugh at him who related it in the former manner, with j. (TA.) But see 2.

kil~isN *
: see kilosN.

kal~aAsN *
: see mukal~isN.

[
kal~aAsapN *
A time-kiln: so in the present day.]

kayoluwsN *
[Chyle; from the Greek χυλός;] a term applied by the physicians to the food when it is digested in the stomach before it departs thence and becomes blood; also called kayomuwsN.
(L.) [But the latter word more properly signifies “ chyme, ” and in this sense is used by modern physicians.]

mukal~isN *
A lime-burner; (Golius, on the authority of Meyd;) [as also kal~aAsN↓: or this latter signifies a seller of quick lime.]
See Supplement

1 kamaA^a *
, aor.
kamaAa
, inf. n. kamo'N; (S, K;) and AkmA^↓; (K;) He fed people with [the truffles called] kamo'. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- kamiy^a, aor.
kamaAa
, inf. n. kamaA^N, He walked barefoot, and had no shoes, or sandals; HafiYa walamo takuno Ealayohi naEolN: (accord. to some copies of the S, on the authority of Ks, and so in the L: or, accord. to the K, and an excellent copy of the S, HafiYa waEalayohi naEolN, which may signify He became thin in the feet, from much walking, though wearing shoes, or sandals:]) kamaA^N in the foot is the same as qasaTN; [i. e., the being naturally stiff in the tendons]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- kamiy^ato (tropical:) It (his foot, S, A, K, or hand, A) became much cracked (Th, S, K) by reason of cold. (A.) Also written in a copy of the A kmA^t; app. by a mistake of the transcriber. (TA.) ＝ -A4- kamiy^a Eani AlA^axobaAri (K) inf. n. kamo'N, (TA,) He was ignorant of, and understood not, or minded not, the news. (K.)

4 AkmA^ *
It (a place) abounded with [the truffles called] kamo'. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 1. ＝ -A2- A^akomaA^atohu Als~in~u Age rendered him a $ayox, or an old man. (S, K.)

5 tkm~A^ *
He gathered [the truffles called] kamo'. (S.) ＝ -A2- tkm~A^ Ealayohi AlA^aroDu The earth hid him [as in a grave]. (K.) ＝ -A3- tkm~A^hu He detested him, or it; syn. takar~ahahu. (K.)

6 tkAmA^nA fY A^aroDihimo *
[We, together, gathered the truffles called kamo' in their land]. (A.)

kamo'N *
A well-known vegetable, (K,) [the truffle,] which comes forth from the earth like the fuTor: or what is called $aHomu AlA^aroDi [the fat of the earth]; and the Arabs also call it judariY~u AlA^aroDi [the small-pox of the earth]: it is also said that the name of kamoA^apN is given to those [truffles] that incline to dust-colour and black; and jbA^p (q. v.) to those that incline to red: kuHol and tuwtiyaA are compounded with the juice of this vegetable [to apply to the eye]: Th also mentions kamaApN [as used for kamoA^apN]. (TA.) The dual of kamo'N is kamoA=ni; (S;) the pl. (of pauc., S) A^akomuw^N; (S, K;) and [pl. of mult.] kamoA^apN: (K:) this last is not a pl. of km', but a quasi-pl. n.: (Sb, K:) [or kamoA^apN is rather a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is without the p, contr. to analogy: (see jabo'N:)] in speaking of many, you say kamoA^apN, contr. to analogy: (S:) or kamoA^apN is the sing., and kamo'N pl.: or [accord. to some,] kamoA^apN is both sing. and pl.: (K:) AHn mentions kamoA^apN as sing., and kamoA^ataAni as dual, and kamoA=tN as pl.: but the right opinion is that of Sb. (TA.) [kamoA^apN also signifies Any kind of fungus, such as the mushroom, and toadstool. See fuTorN.]

kam~aA'N *
One who sells, and who gathers for sale, [the truffles called] kamo'. (K.)

makomaA^apN *
and makomuw^apN A place in which [the truffles called] kamo' grow. (K.)

1 kamuta *
, (contr. to analogy, as verbs significant of colours [if unaugmented] are generally of the measure faEilN, MF,) aor.
kamuta
, inf. n. kamotN and kumotapN (in the CK kamotapN) and kamaAtapN; and Akmt↓, inf. n. A_ikomaAtN; (K;) and Akmt~↓, inf. n. A_ikomitaAtN; and AkmAt~↓, (in the CK A_ikomaA^at~a,) inf. n. A_ikomiytaAtN; (S, K;) He (a horse, S, K, [and a camel, &c.]) was, or became, of the colour called kumayotN. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- kamata AlgayoZa, [aor,
kamuta
,] He concealed, or hid in his bosom, rage, or wrath. (Sgh, K.)

2 km~t vawobahu *
(tropical:) He dyed his garment of the colour of [fresh ripe] dates; i. e., of a red colour inclining to black. (A.) ― -b2- kum~itato She was rendered artificially of the colour called kumayotN, (K,) or was dyed of that colour. (So in a copy of the K.)

4 A^akomata
see 1.

9 A_ikomat~a
see 1.

11 A_ikomaAot~a
see 1.

kumotN *
: see A^akomatu.

kumotapN *
[A dark bay colour:] a red colour mixed with blackness: (Kh, Sb:) or a red colour mixed with qunuwo', (As, S, K,) which latter is blackness that is not pure, or clear: (see kumayotN:) or a colour between black and red: (ISd:) there are two kinds of kmtp; namely kumotapu SuforapK [yellow bay, or gilded bay,] and kumotapu HumorapK [red bay, or chestnut-bay]. (IAar.)

kumayotN *
, masc. and fem., (S, K,) [A bay, or dark bay, or brown, horse &c.:] of a red colour mixed with blackness: (Kh, Sb:) or of a red colour mixed with qunuwo', (As, S, K,) which latter is blackness that is not pure, or clear: (TA [app. from As]:) [see kumotapN, above:] a camel is called A^aHomaru if of an unmixed red; but if of a red colour mixed with qnw', it is called kmyt: (As, S:) the difference between kmyt and A^a$oqaru, as applied to horses, is in the mane and the tail: if these are red, the animal is called A$qr [i. e. sorrel]; and if they are black, it is called kmyt; (AO, S, TA;) and the warod is between these two: (AO, TA:) [all bay horses have black manes, which distinguish them from the sorrel, that have red or white manes: (Farrier's Dict., quoted in Johnson's Dict., voce “ bay ”:)] an epithet applied to the horse and the camel and other animals: (ISd:) you say farasN kmytN, and muhorapN kmytN, and baEiyrN kmytN, and naAqapN kmytN: (TA:) accord. to the Kh, as cited by Sb, it is of the dim. form because it denotes a colour between black and red, as though to imply that it signifies what is near to each of these two colours. (S.) In a marginal note in the S, it is said to be a foreign word arabicized. (TA.) [Perhaps from the Persian kumiy\x{698}aho: Freytag says, accord. to some from the Persian kumyth.] See also A^akomatu, and kumotapN. The Arabs say, that the kmyt is the most powerful of horses, and the strongest in the hoofs. (TA.) ― -b2- tamorapN kumayotN (tropical:) A date of the colour called kumayotN; [or, red tinged, or mixed, with black, or of a blackish red colour]: it is one of the kinds hardest, or toughest, in liHaA=' [i. e. pulp, or flesh], and sweetest to chew. (AM.) ― -b3- tiynN kumayotN (tropical:) A fig of that colour. (AHn.) ― -b4- kumayotN (tropical:) a name of Wine; because there is in it blackness and redness: (S:) or wine in which is blackness and redness: (M, K:) used like a proper name, [or rather as a subst.,] though originally an epithet. (TA.) ― -b5- kumayotN is also applied as an epithet to waste, or unowned, land. (ISd.) ― -b6- kumayotN A long, complete, month, or year. (IAar.)

A^axa*ahu bikamiytatihi *
He took it by its root. (Sgh, K.)

kamaAtiY~N *
: see next paragraph.

Q. 1 kamovara *
, inf. n. kamovarapN, It became compact,
one part of it entering into another, or parts into parts: (K: [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned:]) an obsolete verb: (TA:) whence the following word, (IDrd, K,) if it be Arabic. (IDrd.)

kum~avorFY *
(S, Msb, K,) a [coll.] gen. n., with tenween, and, accord. to some, kumavorFY, without teshdeed, but others disallow this, (Msb,) A certain kind of fruit; (T, S;) well known; [namely, the pear;] called by [some of] the vulgar A_ij~aASN: (T:) [it is called by this latter name, and also A_inojaAS and A_inojaAs, in Syria; but in Egypt and some other countries, kum~avoraY:] n. un. kum~avoraApN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. kum~avorayaAtN: (K:) [here I find added in the TA, it is fem., imperfectly decl.; and in the K, “ and sometimes it is masc. ”: but this is evidently wrong: it is masc., and with tenween, as is shown by its n. un.; but it is sometimes made fem., and then it must be written kum~avoraY, without tenween: for it is added,] and one says, h`*ihi kum~avoraY waAHidapN [this is one pear: in the copies of the K in my possession erroneously written kum~avorFY]: and h`*ihi kum~avoraY kaviyrapN [these are many pears]. (K.) Its dim. has the following forms: kumayomivorapN, (K,) which is the most agreeable with analogy, (ISd, TA,) and kumayomivoriyapN, (K,) which is the form adopted by those who make the pl. km~avorayaAtN, (ISk, TA,) and kumayovirapN, (K,) which is the best form, (ISk, TA,) and kumayomivoraApN. (K.) Az says, I have asked a number of Arabs of the desert respecting the kmvr~Y, but they knew it not. (TA.)

1 kamaHa Ald~aAb~apa *
, [aor.
kamaHa
,] (inf. n. kamoHN; M) and A^akomaHahaA↓; i. q. kabaHahaA (A 'Obeyd, K) and A^akobaHahaA: (A 'Obeyd:) or kamaHa Ald~aAb~apa biAlil~jaAmi signifies He pulled in the horse, or the like, by the bridle and bit, in order that it might stop, and not run: (M:) and AkmHhA↓, he pulled its bridle so that its head became upright, or erect. (As, S, M.)

4 A^akomaHa
See 1. ＝ -A2- AkmH Alkaromu The grape-vine became in a state of commotion preparatory to its putting forth its leaves. (S, K.) ― -b2- AkmHt Alz~amaEapu The gem, or knot, in the place whence a bunch of grapes was about to grow forth became white, and what resembled cotton came forth upon it. (Az, on the authority of Et-Táïfee.) ― -b3- See also Akmx and A^uqomiHa.

kawomaHN *
(and kuwmaHN, L) A man (S) having large buttocks. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- Also kawomaHN, A man (TA) whose teeth fill his mouth so that his speech is thick: (K:) or a man whose teeth are crowded together, one upon another, so that his mouth seems to be straitened by them. (IDrd.) ― -b3- famN kwmH A mouth straitened by the great number of the teeth and by the swelling of the gums. (IDrd.)

1 kamaxa biA^anofihi *
, (S, L, K,) aor.
kamaxa
; (K;) and bAnfh Akmx↓; (L;) He magnified himself, or was proud; (S, L, K;) elevated his nose, from pride: (L:) or Akmx he elevated his head, from pride; (L;) i. q. AqmH [in the CK with x]: (K:) or he sat in the manner of him who magnifies himself (S, L) in his own mind. (L.) A^akomaxuwA baA^owFA They flourished and increased in self exaltation: or taraAd~uwA. (L.) ― -b2- kamaxahu biAll~ijaAmi He pulled him in [i. e. a horse or the like] by the bridle and bit, in order to check or stop him; (L:) i. q. kabaHahu; (K;) [or he pulled up his head by the bridle and bit]. See kamaHa. ＝ -A2- kamaxa bihi, (K,) aor.
kamaxa
, (L,) inf. n. kmoxN, (S, L,) He voided it, namely his excrement, or ordure; or voided it in a thin state; syn. salaHa. (S, K.) Some bread and kaAmaix [q. v. infra] were offered to an Arab of the desert, and he knew not the latter; so it was said to him, “ This is kAmx; ” whereupon he said, “ I know that it is kAmx; ” and added, A^ay~ukumo kamaxa bihi “ which of you voided it? ” Ay~km salaHa bh. (S.) ― -b2- kamaxa bisaloHihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He (a camel) voided his excrement, or ordure, in a thin state. (L.)

4 A^akomaxa
See 1. ＝ -A2- Akmx It (a vine) put forth its gems when about to put forth its leaves. (AHn.) [See also A^akomaHa.]

kumaAxN *
The magnifying one's self; pride. (Abu-l-'Abbás, K.)

kaAmaxN *
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) sometimes written and pronounced kaAmixN, (Msb, and written in both these ways in a copy of the S) but the former is better known, and more common, (TA,) an arabicized word, (S, Mgh, Msb,) from the Persian kaAmaho, (Mgh, Shifá el-Ghaleel,) A kind of seasoning, or condiment, eaten with bread to render it pleasant, or savoury; (S, Msb, K;) [a thing used to give relish to food, or to quicken the appetite;] accord. to some, prepared with vinegar, and used to quicken the appetite; (TA;) also called mur~iY~N: (Msb:) or it is a bad sort of mur~iY~: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. kawaAmixu, (Msb,) or kawaAmiyxu. (Mgh.)

malikN kayomaxN *
A king having his head elevated, from pride. (L.)

1 kamida *
, aor.
kamada
, inf. n. kamadN, It (a thing) became changed in colour, (L, * Msb, K, *) and lost its clearness, (L, K,) the traces thereof remaining. (L.) ― -b2- kamida lawonuhu His, or its, colour became changed. (L.) ― -b3- kamida Alv~awobu The garment became worn-out, (A, K,) and smooth, (K,) so that its colour changed. (A.) ― -b4- kamada, (aor.
kamuda
, K, inf. n. kamodN and kumuwdN, TA,) He (a fuller, L) beat a garment, or piece of cloth. (L, K.) ― -b5- kamida, aor.
kamada
, inf. n. kamadN, (tropical:) He (a man) was affected with concealed grief or sorrow: (S, Msb:) or, with grief or sorrow which he could not dispel: (L:) or, with intense grief or sorrow: (K:) or, with most intense grief or sorrow: (L:) and, with disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow. (K.)

2 km~dhu *
, inf. n. takomiydN, He heated it (a limb) with a kimaAdap; (K;) heated it with rags and the like; (S, L;) applied to it a kimaAdap. (A.) kimaAdN [which see below] signifies the same as takomiydN. (S, L.) ― -b2- He heated for him a garment or piece of cloth or some other thing, and applied it to a place in which he suffered pain in one of his limbs, so as to give him ease. You also say A^akomadahu↓; and makomuwdN is used as the pass. part. n. of this verb, anomalously. (L.)

4 Akmdhu *
He (a fuller, S, A, L, and a washer, L) failed of cleaning it, (S, A, L,) and of making it white, (A,) namely, a garment. or piece of cloth. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Akmdhu He, or it, affected him with intense grief or sorrow: and, with disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow: (K:) it (grief) rendered him sorrowful. (A.) ― -b3- See 2.

kamodN *
: see kamadN.

kamadN *
(L, K) and kamodN↓ (K) and kumodapN↓, (S, L, Msb, K,) the last a simple subst., (Msb,) Change of colour, (S, L, Msb, K,) and loss of its clearness, (L, K,) the traces thereof remaining. (L.) ― -b2- kamadN Concealed grief or sorrow: (S, A, L, Msb:) or grief or sorrow which one cannot dispel: (L:) or intense grief; as also kamodN↓ and kumodapN↓: (K:) or most intense grief or sorrow: (ISd, L:) and disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow. (K.)

kamidN *
A thing changed in colour; (Msb;) see 1; and All~awoni A^akomadu↓ [the same]: (A:) and Alwajohi kaAmidu↓ [changed in countenance]. (A.) ― -b2- Affected with concealed grief or sorrow; as also kamiydN↓: (S, Msb:) or, both words, with grief or sorrow which cannot be dispelled: (L:) or, with intense grief or sorrow; as also kaAmdN↓ and makomuwdN↓ [which see below]: (K:) or, with most intense grief or sorrow: (L:) and, with disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow; as also kaAmidN↓ and makomuwdN↓. (K.) ― -b3- Frowning,
or contracting his face; looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; as also kaAmidN↓. (L.)

kumodapN *
: see kamadN.

kimaAdN *
(a subst. K) The act of beating a garment, or a piece of cloth, by a fuller. (L, K. *) ― -b2- kimaAdN (K) and kimaAdapN (A, L, K) A greasy, (A,) or dirty, (K,) or greasy and dirty, (L,) piece of rag, which is heated, and put upon a pained part, as a means of cure, (A, L, K,) for pain (A, K) of the belly, (K,) or flatulence. (A, K.) ― -b3- kimaAdN i. q. takomiydN; see 2; (S, L;) [The application of a kimaAdap;] the taking a piece of rag, and heating it with fire, and putting it upon the place of a swelling. (Sh, L.) It is said in a trad., AlkimaAdu A^aHab~u A_ilaY~a mina AlkaY~i [The application of a kimaAdap is more pleasing to me than cauterization]. (S, L.)

kamiydN *
and kaAmidN: see kamidN.

makomuwdN *
, which is extr., being from A^akomadahu: (TA:) see 4, and kamidN.

1 kamara *
He (a circumciser) missed the place of circumcision [and hurt, or wounded, the glans of the penis]. (IKtt.)

kamarapN *
The head [or glans] of the penis; (K;) or i. q. Ha$afapN: (Msb:) pl. kamarN: (S, Msb, K:) [or rather, the latter is a coll. gen. n.; and the former, the n. un.] It is said in a proverb, Alkamaru A^a$obaAhu Alkamari; alluding to the likeness of one thing to another. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, by synecdoche, (tropical:) The penis, altogether. (Msb.)

makomuwrN *
A man (S) having the head [or glans] of his penis, (Msb, K,) or the extremity of the head of his penis, (S,) hurt, or wounded, by the circumciser. (S, Msb, K.)

kayomuwsN *
[Chyme; from the Greek χυμός;] a term applied by the physicians to the food when it is digested in the stomach before it departs thence and becomes blood; also called kayoluwsN: (L, TA:) [but the latter word more properly signifies “ chyle, ” and in this sense is used by modern physicians:] a certain mixture or humour (xiloTN): a Syriac word: (K:) [or Greek, as mentioned above:] Az says, that kayomuwsaAtN, as used by the physicians, signifies the four humours; and is not Arabic, but ancient Greek. (TA.)

kayomuwsiy~apN *
Want, or requirement, of food, or nourishment. Occurring in a trad. of Kuss, where it is said to be not an attribute of God. (ISd, TA.)

1 kamu$ato *
, aor.
kamu$a
, inf. n. kamaA$apN, She (a woman) was, or became, small in the breast. (TA.) ― -b2- kamu$ati AlxuSoyapu, inf. n. kumuw$apN, [The testicle, or the scrotum,] was, or became, short, and cleaving to the inner skin. (TA.) See also 5. ＝ -A2- kamu$a, inf. n. kamaA$apN, He (a man) was, or became, quick; (K;) as also tkm~$↓ (S, K, TA) and Ankm$↓; (K, TA;) and Akm$↓, in relation to pace and to work: (IKtt:) or quick and sharp or vigorous or effective: (S:) or determined or resolute, and sharp or vigorous or effective, (A, TA,) and quick, in his affairs: (TA:) or courageous. (Sb, ISd.) You say, fiY saEoyihi Ankm$↓ and tkm~$↓ [He was quick, &c., in his walking, or running, or working]. (A.) And Alfarasu fiY sayorihi Ankm$↓ [The horse was quick, &c., in his going, or pace.] (A.) And Ankm$↓ fiY A^amorihi He hastened, or was sharp or vigorous or effective, in his affair. (As.) And Ankm$↓ fiY AlHaAjapi He was quick and vigorous in executing the needful affair; syn. AjotamaEa fiyhaA. (TA.) ― -b2- And kamu$a He determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair; as also kami$a, [aor.
kama$a
] inf. n. kama$N. (TA.)

2 km~$ *ayolahu *
, (A, TA,) inf. n. takomiy$N, (TA,) He contracted, or tucked up, his skirt. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- km~$hu, (inf. n. as above, S, K,) He hastened him; made him quick; (S, A, K;) [and so app. Akm$hu↓: see $am~ara.] ― -b2- And km~$, (K,) or km~$ AlA_ibila, inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man singing to camels to urge or excite them) was vigorous in driving [so that he made the camels quick]. (K, TA.)

4 Akm$ *
: see 1. ＝ -A2- Akm$hu: see 2. ＝ -A3- Akm$ biAln~aAqapi He bound all the teats of the camel with the SiraAr, q. v. (S, K.)

5 tkm~$ *
It (skin) contracted, or shrank, (A, K,) and became drawn together; (K;) and so Ankm$↓, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, after washing; (K, art. qlS;) and of an udder. (TA.) See also 1. ＝ -A2- See again 1, in two places.

7 Ankm$ *
: see 5. ＝ -A2- See also 1, in five places.

kamo$N *
Short and small; applied to an udder: and [the fem.] with p, applied to a testicle, or a scrotum, (xuSoyap) short, and cleaving to the inner skin. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, Small in the veretrum; as also kamiy$N↓: (S, K:) or short therein: [contr. of saAbigN:] pl. [of mult.] kimaA$N and [of pauc.) A^akomaA$N: (A 'Obeyd:) or, applied to a beast of carriage, short and small therein: ('Eyn:) but when applied to a female, having a small udder; as also kamiy$N↓, (K,) or kamiy$apN, so applied, ('Eyn,) and kamo$apN, applied to a she-camel, (Ks, S,) and kamuw$N↓, thus applied: (TA:) or kamiy$apN [so in the K accord. to the TA, but in some copies of the K kami$apN↓,] and kamuw$N have this signification when applied to a ewe or she-goat: (K:) or the former of these two epithets, (As,) or each of them, (K,) thus applied, signifies short in the teat, (As, K,) so as to be milked only with the ends of three fingers, or with the thumb and forefinger: (As:) and kamo$apN, applied to a woman, having a small breast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and kamiy$N↓, applied to a man, (S, A, K,) Quick: (A, K:) or quick and sharp or vigorous or effective: (S:) or determined or resolute, and sharp or vigorous or effective, (A, TA,) and quick in his affairs: (TA:) and kami$N↓ [app. applied to a man, being the part. n. of kami$a, q. v.] is syn. with kamo$N: (TA:) or kamiy$N↓ signifies courageous. (Sb, ISd.)

kami$N *
: fem. with p: see above, in two places.

kamuw$N *
: see above, in three places.

kamiy$N *
: fem. with p: see above, passim. ― -b2- rajulN kamiy$u AlA_izaAri [lit.] A man having his AzAr [or waist-wrapper] tucked up; (K, TA;) [meaning,] vigorous, laborious, or sedulous, in his affair. (TA.)

superEntry.n: kmE kml kmn kmh kmY kn

head.foreign: kmE kml kmn kmh kmY kn

superEntry.entry: See Supplement

1 kanaba *
, aor.
kanuba
, inf. n. kunuwbN; and Aknb↓; He, or it, was, or became, gross; thick, coarse; or rough: syn. galuZa. (K.) See 4. ― -b2- kanaba He was, or became, possessed of plenty, or riches: syn. AisotagonaY. (K.) ― -b3- kanabahu fiY jiraAbihi, aor.
kaniba
, inf. n. kanobN, He stowed it, or deposited it, in his provision-bag. (K.)

4 A^akonabato yaduhu *
; and kanibato↓, aor.
kanaba
, inf. n. kanabN; (K;) or the former verb only is used; not the latter; (As, S;) His hand was, or became, callous, or hard, (S,) or coarse, or rough, (K,) by reason of work. (S, K.) See 1. ― -b2- Aknb lisaAnuhu His tongue was impeded, or tied up.
(K.) ― -b3- Aknb Ealayohi baTonuhu His belly [meaning its contents] oppressed him, or gave him pain: syn. A_i$otad~a. (K.)

kanabN *
Callousness, or hardness, of the hand, resulting from work: (S:) or coarseness, or roughness, of the foot, and of the hoof, and of the camel's foot, and of the hand: or of the hand only, resulting from work. (K.) ＝ -A2- See kanibN.

kanibN *
, of the same measure as katifN, (K,) or kanabN↓, (as in the copies of the S in my hands) A certain plant: (S, K:) or a certain tree: (Lth:) AHn says, It resembles the qataAd growing in our country, where, sometimes, sandals or shoes are sewed with its bark, and thereof are twisted ropes which endure moisture, day-dew, or rain: and in one place he says, I asked one of the Arabs of the desert respecting the knb, and he shewed me a scattered, small, thorny plant, with white twigs or branches, abounding with thorns, having, at the extremities, baraAEiym [or calyxes, or flowers, or flower-buds,] from each of which grew forth three thorns. (TA.)

kinaAbN *
i. q. $imoraAxN [i. e. the fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm tree]. (S, K.)

kaniybN *
What is dry, of trees: or having its thorns broken. (K.)

kunotubN *
and kunaAtibN Short: (K:) or thick, or coarse, and short: (TA:) or hard and strong: (see kunotvubN:) but the v is augmentative, (TA,) [and therefore the proper art. is knb].

kaAnibN *
Full to satiety; glutted with food. (K.)

mukonabN *
and mikonabN: see next paragraph.

mukonibN *
and mikonabN↓ A coarse, or rough, hoof; (IAar, K;) and the same words, and mukonabN↓, the same as applied to a camel's foot. (IAar)

mukonay^ib~N *
Thick, or coarse, and strong, and short. (K)

Q. 2 takanobata *
He (a man) became contracted [in disposition; or niggardly, or stingy]. (L, as from IDrd.) But see art. knbv. (TA.)

kunobubN *
, (or this should be kunovubN, TA) A hard, strong, robust, man. (L.) But see kunobuvN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and kunaAbitN, A man contracted [in disposition]; niggardly, or stingy. (L.) But see art. knbv. (TA.)

Q. 1 kanobava *
and takanobava↓ He became hard and strong: (L:) he became contracted; syn. taqab~aDa: (K:) [app. in disposition; see kunobuvN: or in make; the second verb being also expl. in the L, with reference to a man, by the words tadaAxala baEoDuhu fiY baEoDK].

Q. 2 takanobava
see Q. 1.

kunobuvN *
and kunobuwvN↓ and kunaAbvNi↓ Hard (L, K) and strong. (L.) [Epithets applied to a man.] ― -b2- Also, all the three words, Contracted [in disposition], and niggardly, or stingy. (K.) ― -b3- Mentioned before in art. kbv; and like kulobuvN. (TA.) ― -b4- [Accord. to the L, these epithets seem also to apply to a man Contracted in make: the first and third being expl. by the words tadaAxala baEoDuhu fiY baEoDK.]

kunobuwvN *
: see kunobuvN.

kunaAbvN *
: see kunobuvN and art. knvb.

1 kanata fiY xaloqihi *
, (aor.
kanuta
, inf. n. kanotN, TK,) He (a man) was strong in his make. (IAar, TS, K.) ＝ -A2- kanita, aor.
kanata
, It (a skin, TA) became foul with the grease of milk [and so retained the water, or milk, well]; syn. Ha$ina: (TS, and SM's copy of the K: in the CK and a MS. copy of the K, xa$una: in another copy of the K, Hasuna.)

8 Aktnt *
He was lowly; humble; submissive. (K.) [See Aiqotanata.] ― -b2- He was content, or well pleased; acquiesced. (K.)

kunotN *
: see kunotiY~N.

siqaA'N kaniytN *
[as also qaniytN] A skin that retains [the water, or milk,] well. (K.)

kunotiY~N *
Strong; robust. (Ibn-Buzruj, K.) An epithet applied to a man. (Ibn-Buzruj.) Formed from kunotu “ I was ” because an old man speaks of himself in time past saying kunotu ka*aA wakunotu ka*aA. (MF.) ― -b2- Also, [and kunotN↓, as implied in the TA, and in the S in art., Ejn,] and kunotuniY~N↓, i. q. kabiyrN [app. Great in age; old: aged]. (AZ, K.) A poet says,
wamaA kunotu kunotiy~FA wamaA kunotu EaAjinFA
wa$ar~u Alr~ijaAli AlkunotuniY~u waEaAjinu
[And I was not old, nor was I one who raised himself from the ground by the help of his hands: and the worst of men is the old, and one who raises himself so]. (TA.)

kunotaniY~N *
: see kunotiY~u.

kunotubN *
and kunaAtibN: see art. knb.

kunovapN *
A nawarodjap (in the TA, nawarodaHap, with H unpointed,) made of myrtle, and of the branches of the [kind of willow called] xilaAf (spread out, TA), upon which sweet-smelling plants are arranged, or disposed, in regular series, and which is then folded: (Lth, K:) the Nabathean word is knvA. (L.) It is a circular thing (daAy^irap) of myrtle, and of branches of willow, upon which sweet-smelling plants are disposed, or arranged, and which is then folded like a volume, or roll, and made in the form of a basket: the damsels prepare this for ornament in the days of the springseason, and amuse themselves with it. nwrdjp is an arabicized word, from the Persian nawarodho, pass. part. n. of nawarodiydano, and meaning “ folded, ” or “ twisted ” (TK, [as explained to me by a very learned Turk, who, however, thinks the words not very clear.])

kanovabN *
and kunovubN and kunaAvibN Hard and strong: (K:) but the v in this case is corrupted from t: see kunotubN in art. knb. (TA.)

kinovaAbN *
[in the TA written knAbv] Sand pouring down. (IAar, K.)

1 kanada *
, (S, &c.), aor.
kanuda
, (A, MS,) or
kanida
, (ElBasáïr,) or kanada niEomapF, (TA,) inf. n. kunuwdN, (S. K, &c.) He was ungrateful; he disacknowledged a benefit. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- A_ino saA^alotahu nakada waA_ino A^aEoTayotahu kanada If thou ask of him, he refuseth; and if thou give him. he is ungrateful. (A.) ― -b3- kanada A^abaAhu Aln~iEomap (K) He disacknowleged his father's beneficence. (TA.) ― -b4- kana*uhu, (S, L,) inf. n. kanodN, (K,) He cut, or severed, it. (S, L, K.)

kunadN *
: see kanuwdN.

kinodapN *
A portion of a mountain. (K.)

kanuwdN *
Ungrateful; who disacknowledges benefits; (El-Kelbee, S, A, L, K;) as also kan~aAdN↓: (L, K;) or a denier: (L:) the former applied also to a woman; and so kunudN↓: (S, A, L:) an unbeliever: (Zj, L:) a blamer of his Lord, (El-Hasan, L, K,) who takes account of evil accidents and forgets benefits: (El-Hasan, L:) rebellious. or disobedient, (K,) in the dial. of Kindeh: (TA:) niggardly; tenacious; avaricious; (K;) in the dial. of the Benoo-Málik: (TA:) who eats alone, and withholds his drinking-bowl (raifodahu), and beats his slave: (Kh, L, K:) all these meanings are assigned to it in the verse [6 of ch. c.] of the Kur-án, A_in~a A@loA_inosaAna lirab~ihi lakanuwdN: but of the last, ISd remarks, that he knows no foundation for it in the classical language, and that it is not easily admissible coupled with lrb~h. (L, TA.) ― -b2- A woman ungrateful for friendship, and for loving communion, commerce, or intercourse; (As, L, K;) as also kunudN↓. (As, L.) ― -b3- A^aroDN kanuwdN (tropical:) Land that produces nothing. (S, A, L, K.)

kan~aAdN *
: see kanuwdN. ― -b2- Also, One who cuts, or severs; who is wont to do so. (S, L.)

kunoduvN *
and kunaAdivN Hard and strong: (K, L:) [as also kunobuvN and kunotubN, &c.].

kunodurN *
[Greek χόνδρος λιβανωτοῦ, or λιβάνου χόνδροσ] i. q. lubaAnN [q. v., i. e. Frankincense], (S, in art. kdr; TA;) accord. to the physicians; (TA;) a kind of Eilok [or resin], very useful for stopping phlegm, (K,) and a dispeller of forgetfulness, and having other properties: n. un. with p. (TA.)

1 kanaza AlmaAla *
, aor.
kaniza
, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and, accord. to MF,
kanuza
also, but the former is that which commonly obtains, (TA,) inf. n. kanozN, (Mgh, Msb,) He buried the property, or treasure, (S, K, TA,) in the earth: (TA:) he collected the property together, (Mgh, Msb,) and treasured it, hoarded it, laid it up, reposited it, stowed it, or stored it, in secret: (Msb:) and AlmaAla Aktnz↓ signifies the same as kanazahu. (TA.) ― -b2- kanaza Al$~aYo'a, (K,) aor.
kaniza
, inf. n. kanozN, (TA,) He pressed the thing, meaning anything, (K,) with his hand or foot, (TA,) in a receptacle, or in the earth. (K.) ― -b3- kanazaAlt~amora, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
kaniza
, (K,) inf. n. kanozN, (Msb, TA,) and, accord. to Az, kanaAzN and kinaAzN, [but see the former of these two words below,] (Msb,) He stowed, or packed, the dates, (TA,) fiY AlwiEaA='i in the receptacle, (A, Msb,) or fiY AljilaAli in the large receptacles of palm-leaves, [pl. of jul~ap,] by throwing [the contents of] a bag (jiraAb) into the bottom of the jul~ap and pressing them with the feet until they became compacted, or commixed in a mass, and then bag after bag until the jl~p was pressed full, when it was sewed up with palm-leaf cord. (TA.) ― -b4- kanaza Albur~a fiY AljiraAbi [He stored up, or packed, the wheat in the bag]. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pass. part. n. voce dar~N.] ― -b5- kanaza AljiraAba He filled the bag very full. (A.) And kanaza Als~iqaA='a He filled the skin of milk or water. (TA.) And $ad~a kanoza Alqirobapi He filled the water-skin. (TA.) ― -b6- kanaza Alr~NmoHa, (Sgh, TA,) inf. n. kanozN, (Sgh, K,) He stuck the spear into the ground. (Sgh, K, * TA.)

8 Aktnz *
It (a thing, S, Mgh, Msb,) became collected together, or compacted; and full. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Aktnz Alt~amoru [The dates became closely packed, or pressed together so as to be compact or commixed in a mass: see 1]. (TA; and K in art. wjA^; &c.) The like is also said of wheat. (TA.) ― -b3- Aktnz All~aHomu The flesh became compact, or hard. (From an explanation of the part. n. in the A; &c.) ＝ -A2- Aktnz AljiraAbu The bag became very full. (A.) And Aktnz Als~iqaA='u The skin of milk or water became full. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Aktnz AlmaAla: see 1.

kanozN *
Treasure; property buried (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) in the earth: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: pl. kunuwzN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) it is applied in a trad. to (tropical:) Any property whereof the portion that should be given in alms is not given. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Property that is preserved in a receptacle. (TA.) ― -b4- Anything abundant, collected together, that is desired with emulation. (Sh, TA.) ― -b5- Gold: and silver. (K.) It is said in a trad., A^uEoTiytu Alkanozayoni mina AlA^aHomari waAlA^aboyaDi I have been given gold and silver. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) [A treasure of knowledge or science]. You say, maEahu kanozN mino kunuwzi AlEilomi (tropical:) [With him is a treasure of the treasures of knowledge or science]. (A, TA.) In the Kur, xviii. 81, it is said to be used in a similar manner, as signifying not gold nor silver, but (tropical:) Science and books. (TA.) And it is said in like manner in a trad., A^alaA A^uEal~imuka kanozFA mino kunuwzi Aljan~api laA Hawola walaA quw~apa A_il~aA biA@ll~`hi (tropical:) [Ho! I will teach thee a treasure of the treasures of paradise: There is no power nor strength but in God]: meaning, that a reward is stored up [in paradise] for him who says this, and who describes himself thereby, like as a treasure is stored up. (TA.) ― -b7- Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee says, that it is used in a verse of 'Alkamah, which he does not quote, as signifying (tropical:) Fat; as a subst.; and adds, that it is the only instance known to him of its being thus used. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, That in which property is preserved, or guarded: (K, * TA:) and makonizN↓ [or rather both] that in which property is buried, treasured, hoarded, laid up, reposited, or stored, in secret: pl. of the latter, makaAnizu. (A, TA.)

kanizN *
: see mukotanizN.

kanaAzN *
and kinaAzN↓: see kanaza Alt~amora. [Accord. to Az, they are inf. ns.; but some seem to regard them as simple substs.] You say, h`*aA zamanu AlkanaAzi, (S, Msb, K. *) and AlkinaAzi↓, (K,) This is the time of packing the dates. (K, * TA.) And El-Umawee says, A^atayotuhumo Einoda AlkanaAzi, and AlkinaAzi↓, I came to them when they were packing the dates. (TA.) ISk says, that it has been heard only with fet-h; (S, Msb;) but some say, that it is like jadaAdN and jidaAdN, and SaraAmN and SiraAmN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, sometimes, [The storing, or packing,] of wheat. (TA.)

kinaAzN *
: see kanaAzN: ＝ -A2- and see also mukotanizN, throughout.

kaniyzN *
Dates packed in [the receptacles called] qawaASir [pl. of qawoSar~apN] (K, TA) and jilaAl [pl. of jul~apN]. (TA,) for winter; (K, TA;) as also makonuwzN↓. (TA.) See kanaza Alt~amora. ― -b2- See also mukotanizN.

kan~aAzN *
One who takes extraordinary pains in treasuring, or hoarding, gold and silver. (TA.)

makonizN *
: see kanozN.

makonuwzN *
: see kaniyzN: ― -b2- and mukotanizN.

mukotanizu All~aHomi *
, and kaniyzuhu↓, (A, TA,) and kanizahu↓, and makonuwzuhu↓, (TA,) Compact, or hard, in flesh: (A:) and [in like manner] kinaAzN↓ compact and strong in flesh. (TA.) You say, naAqapN kinaAzN, (S, K,) or kinaAzu All~aHomi, (A,) and jaAriyapNi kinaAzN, (K,) and hanN kinaAzN, (TA,) A she-camel, (S, A, K,) and a girl, (K,) and a woman's pudendum, (TA,) compact, (mukotanizap, S, or kaniyzap, or, as in the K, abundant, kaviyrap, TA,) in flesh, (S, K,) and hard, or firm: (K:) pl. kunozN and kinaAzN; the latter being like the sing.; (K;) but the two vowels [namely the two kesrehs] and the two alifs are regarded as different; for the word is not, as some assert, of the same class as junubN, since it has a dual form, namely kinaAzaAni. (TA.) ― -b2- kitaAbN mukotanizN biAlfawaAy^idi (tropical:) [A book, or writing, stored with useful things]. (A, TA.)

1 kanasa *
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
kanusa
, (S, Msb,) or
kanisa
, (Mgh,) inf. n. kanosN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He swept (Mgh, TA) a house, or chamber, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or place, (TA,) with a mikonasap [or broom]. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- mar~uwA bihimo fakanasuwhumo (tropical:) They passed by them and swept them away, or destroyed them; syn. kasaHuwhumo. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- kanasa, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
kanisa
, (S, Msb, K,) or
kanusa
, (Mgh,) inf. n. kunuwsN, (Mgh, Msb,) He (an antelope) entered his kinaAs, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e., his covert, or hiding-place, among trees; (S, K;) or abode; (Msb;) or cave; (TA;) as also tkn~s↓ (S, A, Mgh, K) and Aktns↓;) (A, TA;) which two verbs are likewise said of a wild bull or cow, in the same sense. (TA.) [Hence,] tkn~s↓ also signifies (tropical:) He (a man, TA) entered the tent: (K:) or hid himself, and entered the tent. (TA.) And tkn~st↓ (tropical:) She (a woman) entered the hawodaj [or camel-litter]: (K:) app. taken from the saying of Lebeed, fatakan~asuwA quTonFA, meaning, and they entered hawaAdij [or camel-litters] covered with cloths of cotton. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] kanasati Aln~ujuwmu, (Zj,) aor.
kanisa
, (AO, Zj, S, K,) inf. n. kunuwsN, (Lth, Zj,) (tropical:) The stars hid themselves in their place, or places, of setting, (AO, Zj, S, K, *) like antelopes in their kunus [or coverts]: (K:) [or] continued in their courses and then departed, returning: (Zj:) or the stars [here meaning planets] became stationary in their circuiting or revolving. (Lth.) See kaAnisN.

5 takan~asa
see 1; the former, in four places.

8 A_ikotanasa
see 1; the former, in four places.

kinaAsN *
A gazelle's covert, or hiding-place, among trees: (S, K:) so called because he sweeps (ykns) the sand, or in the sand, [accord. to different copies of the K,] until he reaches the soil, or moist earth: (K, * TA:) or his abode: (Msb:) or cave: (TA:) and [in like manner] makonisN↓ a place into which a gazelle or a wild bull or cow enters to protect itself therein from the heat: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akonisapN (TA) and [of mult.] kunusN and kun~asN (K) and [pl. pl., i. e., pl. of kunusN,] kunusaAtN. (TA.)

kunaAsapN *
Sweepings; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the dust of a house that is swept and thrown into a heap. (Lh.) ― -b2- Also, The place of sweepings; (Mgh;) the place where sweepings are thrown. (TA.)

kaniysapN *
A place of worship (K) of the Christians; [a Christian church:] (S, A, K:) or of the Jews; (Sgh, K;) i. e., of the Jews only: [a Jewish synagogue;] that of Christians being called biyEapN: (Sgh:) [Chald כְנישָׁה: (Golius:)] or both; (Mgh, Msb;) being sometimes applied to the former [in classical times, as it is in the present day, as well as to the latter]: (Msb:) or of unbelievers, (K,) absolutely: (TA:) an arabicized word, [from the Chaldee mentioned above, or] from [the Persian word] kunisoto (Az, Mgh) or kanasoto (TA) [signifying “ a firetemple ”]: pl. kanaAy^isu. (A, Msb.) ＝ -A2- A thing resembling [the kind of camel-litter called] a hawodaj, composed of twigs, or branches, stuck in a maHomil or a raHol, with a cloth thrown over them, in which the rider sits in the shade and conceals himself: (Mgh, Msb:) of the measure faEiylapN from kunuwsN [an inf. n. of kanasa]: (Mgh:) pl. as above. (Msb.)

kan~aAsN *
One who sweeps Hu$uw$ [meaning privies]. (A, TA.)

kaAnisN *
An antelope, (S, A, TA,) and a wild bull, (TA,) entering his kinaAs, (S, A, TA,) i. e., his covert, or hiding-place, among trees: (S:) fem. with p: (Zj:) pl. kun~asN, both of the masc. and fem., (Zj,) and kawaAnisu, of the masc., (A,) [and of the fem. also accord. to rule,] and kunuwsN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alkun~asu, (S,) or AljawaAriY Alkun~asu, (K,) [in the Kur, lxxxi. 16,] (tropical:) The stars; because they hide themselves in their place of setting: (AO, S:) or the stars that rise running their course, and hide themselves in their places of setting: (Zj:) or all the stars; because they appear by night and lie hidden by day: (K:) or i. q. Alxun~asu, (K, TA,) i. e., Als~ay~aArapu, (TA,) or Als~ay~aAraAtu, (Bd,) or Alxun~asu Als~ay~aArapu, (S,) the five stars, [or planets,] Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury; (TA;) because they hide themselves in their place of setting, like antelopes in their kunus [or coverts]; (K;) or because they become hidden beneath the light of the sun: (Bd:) or the stars [meaning plants] that become hidden in their courses, and run their courses and become stationary in their places of circuiting, and then circuit [again]; every star [of those thus named] having a circuit in which it becomes stationary, and [then] revolves [again], and then it departs, returning: (Lth:) or the angels: (K:) or the wild bulls or cows, and the wild antelopes, (Zj, K,) that enter their kunus [or coverts] when the heat is vehement. (Zj.)

makonisN *
: [pl. makaAnisu:] see kinaAsN. ― -b2- [Hence,] makaAnisu Alr~ayobi (assumed tropical:) The places of suspicion. (TA.)

mikonasapN *
A broom; a thing with which one sweeps: (S, A, Msb:) pl. makaAnisu. (A, TA.)

mukan~isN *
A maker of brooms. (Golius, from Meyd.)
See Supplement

kanoEatN *
. A species of fish; (AO, TS, L, K;) as also kanoEadN; from which it appears to be formed by the substitution of t for d. (TS, L.)

Q. 2 takanoEava *
It (a thing) became collected together. (L.)

kanoEadN *
A kind of sea-fish; (S, L, K;) as also kanoEatN, in which the t seems to be a substitute for the d. (L.)
See Supplement

kunofuvN *
and kunaAfivN Short. (K.)
See Supplement

1 kahiba *
, (S, K,) and kahuba, (K,) inf. n. kahabN and kuhobapN, (TA,) He (a camel, S,) was, or became, of the colour called kuhobap. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 4 A_ikohaA^ab~a lawonuhu *
His complexion was, or became, changed, [or darkened by the sun &c.]. (TA.)

kahobN *
A buffalo (or camel, A; and so in the CK;) advanced in years. (K.)

kahabN *
: see kuhobapN

kuhobapN *
