The colour which is also called quhobap: (As, S, K:) or that which is called duhomap: or dust-colour intermixed, or tinged over, with black: (K:) used absolutely, (TA,) or only with reference to camels, (K,) i. e., to their colours: (TA:) or a colour not purely red, but applied specially to a red colour: (AA, S:) or any colour inclining to that of dust: (Yaakoob, who does not particularize anything [to which it is applied] exclusively: TA): Az says, I have not heard khbp as a colour of camels on the authority of any one but Lth; and perhaps it is used as a colour of clothes: (TA:) it is also said that kahabN↓ signifies the colour of the buffalo. (IAar, cited by Az.)

banuw kuhayobapa *
, an expression used by the poet Hassán Ibn-Thábit, meaning (tropical:) Sons of a base, or an ignoble, woman: khybp being thus used as though it were a proper name. (RA.)

kaAhibN *
: see A^akohabu.

A^akohabu *
(Az, S, K) and kaAhibN↓ (K) A camel (Az, S) of the colour called kuhobap: (Az, S, K) fem. of the former kahobaA'N, (Az) [and pl. kuhobN]. ― -b2- rajulN A^akohabu All~awoni (tropical:) A man whose complexion is changed, [or darkened by the sun &c.]. (TA.)

1 kahada *
, (S, K,) aor.
kahida
, inf. n. kahodN (K) and kahadaAnN, (S, K,) He was quick; made haste; (L, K;) in his pace: (L:) he (an ass) ran; syn. EadaA. (S, L.) ― -b2- kahada and Akhd↓ He was quick in service. (TA.) ― -b3- kahada He was importunate, persevering, or urgent, in petitioning, or seeking, or desiring. (K.) ― -b4- kahada and Akhd↓ He was, or became, fatigued, tired, or weary. (K.) ― -b5- kahada and Akhd↓ He became jaded, harassed, or fatigued, by labour, or toil: as also kadaha and A^akodaha. (L.) ― -b6- kahadotuhu (so in the copies of the K; but differently in the S: [see 4:] TA I made him to be quick, or to hasten. (K.)

4 A^akohadotuhu *
I made him (an ass) to run. (S, L.) See also 1. ― -b2- Akhd He fatigued, tired, or wearied, (L, K,) his companion. (L.)

Q. Q. 4 A_ikowahad~a *
It (a young bird) trembled, or fluttered, before its mother, that she might feed it: (S, L:) and he (an old man) trembled: (L:) i. q. A_iqomahad~a. (K.)

kahodN *
Distress; trouble; fatigue; weariness; i. q. jahodN. (TA.) You say A^aSaAbahu jahodN wakahodN [Distress, &c., befell him]. (L, K.)

kahodaA='u *
A female slave: (K:) so called because of her quickness in service. (TA.)

kahuwdu Alyadayoni *
A she-ass quick in the fore legs. (L, K.)

kaAhidN *
and mukohadN↓ Fatigued; tired; weary. (L.)

kawohadN *
One who trembles by reason of old age. (K.)

mukohadN *
: see kaAhidN.

kahodabN *
A heavy, or dull, man: syn. vaqiylN waxomN. (K.)

1 kaharahu *
, aor.
kahara
, inf. n. kahorN, He chid him with rough speech, (S, Mgh, K,) to show him contempt. (TA.) ― -b2- He reviled him. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- He encountered him with a frowning face, (K,) to show him contempt: (TA:) or he frowned at him. (TA.) ― -b4- He oppressed him; i. q. qaharahu. (S, K.) So in the Kur, [xciii. 9,] faA^am~aA A@loyatiyma falaA tkoharo [Therefore, as to the orphan, thou shalt not oppress him]; accord. to the reading of Ibn-Mes'ood. (Ks, S.) Yaakoob says, that the k in kaharahu is a substitute for the q in qaharahu. (TA.)

kahorabN *
and kahorabaA [or kahorubaA] A well-known yellow substance; [yellow amber]: from the Persian kaAhu rubaA, i. e., “ carrying off straw, ” [on account of its electric attraction]. (TA.) See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 468: and see HawarN.
See Supplement

kahokabN *
and kahokamN i. q. baA*inojaAnN [The eggplant, or melongena]. (IAar, T, K.) Mentioned in the T in art. khkm; whence it seems that the b is a substitute for m. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 kaAba *
, aor. yakuwbu; and AktAb↓; He drank with a kuwb, the kind of mug or cup so called. (IAar, K.)

2 kw~b *
, inf. n. yakowiybN, He pounded, or brayed, a thing with a fihor [or kuwbap, q. v.] (K.)

8 A_ikotawaba
see 1.

kuwbN *
A mug, or drinking-cup, (kuwzN,) without a handle: (Fr, S, K:) or one (with a round top, TA,) that has no spout: (K:) or a vessel, (Bd in lvi. 18,) or drinking-cup, (Jel. ibid.) having neither handle nor spout: (Bd, Jel. ibid.:) pl. A^akowaAbN. (S, K.)

kawabN *
Slenderness of the neck with bigness of the head. (L, K.)

kawobapN *
A sighing, or grief, or regret, for something that has past, or escaped one. (K.) Probably formed from the mahmooz word [kaA^obapN]. (TA.) [Perhaps an inf. n.]

kuwbapN *
, occurring in a trad., in which it is forbidden, (TA,) The game called narod; (K;) an appellation given to that game by the people of El-Yemen: (A 'Obeyd, on the authority of Mohammad Ibn-Ketheer; and IAth) or that called $iToranoj: (K:) or a small drum, slender in the middle: (S, K:) accord. to some, (TA,) the musical instrument called barobaT; (K;) as occurring in a trad. of 'Alee, in which a command is given to break the thing thus called. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. q. fihorN; (K;) i. e., A small stone, such as fills the hand. (TA.)

kuwtiY~N *
Short: (K:) or a short and deformed or ill-shapen man. (So in a marginal note in two copies of the S.)

2 kw~v *
, inf. n. takowiyvN, It (growing corn or the like) became composed of four leaves, and of five. (En-Nadr, K.) ＝ -A2- kw~v bigaAy^iTihi, inf. n. takowiyvN, He voided his excrement [in form] resembling the heads of hares, or rabbits. (K.)

kaAvN *
i. q. kaAv~N, [q. v. in art. kv]. (K.)

kawovN *
A qafo$, or kind of short boot: (AM, K:) app. an arabicized word. (AM, L.)

kawovapN *
What is composed of four leaves, and of five: referring to growing corn and the like: n. un. of kawovN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kawovapN, or kuwvapN↓, [as in different copies of the K, the latter being the reading in the TA, which mentions kwyvp as another reading,] Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; plenty; fruitfulness. (K.)

kuwovapN *
: see kawovapN.

kuwiviY~N *
Short: like kuwtiY~N [q. v.]. (T.)

1 kaAHahu *
, [aor. yakuwHu,] inf. n. kawoHN; and kw~Hhu↓, and AkAHhu↓, and kAwHhu↓; He fought with him and overcame him: (K:) so Az, explains kAwHhu, inf. n. mukaAwaHapN: or, accord. to the M, kAwHhu↓ signifies he fought with him; and kAHh, he overcame him; (TA;) and kw~Hhu↓, inf. n. takowiyHN, also has this last signification; (IAar, S, TA;) and so AkAHhu↓, inf. n. A_ikaAHapN. (IAar, TA.)

2 kaw~aHa
See 1. ― -b2- Also kw~Hhu, (inf. n. takowiyHN, TA,) He abased him; rendered him abject; syn. A^a*al~ahu. (K.) ― -b3- It (the nose-rein) rendered him (a camel) submissive, or tractable. (TA.)

3 kaAowaHa
See 1. ― -b2- Also kAwHhu He reviled him, or vilified him, mutually; and treated him in an open manner (S, K) with opposition or altercation. (TA.)

4 AkAHhu *
He destroyed him. (T, in this art; and K in art. kyH.) See 1.

6 takaAwaHaA *
They two laboured, or strove, each with the other, to do evil, or mischief. (S, K.)

kaAHN *
and kiyHN↓ The foot, or base, (EuroD,) of a mountain: (S, K:) [or] its face, or part facing the spectator, above its foot, or base; syn. sanadu jabalK: (S:) or its foot, or base, (ErD) and most rugged part: or its safoH [i. q. EuroD]; and the foot, or base, of its face; syn. safoHu sanadihi: or kiyHN signifies the side (naAHiyap) of a mountain: and any rugged face of a mountain, above its foot, or base: and in some cases, the side of a valley, when it is rugged, but not unless consisting of the hardest and roughest of stones: (As, TA:) pl. of kaAHN, A^akowaAHN; (M;) and (of kiyHN↓, TA,) A^akoyaAHN and koyuwHN (K) and kiyaHapN. (As, T.) ― -b2- A^akoyaHu kiyHN↓ A rough or rugged [foot, or base, or face above the foot or base, &c., of a mountain]; an expression similar to yawomN A^ayowamu; (K, art. kyH;) the latter word being a corroborative; for the sanad of a mountain is called kyH only because of its ruggedness and roughness. (TA.)

kyHN *
: see kaAHN.

kaAxN *
: see kuwxN.

kuwxN *
, (S, L, K,) a Persian word, (L,) and kaAxN↓, (K,) A house [or hut] with a gibbous roof: (L, TA:) a house [or hut] of reeds or canes, (with a gibbous roof, K,) without an aperture for the admission of light: (S, L, K:) any place which a husbandman or a gardener prepares in which to guard his growing corn or his garden: and the people of Marw give the name of kAx↓ to a pavilion (qaSor) made in a garden or other place: (L:) pl. A^akowaAxN (S, K) and kuwxaAnN and kiyxaAnN and kiwaxapN: (K, TA:) [the last, in the CK, written kuwaxapN].

1 kaAda yafoEalu ka*aA *
, (S, K, * &c,) [originally kawida,] first pers. kidotu, accord. to the usage of most of the Arabs, (IKtt,) aor. yakaAdu, (S, K, &c.,) the form used by all the Arabs, (IKtt.) or yakuwdu [is also used, by some of those who make the pret. to be originally kawuda], (Lth,) inf. n. kawodN (Lth, S, M, K, &c) and kaAdN (M, IKtt) and makaAdapN (Lth, S, M, K, &c.) and makaAdN; (Lth, M, K;) and kaAda, originally kawuda, deviating from constant rule, (MF,) first pers. kudotu, (S, IKtt, MF,) in the dial. of the Benoo-'Adee, (MF,) mentioned by Sb as heard from some of the Arabs, (S,) aor. yakaAdu, (IKtt,) deviating from constant rule, (MF,) [and yakuwdu, mentioned above, agreeably with rule;] as also kaAda, (Msb, K, art. kyd,) originally kayida, first pers. kidotu, aor. yakaAdu, (Msb, art. kyd,) inf. n. kayodN; (L, art. kyd;) and kiyda, (S, K, &c.,) a form mentioned by Abu-l-Khattáb to Sb, as used by some of the Arabs, who in like manner said maA ziyla yafoEalu ka*aA, for kaAda and zaAla; (S;) He was near to doing so; he nearly, well nigh, or almost, did so; he wanted but little of doing so; (Akh, S, M, K, &c.;) he purposed, or intended, doing so; (Lth, M, IKtt;) but did it not, [or did it not immediately]. (Akh, S, K, &c.) kaAda is applied to signify the being near to doing a thing whether it be [afterwards] done or not done. (S.) Without a negative, it enunciates the negation of the action; and coupled with a negative, it enunciates the happening of the action. (S, K.) [This will be explained in the course of the following observations.] It is (as Es-Suyootee says in the Itkán) an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, of which only the pret. and aor. are used. It has a noun as the subject, in the nom. case; and an aor., [generally] without A^ano, as the predicate. (TA.) Sometimes they introduce A^ano after it, likening it to EasaY; as, for ex., in the saying of Ru-beh,
qado kaAda mino Tuwli AlbilaY A^ano yamoSaHaA
[It had nearly come to nought from length of wear]. (S.) Used affirmatively, it is affirmative of the being near [to doing a thing, &c.]; and used negatively, it is negative thereof. It is a well-known opinion of many, that, used affirmatively, it is negative; and used negatively, it is affirmative: so that kaAda zayodN yafoEalu means [Zeyd was near to doing; but] he did not [or did not immediately]; as is shown by the expression [in the Kur xvii. 75, where A_ino is a contraction of A_in~a,] waA_ino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka [And verily they were near to seducing thee]: and maA kaAda yafoEalu means [He was not near to doing; but] he did; as is shown by the expression [in the Kur ii. 66,] wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [And they were not near to doing (it); but they afterwards did (it)]. I'Ab is related to have said, that wherever kaAda and A^akaAdu and yakaAdu occur in the Kur-án, they denote a thing's never happening. Some say, that kaAda [with a negative] denotes an action's happening with difficulty. Some, again, say, that the pret. preceded by a negative is affirmative [of the action &c.]; as is shown by the expression wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [quoted above]: and that the aor. preceded by a negative is negative; as is shown by the expression [in the Kur xxiv, 40,] lamo yakado yaraAhaA [He is not near to seeing it]; meaning that he sees not anything: [though this phrase is said to bear a different meaning, which see below]. But the correct opinion is the one first mentioned; that, used affirmatively, it is affirmative [of the being near to do a thing &c.]; and used negatively, it is negative [thereof]: so that kaAda yafoEalu signifies He was near to doing; but did not [or did not immediately]: and maA kaAda yafoEalu He was not near to doing; much less did he do [or do immediately]; the denial of the action [or of the immediate performance of the action] being necessarily understood from the denial of the being near to do it. As to the expression in the Kur, wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [quoted above], it enunciates the state of the people to whom it relates in the beginning of their case; for they were far from sacrificing the cow; and the affirmation of the action is understood only from the [preceding] expression fa*abaHuwhaA. And as to the expression [in the Kur xvii. 76,] laqado kidt~a tarokanu A_ilayohimo [Thou hadst certainly been near to inclining to them], the Prophet's not inclining to them little or much is understood from lawolaA [preceding], which requires this inference. (TA.) [Often, however, or (as some say) generally, with a negative preceding or following it, it is affirmative of the action's happening, but only after difficulty, or delay.] Aboo-Bekr says, that maA kaAda fulaAnN yaquwmu means [Such a one hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, rose; like lamo yakado yaquwmu, and kaAda laA yaquwmu; waqado qaAma being understood; or] he rose after being slow, or tardy: (L:) and accord. to Az and others, maA kidotu A^afoEalu means [I hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, did; or] I did after being slow, or tardy: but sometimes it means I was not near to doing. (Msb, art. kyd.) It is said, that kaAda is sometimes a [mere redundant] connective (Silap) of the members of a sentence; (Kutr, Akh, AHát, K;) as in lamo yakado yaraAhaA [quoted above], meaning, He does not see it: (K:) or this means he is not near to seeing it: or, as some say, he sees it after his having been not near to seeing it by reason of the intenseness of the darkness: [or he hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, sees it:] and Fr says, with reference to the verse in which this phrase occurs, that it is allowable to say lamo yakado yaquwmu [meaning, He hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, rose] when one has risen after difficulty. (TA.) [Thus it appears, that, maA kaAda yafoEalu and lamo yakado yafoEalu sometimes signify He hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, did: and sometimes, he was not near to doing; he never did; he did not at all: so that it may be rendered he hardly or scarcely, or nowise or in nowise or never, did: or he could hardly do, or he could not at all, or could not nearly, or he could nowise or in nowise, do.] ― -b2- As asserts his having heard certain of the Arabs say, laA A^afoEalu *`lika walaA kawodFA [I will not do that, nor will I be near to doing it]. (S.) ― -b3- kaAda also signifies He desired; syn. A^araAda. (Akh, S, K.) So in the verse
kaAdato wakidotu watiloka xayoru A_iraAdapK
lawo EaAda mino lahowi AlS~abaAbapi maA maDaY
[She desired, and I desired; and that were the best of desire, if what hath passed, of the diverting delight of tender love, returned]. (Akh, S.) So, too, in the saying in the Kur [xx. 15,] A^akaAdu A^uxofiyhaA I desire (S, K) to conceal it: or, to manifest it: (Beyd:) for, like as it is allowable to put A^uriydu in the place of A^akaAdu, as in the saying in the Kur [xviii. 76,] jidaArFA yuriydu A^ano yanoqaD~a, so it is to use AkAd [in the place of Aryd]: Akh says, that the words of the verse in question mean I will conceal it, A^uxofiyhaA: and some say, that the meaning is I will manifest it: (TA:) but most hold, that AkAd should here be rendered in its original sense. (MF, TA.) Some of the Arabs make kAd to denote certainty; like Zan~a, which primarily denotes doubt, and secondarily certainty. (L, art. kyd.) ― -b4- Earafa maA yukaAdu minohu [is in like manner explained] He hath become acquainted with that which is desired of him. (S, K.) ― -b5- You say to him who seeks of you a thing, when you do not desire to give him it, laA walaA makaAdapa walaA maham~apa, (Lth, S, * L, K, *) and laA kawodFA walaA ham~FA, and laA makaAdFA walaA maham~FA, (Lth, L,) i. e. laA A^akaAdu walaA A^ahum~u [No, nor do I desire, nor do I purpose, or intend]. (Lth, L, K.) ― -b6- You also say, in the same sense, laA maham~apa liY walaA makaAdapa [I have no purpose or intention, nor any desire]. (S) ― -b7- See also kaAda in art. kyd.

2 kw~* *
, inf. n. takowiy*N, It (an A_izaAr [or a wrapper for the lower part of the body and the thighs]) reached to the part called the kaA*ap (L, K) only. (L.) ― -b2- He (a man in the act of concubitus) thrust against the sides of the pubes. (K.) ― -b3- He beat or struck, with a staff, or stick, upon the posteriors, (K,) between the thigh and the hip. (TA.)

kaA*apN *
What surrounds the vulva, of the exterior of the two thighs: (L, K:) or the portion of flesh of the inner side of the thigh; the two together are called the kaA*ataAni: (As, L:) or the flesh of the hinder part of the thigh: (L, K:) or the part of the thigh which is the place that is cauterized in the hinder part of the thigh of the ass; so in a man &c.: (L:) or the kaA*ataAni are two compact portions of flesh in the upper part of each thigh of an ass, the place that is cauterized, between the thigh and the haunch: (T, L:) or the flesh of the outer sides of the two thighs, below the jaAEirataAni; (AHeyth, T, L;) and this is the correct signification: (T, L:) or the prominent flesh in the upper parts of the thigh: (S, L:) pl. kaA*aAtN and [quasi-pl., or coll. gen. n.,] kaA*N. (L.)

mukaw~i*N *
An A_zaAr [or a wrapper for the lower part of the body and the thighs] reaching to the part called the kaA*ap (L, K) only; or, to the kaA*ataAni, when it is put on. (L.)

1 kaAra AlEimaAmapa EalaY raA^osihi *
, (S, A, Msb, *) aor. yakuwru, (S, Msb,) inf. n. kaworN, (S, Msb, K,) He wound round the turban upon his head; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also kw~rhA↓, inf. n. takowiyrN: (S, A, K:) or the latter has an intensive signification [app. meaning he wound it round many times upon his head; or in many folds]: and hence you say, Al$~aYo'a kw~r↓ he wound the thing in a round form. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Hence the saying, HaAra baEoda maA kaAra, (Zj, in TA, art. Hwr,) (assumed tropical:) He became in a bad state of affairs after he had been in a good state: or he became in a state of defectiveness after he had been in a state of redundance. (TA, art. Hwr.) See also kaworN, below. ＝ -A3- kaAra, (TA,) inf. n. kaworN, (K,) He carried a kaArap, q. v., (K, TA,) upon his back; (TA;) as also AstkAr↓. (K, TA.)

2 kaw~ara
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- A_i*aA Al$~amosu kuw~irato, in the Kur [lxxxi. 1,] When the sun shall be wound round [with darkness] like a turban: (AO, S:) or shall be wrapped up and effaced: (AO accord. to the S, or Akh accord. to the TA:) or shall be wrapped up and have its light taken away: (Jel:) or shall have its light collected together and wrapped up like as a turban is wrapped: (TA:) or shall be folded up like as a sijil~ [or scroll] is folded up: (Msb:) or shall lose its light: (Fr, Katádeh, S:) or shall be divested of its light: ('Ikrimeh:) or shall be blinded; syn. Eaw~irato: (I'Ab, S:) or shall pass away and come to nought: or shall be collected together and cast down into the depth below; syn. duhowirato: (both of which are explanations given by Mujáhid:) or shall be cast away. (Er-Rabeea Ibn-Kheythem.) ＝ -A3- yukaw~iru A@ll~ayola EalaY A@ln~ahaAri (Kur xxxix. 7) He maketh the night to be a covering upon the day: or He addeth of the night to the day: (S:) or He maketh the night to overtake the day: (TA:) or He bringeth in the night upon the day: (K:) from kaw~ara AlEimaAmapa: all of which meanings are nearly alike. (TA.) ＝ -A4- kw~r AlmataAEa, (A, K:) inf. n. takowiyrN, (S,) He collected together the goods and bound or tied them: (S, K:) or he put the goods one upon another. (A.) ＝ -A5- TaEanahu fakaw~arahu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He smote and pierced him [with his spear], and threw him down gathered together, or in a heap. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- Darabaha fakaw~arahu He smote him, and threw him down prostrate: (K, * TA:) [like jaw~arahu:] or kw~rhu signifies he prostrated him, whether he smote him or not. (TA.)

5 tkw~r *
He fell upon his side, and drew himself together; syn. taqaT~ara wata$am~ara: (S, K:) or he wrapped himself up, and tucked up his garment, or skirt, or the like; syn. talaf~afa wata$am~ara. (TA.) ― -b2- He fell; fell down. (S, K.) ― -b3- He became prostrated; as also A_ikotaAra↓: (K:) or AktAr signifies he prostrated a thing, one part upon another. (TA.)

8 AktAr *
He turbaned himself; attired himself with a turban. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 5.

10 A_isotakowara
see 1, last signification.

kaworN *
, (S, Msb,) an inf. n. used as a subst., (Msb,) or kuwrN↓, (ISh, T, A,) A turn, or twist, of a turban: (ISh, T, A, Msb:) pl. A^akowaArN. (A, Msb.) You say, AlEimaAmapu Ei$oruwna kuwrFA [The turban is composed of twenty turns], and Ea$arapu A^akowaArK [ten turns]. (A.) ＝ -A2- Increase; or redundance. (S, A, Msb.) Hence the saying, naEuw*u biAll~`hi mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawori (S, A, Msb) We have recourse to God for preservation from decrease, or defectiveness, after increase, or redundance: (S, Msb:) or, as it is also related, baEoda Alkawoni, which means the same: or the meaning is, from return to disobedience after obedience: (Msb:) or from return after pursuing a right course. (TA.) See also HaworN.

kuwrN *
: see kaworN. ＝ -A2- A camel's [saddle of the kind called] raHol: (K, TA:) as also makowarN↓ (K) and mukowar~N↓, the latter with damm to the m and teshdeed to the r: (TS, L:] or a raHol with its apparatus: (S, Msb, K:) pronounced by many kaworN; but this is a mistake: (IAth:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akowaArN (S, Msb, K) and A^akowurN, (K,) and (of mult., TA) kiyraAnN (S, Msb, K) and kuwraAnN and kuw^uwrN, which last, says ISd, is extr. as a pl. form of a sing. such as kwr with an infirm letter. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A blacksmith's fire-place; (S, * A, Msb;) his majomarap; (K;) constructed of clay: (S, Msb, K: *) and also said to signify the skin [with which he blows his fire]: (Msb, TA:) or this latter is called [only] kiyrN: (A, in the present art.; and S, Msb, K, art. kyr:) an arabicized word. (Msb.) ＝ -A4- [A hornets', or bees', nest;] the place, (S, K,) or structure, (TA,) of hornets: (Alz~anaAbiyr, S, K [in the CK, Ald~anaAniyr, which is a mistake:]) or of bees: (accord. to a trad. cited in the TA:) pl. A^akowaArN. (TA.) See also kuwaArapN.

kaArapN *
A bundle (HaAlN) which a man carries on his back: or a bundle (EikomN) of clothes, put in one piece of cloth [and tied up]: such is that of the qaS~aAr [or beater and washer and whitener of clothes]: (TA:) or the kArp is what is carried on the back, [being a bundle] of clothes: (S:) or what are put together and tied up [in a wrapper] of clothes: (Msb:) or a certain quantity of wheat; (K, TA;) which a man carries on his back: (TA:) pl. kaAraAtN. (A, Msb.) [See also EajalapN.]

kuwrapN *
A province, district, or tract of country; a quarter, or region; syn. SuqoEN: (S, Msb, K:) a mixolaAf [q. v.] of a country; i. e., a qaroyapN [which properly signifies a town or village] of the qurFY of El-Yemen: (M, TA:) [but mxlAf is generally used in the first of the senses here assigned to kwrp:] and also a city: (S, Msb, K:) [or a provincial city: but the first of these significations is the most common, as is implied in the Msb: see also banodN:] pl. kuwarN, (S, Msb, K,) like as gurafN is pl. of gurofapN. (Msb.) IDrd says, I do not think it Arabic. (TA.) [Perhaps from the Greek χῶρα.]

kiwaArN *
and kiwaArapN: see kuwaArapN.

kuwaArapu naHolK *
, (S, Msb, K,) and kuw~aArap↓, (Msb, K,) written in both these ways in the T, in explanation of the word EamiyrapN, (Mgh,) and kiwaArap↓, (T, TS, L, K,) and kiwaAr↓, (T, TS, L, Msb,) A bee-hive; or habitation of bees; syn. xaliy~apN: (Msb:) or a bee-hive, when made of clay: (El-Ghooree, in Mgh:) or a bee-hive, or habitation of bees, when containing honey: (Msb:) or a thing made for bees, of twigs, (T, Mgh, TS,) or of clay, (TS, K,) or of twigs and clay, accord. to most copies of the K, or of twigs only, accord. to most of the lexicologists, (TA,) like a qiroTaAlap [an asses' pannier], (T, Mgh, TS,) narrow at the head, (T, Mgh, TS, K,) in which they make their honey: (TA:) or the honey of bees in the wax: (S, Msb, K:) or kuw~aAraAtN↓ [pl. of kuw~aArapN] signifies domestic bee-hives; as also kawaAy^irN. (AHn, K.) [Of the latter pl., it is said in the TA, that ISd holds it to be pl., not of
kwArp, but, of kuw~arap: but the passage seems to be corrupt.]

kuw~aArapN *
: see kuwaArapN.

makowarN *
: see kuwrN.

mikowarN *
and mikowarapN↓ and mikowaArapN↓ A turban. (IAar, Sgh, K.)

mukowar~N *
: see kuwrN.

mikowarapN *
: see mikowarN.

mikowaArapN *
: see mikowarN.

1 kaAza *
, aor. yakuwzu, (TA,) inf. n. kawozN, (K,) He collected a thing. (K *, TA.) ＝ -A2- He drank with a kuwz; (K, * TA;) as also AktAz↓. (TA.)

5 tkw~zwA *
They collected themselves together. (Sgh, K.)

8 AktAzhu *
He ladled it out (namely water, S, A) with a kuwz. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

kuwzN *
A kind of vessel, (TA,) well-known, (A, K,) [namely, a mug, or drinking-cup,] with a handle: (IAar, TA:) AHn says, that it is a Persian word; but ISd denies this, and asserts it to be genuine Arabic: it is said to be from kaAza “ he collected: ” (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akowaAzN, and [of mult.] kiyzaAnN and kiwazapN. (S, K.)

kaw~aAzapN *
[app. A stand, or a shelf, upon which mugs (kiyzaAn) are placed: see bar~aAdapN]. (Lth, T, art. brd.)

rajulN mukaw~azu Alr~aA^osi *
A man having a long head. (A, K.)

1 kaAsa *
, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yakuwsu, inf. n. kawosN, (Msb, TA,) He (a camel) walked upon three legs, (S, Msb, K,) being hamstrung: (S, K:) or raised one of his legs, and jumped upon the rest. (TA.) Thus you say of a quadruped: but when said of another, it means, He went upon one leg. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kaAsa, (S, A, TA,) aor. yakuwsu, (S, TA,) inf. n. kawosN, (A, TA,) He (a man) became turned upside down, (S, TA,) head downwards; (S;) as also tkw~s↓. (K.) ― -b2- He (a poor man) fell upon his head. (A, * TA.) ＝ -A3- kaAsa fulaAnFA, (K,) aor. yakuwsuhu, inf. n. kawosN, (TA,) He prostrated such a one; (K;) as also AkAshu↓, (K,) inf. n. A_ikaAsapN; (TA;) which latter verb is the more chaste: (Sgh:) or he threw him down upon his head; as also kw~shu↓: (TA:) or this last, which is said of God, (S, A, K,) inf. n. takowiysN, (S, K,) signifies He turned him upside down, (K,) or head downwards, (S,) or upon his head, (A,) fiY Aln~aAri in the fire [of Hell]: (S, A:) and you say also, EalaY raA^osihi kaw~asotuhu↓, meaning, I turned him over upon his head. (S.)

2 kaw~asa
see 1, in three places.

4 AkAs AlbaEiyra *
, (K,) inf. n. A_ikaAsapN, (TA,) He made the camel to walk upon three legs, by hamstringing him. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 takaw~asa
see 1.

kaAsN *
: see kaA^osN.

kuwsN *
A drum: said to be an arabicized word [from the Persian kuwsN, pronounced “ kós, ” but in Arabic “ koos, ” and applied in the present day to a kettle-drum; accord. to Golius, a kettle-drum that used to be beaten in the camps and palaces of kings]. (S, K.) [The modern pl. is kuwsaAt.] ＝ -A2- Hence, A farosax [or parasang, or league, in which sense also it is of Persian origin]: because this is the utmost distance at which may be heard the beating of the kws. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, A triangular piece of wood with which a carpenter measures the squareness of wood. (Lth, A, * K.) It is [in this sense likewise] a Persian word. (TA.)
See Supplement

kawokabN *
&c.: see art. kkb.
See Supplement

superEntry.head: kyA^ and kwA^
superEntry.entry:
1 kaA='a Eani AlA^amori *
, first pers. kiy^otu, aor. yakiYo'u, inf. n. kaYo'N and kayoy^apN; (S, K; *) and kaA='a Eanohu, first pers. kuw^otu, aor. yakuwo'u, inf. n. kawo'N and kaA='N and kaA^owN, this last formed by transposition; (K;) He abstained from the thing through timidity: (TA:) or he dreaded the thing, and abstained from it through cowardice: (S, K, TA:) or his eye reverted from the thing, and he desired it not. (TA.) ― -b2- kaA'a Eanohu He retired from him through fear. (TA.) [Accord. to the TA, it seems that A^akaA='ahu↓ also has this signification.]

4 AkA'h *
, inf. n. A_ikaA='N and A_ikaA='apN, He came upon him suddenly, when he (the latter) was about to do a thing, and caused him to abstain from it through fear or cowardice. (K, TA.) But some say that this is correctly A^akaA^ahu; like kataba, inf. n. kitaAbN and kitaAbapN. (TA, art. A^akA^.) ― -b2- See 1.

kaA='N *
and kaA='apN and kaYo'N↓ (S, K) and kayoy^apN (K) A weak-hearted, cowardly, man: (K, TA:) like kaE~N and kaAE~N. (S.)

kaYo'N *
and kayoy^apN: see kaA='N.

2 ky~t *
, inf. n. takoyiytN, He stuffed, or filled, a bag or other receptacle for travelling-provisions or for goods or utensils &c. (En-Nawádir, TS, K.) ― -b2- Also, He made his travelling-apparatus light, or easy of conveyance; syn. yas~ara. (S, K.) A poet says,
kay~ito jihaAzaka A_im~aA kunota murotaHilFA
A_in~iY A^axaAfu EalaY A^a*owaAdika Als~abuEaA
[Make thy travelling apparatus light, when thou art departing on a journey; for I fear for thy droves, or troops, of camels, on account of the beast of prey]. (S.)

A^akoyaAtN *
i. q. A^akoyaAsN, [pl. of kay~isN:] (K:) the Rájiz says,
gayor A^aEif~aA'i walaA A^akoyaAti
[Not such as abstain from things unlawful and unbecoming, nor ingenious, or acute in mind, &c.]. (TA.) See art. s p. 1281 a. Some say, that it it is a word mispronounced: others, that it is formed by the change of s into t, as in the case of Tas~N and TasotN. (TA.)

kaAna mina AlA^amori kayota wakayota *
, and kayot wakayoti, (AO, S, K, &c.,) and kyotu wakayotu, (IAth, ISd, IKtt,) i. e. ka*aA waka*aA, [Some of the circumstances of the case were thus and thus; or so and so; or such and such things]. (Lth, K.) The t in kyt is originally p; (S, K:) as in the case of *ayot; these two words being originally kay~ap and *ay~ap: (TA:) or the t in kyt and *yt is substituted for Y: they are originally kay~ap and *ay~ap; and the p is elided, and the Y which is the last radical letter is changed into t: so accord. to AHei; and most of the leading authorities on inflexion assert the same. (MF. voce *ayota.) See *yt.

1 kaAdahu *
, aor. yakiydu, (S, L, Msb,) inf. n. kayodN (S, L, Msb, K) and makiydapN, (S, L, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and kAydhu↓, (A,) inf. n. mukaAyadapN; (S;) or this implies reciprocation; (TA;) [and AktAdhu↓, which see below. app. signifies the same as kaAdahu like as AixotadaEahu signifies the same as xadaEahu;] He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him or he deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; and desired to do him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action,
clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded; i. q. makara bihi (S, L, Msb, K) and xadaEahu: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, mkrbh implies the feigning of the contrary of one's real intentions; whereas kAdh does not: or this latter signifies he did him harm, or mischief; and the former, he did so clandestinely. (MF.) ― -b2- kaAda, aor. yakiydu, (L,) inf. n. kayodN and makiydapN, (L, K,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He acted deceitfully, mischievously, or wickedly. (L, K.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. kayodN, He practised an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient; or he exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management or ordering of affairs,, with excellent consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage with subtilty according to his own free will; syn. AixotaAla; (L:) and of the inf. n., HiylapN. (L, K.) ― -b4- kaAdahu He taught him Alkayod [i. e., to deceive, beguile, or circumvent, &c., or, to act deceitfully, mischievously, or wickedly; or, to practise modes, or means, of evading or cluding, &c.]. So some explain it in the Kur xii. 76. (TA.) ― -b5- It is said in a trad., maA qawoluka fiY EuquwlK kaAdahaA xaAliquhaA What sayest thou of intellects to which their Creator hath desired to do evil? (L.) So some explain the verb in the Kur xxi. 58. (TA.) ― -b6- yakiyduwna kayodFA waA^akiydu kayodFA [Kur lxxxvi. 16, They practise an artful device, and I will practise an artful device]. kayodu A@ll~`hi lilokuf~aAri [God's practising an artful device towards the unbelievers] means his taking them unawares, so that they do not reckon upon it; bestowing upon them enjoyments in which they delight, and on which they place their reliance, and with which they become familiar so as not to be mindful of death, and then taking them in their most heedless state; A_isotidoraAjuhumo mino Hayovu laA yaEolamuwna. (Zj, L.) ― -b7- kaAda, aor. yakiydu, inf. n. kayodN, He contrived, devised, or plotted, a thing, whether wrong or right. Ex. fulaAnN yakiydu A^amorF maA A^adoriY maA huwa Such a one contrives, devises, or plots, a thing: I know not what it is. (L.) ― -b8- kaAda, aor. yakiydu, He worked, or laboured, at, or upon, anything; he laboured, took pains, applied himself vigorously, exerted himself, strove, or struggled, to do, execute, or perform, or to effect, or accomplish, or to manage, or treat, anything; he laboured, strove, or struggled, with anything, to prevail, or overcome, or to effect an object; syn. EaAlaja. (S, L.) ― -b9- kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, He strove, or laboured; exerted himself, or his power or ability; employed himself vigorously, laboriously, sedulously, or earnestly; was diligent; took extraordinary pains. (L.) ＝ -A2- kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, He (a raven or crow) exerted himself in his croaking. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- kaAda binafosihi, (K,) aor. yakiydu, (S, L,) inf. n. kayodN, (L,) (tropical:) He gave up his spirit: (S, L, K:) endured distress in giving up the ghost. (A.) ― -b2- kaAda, (K,) inf. n. kayodN, (S, K,) He vomited. (S, K.) ― -b3- kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, It (a zanod) emitted fire. (L, K.) ― -b4- kaAdato, (L, K,) aor. takiydu, inf. n. kayodN, (L,) She had the menstrual flux. (L, K.) ＝ -A4- laA A^afoEalu *`lika walaA kayodFA walaA ham~FA I will not do that, nor do I desire, nor do I purpose, or intend. (K, * TA.) See kaAda in art. kwd. ＝ -A5- kaAda yafoEalu ka*aA, (L. Msb, K,) originally kayida, first pers. kidotu, aor. yakaAdu; (L, Msb;) and kiyda: (L, K:) see art. kwd. [It is mentioned in arts. kwd and kyd in the L, K: in the former only in the S: and in the latter only in the Msb.]

3 kaAoyada
see 1.

6 humaA yatakaAyadaAni *
(L, K) They two deceive, beguile, or circumvent, each other; or do so, each desiring to do to the other a foul, abominable, or evil, action clandestinely. (TK.) See 1. You should not say yatakaAwadaAni. (L, K.)

8 AktAd *
is of the measure AfotaEala from Alkayodu; (K;) and AktAdhu signifies A_HotaAlahu [or rather A_iHotaAla Ealayohi]. (TK.) See 1.

kayodN *
: see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) War: (S, K:) so called because of the stratagems employed therein. (TA.) One says, gazaA fulaAnN falamo yaloqa kayodFA (tropical:) Such a one went on a hostile expedition and found not war: (S, L:) i. e., did not fight. (A.) ― -b3- kayodN *aAtu gadorK (tropical:) A war characterized by perfidy. kyd is here made fem. because meaning HarobN. (L, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- kayodN Vomit. (S, * L, K. *) balaEa Alkayoda. He swallowed vomit. (L, from a trad.)

makiydapN *
: see 1. ― -b2- As a simple subst., Deceit, guile, or circumvention, and desire to do a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, to another clandestinely: (Msb:) [and an evasion, or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, &c.: see 1 as intrans.:] pl. makaAy^idu. (A.)

kiyrN *
[A blacksmith's bellows;] a blacksmith's [skin, of the kind called] ziq~, into which he blows: (Mgh, K:) or a blacksmith's skin (ziq~), with which he blows [his fire]: (Msb:) also, (Msb,) composed of a thick skin (jilod, S, Msb, or ziq~, S), with HaAfaAt [or edges, forming a wide mouth, which being opened and closed by means of two pieces of wood to which the edges are sewed, the skin becomes filled with air, which is then forced out through a pipe at the end opposite the mouth: such, at least, is the most common kind of bellows used by the Arabs of the present day with which I am acquainted]: but the thing constructed of clay [in which the blacksmith kindles his fire] is called kuwrN: (S, Msb:) so ISk says he heard AA say: (Msb:) [but see kuwrN: and see a verse cited in the last paragraph of art. Ewr:] the pl. [of pauc.] is A^akoyaArN, and [of mult.] kiyarapN (Msb, K) and kiyraAnN; (K;) the last on the authority of Th; but doubtful; for it is not known in the lexicons, and is [properly] pl. of kuwrN. (TA.)

1 kaAsa *
, aor. yakiysu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. kayosN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and kiyaAsapN (S, A, K) and kuwsaY, with w put in the place of Y, [originally kuyosaY,] (Seer [mentioned by him as syn. with kayosN]) He (a boy, S [but often said of a man also,]) was, or became, acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; shrewd; clever; ingenious; skilful; knowing; intelligent: kayosN being the contr. of HumoqN; (S, A, K;) and i. q. ZarofN, (Mgh, Msb,) and xiq~apN, and tawaq~udN, (TA,) and fiTonapN, (Msb, TA,) and fiqohN, (TA,) and EaqolN. (IAar, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- kaAsa fiY AlA^amori, aor. yakiysu, (A, TA,) inf. n. kayosN; (Mgh, TA;) and tky~s↓; and tkAys↓; (A, TA;) He acted gently, (TA,) or with good gentleness or moderation or calmness, (Mgh,) in the affair. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- kaAsahu, aor. yakiysuhu, (S, * K,) inf. n. kayosN, (A, TA,) He overcame him, or surpassed him, (S, A, K,) in kiyaAsap (A, K) or kayos (A, Nh) [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect; &c.: see above]. So in the following words of a trad., (K,) said by the prophet to Jábir Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Ansáree, (TA,) A^ataraAniY A_in~amaA kisotuka liA=xu*a jamalaka laka Alv~amanu walaka Aljamalu [Dost thou think me to have only overcome thee in acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, &c., in order that I might take thy camel? Thine be the price, and thine be the camel]: (K, * TA:) or, according to another relation, xu*o jamalaka wamaAlaka [Take thou thy camel and thy property]: and accord. to another, A_in~amaA maA kasotuka [that I have only acted in a niggardly manner with thee], from AlmikaAsu. (TA.) ― -b2- kayisa, [aor. yakoyasu,] inf. n. kayasN, is also mentioned by IKtt as a dial. form of kaAsa in the sense of He overcame or surpassed [in acuteness &c.] (TA.)

2 ky~shu *
, (K,) inf. n. takoyiysN, (TA,) He (God, TK) made him acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent; (K, TA;) and well educated, or well bred. (TA.)

3 kAyshu *
, (S, A, K,) inf. n. mukaAyasapN, (TA), He vied, or contended, with him in kayos [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect; &c.: see 1]. (K.) You say, kaAyasotuhu fakisotuhu [I vied, or contended, with him in acuteness, &c., and] I overcame, or surpassed, him (S, A) [therein, i. e.] in kayos. (A.) And kaAyasahu fiY AlbayoEi (S, A) [He vied, or contended, with him in acuteness, &c., in selling; as seems to be indicated in the S: or] he jested, or joked, with him (laAgaAhu) in selling. (A, TA.)

4 A^akoyasa * and A^akaAsa
He (a man, S) had born to him children acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (S, K:) or he begot a child acute &c. (IKtt.) And A^akoyasato and A^akaAsato She brought forth children acute &c. (A.) A poet says,
falawo kunotumo limikoyasapK A^akaAsato
wakayosu AlA^um~i yuEorafu fiY AlbaniynaA
[But if ye belonged to one who most generally brought forth children acute in intellect, she had brought forth such children; for the acuteness of intellect of the mother is known in the sons]. (S.)

5 tky~s *
He affected acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, shrewdness, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence: [see taEaq~ala:] or did so, not having it: syn. taZar~afa: (S, K, TA:) he feigned, or made a show of, kayos [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect; &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

6 takaAoyasa
see 1.

kayosN *
: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also kay~isN.

kiysN *
[A purse;] a well known receptacle; (TA;) a thing made of pieces of rag sewed together; (Msb;) for money, (S, K, TA,) and for pearls and sapphires: (TA:) [so called] because it comprises them: (K, TA:) [a remark that seems to indicate a signification of kaAsa or some other word from the same root which I do not find elsewhere pointed out: but the more probable derivation is from the Persian kiysaho:] that which is tied up, of leather, and of pieces of rag, is not called thus, but is called xariyTapN: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^akoyaAsN (S, Msb, K) and kiyasapN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) The membrane that encloses a child in the womb; syn. ma$iymapN. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, (assumed tropical:) The scrotum.]

kay~isN *
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and kayosN↓, (TA,) [like hiy~inN and hayonN, &c.,] Acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever; ingenious; skilful; knowing; intelligent: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) fem. kay~isapN: (S, A:) and kiysaY↓, applied to a woman, is syn with kay~isapN, and is, as also kuwsaY, [each originally kuyosaY,] fem. of A^akoyasu: (S:) [whence it appears that this last word is accord. to J syn. with kay~isN; i. e., a simple epithet, like its contr. A^aHomaqu: but it has another signification, for which see below:] or, accord. to Kr, kiysaY and kuwsaY are pls. of kay~isapN; and there are no similar instances except DiyqaY and DuwqaY, pls. of Day~iqapN, and TuwbaY, pl. of Tay~ibapN: but ISd holds them to be fems. of the measure A^afoEalu: (TA: [see DuwqaY in art. Dyq:]) the pl. of kay~isN is A^akoyaAsN (A, Mgh, Msb, TA) and kayosaYi, (A, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, kiysY,]) like HamoqaY, (A,) having this latter form in order that it may resemble its contr., HamoqaY: (TA:) and kiyaAsN is pl. of kay~isapN, (A, TA,) [and A^akaAyiysu is app. pl. of kiyaAsN: see an ex. voce Ti$~apN.] You also say, rajulN kay~isN mukay~asN↓, meaning, A man acute or sharp or quick in intellect, &c.: (S:) or [acute &c., and] described as being so; or having the attribute of kayos ascribed to him: (A:) or rajulN mukay~asN↓ signifies, as also kay~isN, a man known as possessing kayos [or acuteness &c.]. (TA.) And A_imoraA^apN kay~isapN A woman well educated, or well bred. (TA.) And rajulN kay~isu AlfiEol A man good in action or conduct. (TA.) And banaY daArFA kay~isapF (A) (tropical:) He built an elegant house; syn. ZariyfapF. (TA.) [The dim. kuway~isN, more properly kuyay~isN or kiyay~isN, is much used in the present day as signifying (tropical:) Elegant, pretty, or beautiful.]

kuwsaY *
: see A^akoyasu: and kay~isN, in two places.

kiysaY *
: see A^akoyasu: and kay~isN, in two places.

kayosaAnu *
(tropical:) a proper name for Perfidy; (IAar, S, A, K;) as also A^abuw kayosaAna: (IAar:) of the dial. of Teiyi: and derived from kayosN. (Kr.) You say, rakiba kayosaAna (tropical:) He acted perfidiously. (A.)

A^akoyasN *
[More, and most, acute or sharp or quick in intellect; more, and most, shrewd, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent]: (Lth, ISd, A:) fem. kiysaY (ISd) and kuwsaY: (Lth, ISd:) [in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, and in the text of the K as given in the TA, kiysaY and kuwsaY, each of which is originally kuyosaY, are said to be fems. of A^akowasu; but this is evidently a mistake for A^akoyasu:] pl. kuwsN, [originally kuyosN,] which is applied to women, [as well as men,] and kuwsayaAtN, which is applied to women only. (Lth.) You say, h`*aA AlA^akoyasu [This is the more, or most, acute &c.]. (Lth.) And A^aY~u Almuw^ominiyna A^akoyasu Which of the believers is the most intelligent? (TA.) And it is said in a proverb, A^akoyasu mino qi$~apK (A) [(tropical:) More acute &c. than] a little female ape or monkey. (TA, art. q$.) And in a trad., A^akoyasu Alkayosi Alt~uqaY waA^aHomaqu AlHumoqi Alfujuwru (tropical:) [The most acute of acuteness is piety, and the most foolish of foolishness, or the most stupid of stupidness, is vice]. (A.) ― -b2- See also kay~isN.

mukiysapN *
A woman who brings forth children acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (TA:) and mikoyaAsN↓, who does so usually; contr. of miHomaAqN: (A:) [and mikoyasapN↓, who does so most generally: see an ex. of this under 4.]

mikoyasapN *
: see mukiysapN and 4.

mukay~asN *
: see kay~isN.

mikoyaAsN *
: see mukiysapN.
See Supplement
